2 SOUR Wisconsin Marriages, 1836-1930
1 NOTE Bert went to Wisconsin where he met Edna; he may have gone to
2 CONT be a school teacher.
2 CONT He returned to Vermont when his father died, and he then ran
2 CONT the family farm for a while.
2 CONT When he returned Vivian would have been two and Emma a
2 CONT newborn.
2 CONT Edna and Vivian returned to Wisconsin for awhile to help
2 CONT Ella, Edna's sister.
2 CONT Emma remained in Vermont and was raised for many years by her
2 CONT grandmother Warner, who refused to let her go back with Edna
2 CONT after Edna returned from Wisconsin.
2 CONT Bert did not like farming and moved into Danby with Edna and
2 CONT Vivian.
2 CONT Jenny, Emma and hired hand Ben ran the farm.
2 CONT Bert did not pay the taxes on the farm and eventually lost
2 CONT it.
1 NOTE Jim Pederson of Eau Claire, Wisc, has Alexander Harvey's family
2 CONT bible, where it states that the marriage was performed at home.

3 CONT coast guard officer; b. New London, Conn., Oct. 15, 1925;

3 CONT Feb. 5, 1949; children: Thomas Trask IV; James R., Jennifer
3 CONT Wetmore Sellers, Daniel H., Judith J. Wetmore Logan.

3 CONT grades to rear adm., 1977; instr. profl. studies dept. C.G.

3 CONT communications br. 5th C.G. Dist., Portsmouth, Va.,

1 REFN empak

1 TYPE e-mail
1 AUTH Peter A Kincaid
2 EMAL kincaidp@nbnet.nb.ca
1 TEXT I am trying to track down a Richard/Ritchie Wetmore who was born in
2 CONT Sussex, NB on June 18, 1896; the son of Alfred Burpee Wetmore and
2 CONT Ida/Ada P. Perry.  His last known where abouts was in Cambridge,
2 CONT Mass.  He had brothers Weeden, Roy, Frank, Burpee, and Laurie and
2 CONT sisters Mrs. Alex Reid, Mrs. Percy Folkins, and Edna Wetmore.
2 CONT Someone has traced out most of the Wetmore families in New
2 CONT Brunswick (descendant charts are at the Provincial Archives) but
2 CONT they didn't have anything on Richard.

1 REFN hartford
1 TITL Hartford, Connecticut Land Records: 1639 - 1688 And Births,
2 CONT Marriages and Deaths: 1644 - 1730
1 EDTR Albert C. Bates
1 INFO Two volumes - a reproduction of proceedings of a Connecticut
2 CONT state society.
1 ENTR
2 PAGE 528
2 TEXT Land in Hartford on Conecticut belonging to Jonathan & Samuel
3 CONT Webster & their heires & afsignes foreuer.
3 CONT
3 CONT One parcell which they bought of Thomas Ranney & Thomas whetmore
3 CONT lying in the Sowth meadow containing by estimation fower acres &
3 CONT Twenty Six rods & abuts on mr Haines land west Enfign Standlys
3 CONT land Sowth Sam Hubards land east & the churches land North as
3 CONT appeares by his deed dated Auguft 10, 1687 they acknowledged
3 CONT before John Allyn Afisftand & recorded then.
1 ENTR
2 PAGE 529
2 TEXT Land in Hartford on connecticutt belonging to Thomas Ranny &
3 CONT Thomas Wetmore & their heirs & afsignes foreuer.
3 CONT
3 CONT One parcell lying in the Sowth meadow which they receiued of
3 CONT Samuel Steell & Samuel Hubard for a legacy due to them by
3 CONT Captain Tho: watts his laft will & Teftament containing foure
3 CONT acres & Twenty Six rod & abutts on mr Haines land weft & on
3 CONT enfign Standly land Sowth & Samll Hubards land Eaft & the
3 CONT Churches land North as appeares by his deed dated Auguft 9th
3 CONT 1687 then acknowledged before John Allyn Afsiftant & recorded
3 CONT the Same day.
1 ENTR
2 PAGE 577
2 TEXT John whittmore Sun of Thomas whitmore was Babtifed Septem the
3 CONT Sixth one thoufand forty & Six.
1 ENTR
2 PAGE 578
2 TEXT Sara Whitmore Daughter of John Whitmore was borne Defem the
3 CONT Sixtenth one Thoufaind Six hundreth fory & Seven.

2 PAGE 582

1 REFN bobwill
1 EVEN Email Received
2 DATE 20 August 1996
2 FROM Bob Will
2 ADDR MVBob@aol.com
2 TO Thomas T. Wetmore IV (ttw@shore.net)
2 SUBJ Wetmore
2 TEXT Tom-
3 CONT
3 CONT I got your address from Marcia McDermott via the internet.
3 CONT She says you have quite a database on the Wetmores.
3 CONT Is that true?
3 CONT I'm looking for information on my grandfather, Orin DeLos Wetmore:
3 CONT
3 CONT Born: 1848 in Oswego, NY.
3 CONT Died: 1927 in San Diego, CA.
3 CONT A family legend (possibly true) has it that he was related to
3 CONT Joseph Brant, the famous Mohawk Indian chief in Ontario, Canada,
3 CONT and upper state New York.
3 CONT He was an inventor as well.
3 CONT Father's name: William DeLos Wetmore, of New York. Born 1818.
3 CONT Mother's name: Diana Irons, of New York, born 1818.
3 CONT Grandfather: Orin Miles Wetmore, born 1795
3 CONT Grandmother: Betsy Page, born 1796
3 CONT
3 CONT Please let me know if you have any connection with my relatives.
3 CONT Thanks, Tom.
3 CONT Best regards-
1 EVEN Email Received
2 DATE 23 August 1996
2 FROM Bob Will
2 TO Thomas T. Wetmore IV (ttw@mvjok.mv.lucent.com)
2 ADDR MVBob@aol.com
2 SUBJ Wetmore Ancestry
2 TEXT Tom,
3 CONT
3 CONT My full name is Robert Glenn Will.
3 CONT My father's name is Robert Ross Will.
3 CONT My mother's name is Marie Louise Wetmore.
3 CONT My grandmother's (mother's mother's) name is Marie Louise
3 CONT DuCharme Wetmore.
3 CONT
3 CONT I hope you can locate them.
3 CONT Let me know what you come up with.
3 CONT Thanks Tom.
3 CONT
3 CONT -Bob

0 @F15@ FAM
1 HUSB @I25@
1 WIFE @I75@
1 MARR
2 DATE 10 March 1914
2 PLAC New London, New London County, Connecticut
2 SOUR New London vital records
1 NOTE Wetmore-Carruthers Wedding This Morning
2 CONT Ceremony Was Performed at 10 o'Clock at Home of Bride.
2 CONT
2 CONT Mrs. Arline Louisa Carruthers, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. W. B. Keeney,
2 CONT of Hempstead street, who has been a trained nurse in New York for some time,
2 CONT was married to Thomas T. Wetmore at 10 o'clock this morning at the the
2 CONT home of the bride.
2 CONT The wedding was a very quiet affair.
2 CONT The ceremony was performed by Rev. Charles R. McNally.
2 CONT
2 CONT The couple were attended by Miss Portia and Trask Wetmore.
2 CONT The bride wore a handsome gown of blue with hat to match.
2 CONT The couple left on the 11.15 trail for Boston for a brief wedding trip.
2 CONT On their return they will reside at Ocean beach, where Mr. Wetmore has
2 CONT recently erected a new cottage.
2 SOUR New London Day, March 10, 1914.

4 OCCU Labourer
2 WITN
3 NAME John Slater
3 NAME Ellen Kaneen
2 REGR G. L. Ireland, Curate
2 NOTE There are two versions of this record, one obtained from the
3 CONT General Register Office of England, and one from the parish
3 CONT register of Liverpool, held in the Liverpool Libraries.
3 CONT They are both in the same hand.
2 NOTE The register office version incorrectly gives Margaret's
3 CONT name as Margaret Edwards, even though her father is given as
3 CONT William Edmonds.
2 NOTE The parish version gives her name as Margaret Edmonds,
3 CONT although she signs her name on that record as Margaret Edmunds.
2 NOTE Only the parish version has the actual signatures; the
3 CONT register office version has transcriptions.
2 NOTE Both records show her father as William Edmonds, although
3 CONT other evidence indicates that her father's name was John.
2 SOUR Marriage record, General Register Office, England,
3 CONT and the Liverpool parish register, Saint John's Church, archived
3 CONT at Liverpool Libraries.
1 MARR
2 DATE October to December 1858
2 PLAC Liverpool, England
2 SOUR vol 8b, pg 223, civil marriage registration index
1 NOTE The order and number of children in this family are not fully
2 CONT knwon.

1 TEXT Marriage Notice from a newspaper found in a scrap book online.
2 CONT Miss Portia Louise Wetmore, daughter of Thomas T. Wetmore of Ocean Beach,
2 CONT New London, and Lieutenant Wales Benham of the United States Coast Guard,
2 CONT son of Mrs. A. W. Benham were married Monday in St. James's Episcopal
2 CONT Church by Rev. Philip Markham Kenridge.
2 CONT T. Trask Wetmore, U.S.C.G., brother of the bride, was best man.
2 CONT Following the ceremony, a reception was held at the home of the bride's
2 CONT father, after which Lieutenant Benham and Mrs. Benham left for a
2 CONT wedding trip to Boston. After their return, they will live at Glenwood
2 CONT Park, New London. The bride is a graduate of Williams Memorial Institute
2 CONT Lieutenant Behnam is statioined in Groton.

1 RESI
2 PLAC New London, New London, Connecticut, United States
2 ADDR 73 Lower Boulevard
2 PHON 203-443-5427
1 DEAT
2 DATE 8 November 1970
2 PLAC New London, New London County, Connecticut, United States
1 BURI
2 PLAC Danby, Vermont, United States
2 CEME Scottsville Cemetery
2 SOUR direct knowledge
1 INFO
2 TEXT Thomas Trask Wetmore, Jr., was born in New London, Connecticut, May 5, 1896,
3 CONT and there was educated in the public schools, leaving Bulkeley High School
3 CONT in his junior year.
3 CONT He was in the employ of the Ship and Engine Company until October 30, 1917,
3 CONT when he enlisted in the United States navy for the period of the war between
3 CONT the United States and Germany.
3 CONT He served until honorably discharged, then returned to New London, were he was
3 CONT engaged with the local telephone compnay until October 1, 1919, when, under the
3 CONT name Wetmore & Beran, he established a real estate and insurance business,
3 CONT now the most important of its kind in the city.
3 CONT The partnership was dissolved in February, 1921, and Mr. Wetmore continues the
3 CONT business alone.
3 CONT Mr. Wetmore is a young man of energy and ability and is succeeding in his business.
2 TEXT Mr. Wetmore is a son of Thomas Trask Wetmore, Sr., born in New London county,
3 CONT now a retire business man, but deeply interested in the subject of antique furniture.
3 CONT His wife, Margaret Ellen (Kaneen) Wetmore, born in New London, died May 10, 1900,
3 CONT leaving a son, Thomas Trask, Jr., of previous mention, and a daughter,
3 CONT Portia Louise, who married Captain Wales A Benham.
2 SOUR "A Modern History of New London County," Volume 2, edited by
3 CONT Benjamin Tinkham Marshall. 1922.
1 OCCU real estate and insurance broker
1 TODO Get his listings from the post-1930 New London city directories
1 TODO Include his W W I miliary record.
1 OBIT
2 DATE 9 November 1970
2 NEWS The New London Day
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Thomas Wetmore
2 TEXT New London -- Thomas Trask Wetmore Jr., 74, of 73 Lower Boulevard,
2 TEXT died unexpectedly Sunday at Lawrence Memorial Hospital, where he had
2 TEXT been admitted earlier in the day.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Born May 5, 1896, in New London, he was the son of Thomas J. [sic] and
2 TEXT Margaret Kaneen Wetmore.
2 TEXT He was a real estat [sic] and insurance broker in New London for many years.
2 TEXT Mr. Wetmore was a Coast Guard veteran of World War I and was an avid fisherman
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Surviving are his widow, the former Vivian Brown; two sons, Thomas T. Wetmore 3rd
2 TEXT of Governors Island, N.Y., and James H. Wetmore of Groton, and nine grandchildren.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Funeral services will be conducted at 11 a.m. Wednesday at the Byles Memorial
2 TEXT Funeral Home.
2 TEXT Burial will be Thursday in Danby, Vt.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT There are no calling hours.

1 OCCU Hospital Administrator
1 DEAT
2 DATE 24 December 1976
2 PLAC Waterford, New London County, Connecticut
2 ADDR 17 Magonk Point Road
1 OBIT
2 DATE 27 December 1976
2 PLAC New London, Connecticut
2 SOUR The New London "Day"
2 HEAD Richard Hancock, 72, dies; hospital head for 34 years
2 TEXT Waterford - Richard James Hancock, 72, of 17 Magonk Point Road, a
3 CONT longtime chief administrator at Lawrence Memorial Hospital, was
3 CONT dead on arrival at the hospital Friday night after being
3 CONT stricken at home.
3 CONT
3 CONT Born in New London Aug. 18, 1904, the son of Charles and Marie
3 CONT Escott Hancock, he was married to Muriel Smith in New London
3 CONT Sept. 24, 1927.
3 CONT
3 CONT Mr. Hancock was appointed chief administrator at the hospital in
3 CONT March 1937 and remained at that post until he retired Dec. 31,
3 CONT 1970.
3 CONT
3 CONT During his long tenure as chief executive oficer of the
3 CONT hospital, Mr. Hancock superised most of its major expansion
3 CONT programs, including construction of the maternity wing, the
3 CONT administrative and operating wing, the Palmer wing and the north
3 CONT wing.
3 CONT
3 CONT He was a corporator, honorary corporator and trustee of the
3 CONT hospital.  He was also a Fellow in the American College of
3 CONT Hospital Administrators, a member and past president of the
3 CONT Connecticut Hospital Association, past president of the New
3 CONT England Hospital Assembly and a former trustee of the American
3 CONT Hospital Association.
3 CONT
3 CONT Mr. Hancock was graduated from the former Bulkeley School in the
3 CONT class of 1921.  He was employed at the former Mariners Savings
3 CONT Bank in New London until 1928 when he began working at the
3 CONT hospital.
3 CONT
3 CONT He was a member of the Brainard Lodge of Masons, Connecticut
3 CONT Consistory, Valley of Norwich, 32nd Degree, a member of the New
3 CONT London Rotary Club and treasurer of the Waterford Historical
3 CONT Society.
3 CONT
3 CONT He was also a volunteer with the American Cancer Society and on
3 CONT June 26, 1974, he was made an honorary life member of the
3 CONT society.  He was also a member of the board of the
3 CONT Bacon-Hinckley Home of New London.
3 CONT
3 CONT Besides his wife Muriel, of Waterford, he leaves one son,
3 CONT Commander Richard J. Hancock Jr., U.S. Navy, of Virginia Beach,
3 CONT Va.; three daughters, Mrs. Joan Wetmore of New London, Mrs.
3 CONT Nancy Carr of Waterford, and Mrs. Pamela Knapp of Rockville,
3 CONT Md.; and 18 grandchildren and two great-grand-children.
3 CONT
3 CONT Funeral services will be at the Waterford Presbyterian Church,
3 CONT Great Neck Road, at 1 p.m. Tuesday.  Internment will be in
3 CONT Jordan Cemetery, Waterford.  Visiting hours are 7 to 9 p.m.
3 CONT today at the Byles Memorial Home, 99 Huntington St., New
3 CONT London.  Contributions may be made to the Lawrence Memorial
3 CONT Hospital's Development Fund.
1 NEWS
2 DATE 28 December 1976
2 PLAC New London, Connecticut
2 SOUR The New London "Day," 28 December 1976, page 10
2 HEAD Opinion of The Day \ Richard Hancock
2 TEXT To many people in Eastern Connecticut, the name of Richard J.
3 CONT Hancock is synonymous with Lawrence Memorial Hospital.  There is
3 CONT good reason for that impression.  Dick Hancock had devoted the
3 CONT greater part of his life, some 42 years, to achieve the smooth
3 CONT functioning service qualities of the hospital.  It is today a
3 CONT regional institution, widely respected throughout the Northeast,
3 CONT largely because Mr. Hancock gave so much of himself to insure
3 CONT its success.
3 CONT
3 CONT Lawrence Memorial was a smalltown community hospital when he
3 CONT went to work there in the bookkeeping department in 1927.  But
3 CONT his interests were not confined to the ledgers.  His overriding,
3 CONT but never effusive, concern was for the people who were patients
3 CONT and for their relatives, for the doctors, nurses and support
3 CONT staff and for the environment in which all came together there
3 CONT in the cause of humanity.
3 CONT
3 CONT Mr. Hancock's dedication did not escape the perceptive eye of
3 CONT Katherine Prindiville, the then superintendent.  Miss
3 CONT Prindiville gave him the opportunity to act as understudy, and
3 CONT assignment he accepted with untiring zeal.  It was only natural
3 CONT that when she retired in March, 1937, he was named her
3 CONT successor.
3 CONT
3 CONT No better choice could have been made.
3 CONT
3 CONT The great advances in medicine were changing all hospitals for
3 CONT the better, making them of greater service to many more people.
3 CONT It is to Mr. Hancock's credit and the community's advantage that
3 CONT he understood the needs and was able to become a leader in
3 CONT seeing that needs were met.  Four major wings were added during
3 CONT his tenure.  Despite the difficulties such construction entail
3 CONT for a fully operational hospital, it was a remarkably smooth
3 CONT transition from small community hospital to a 324-bed regional
3 CONT general institution.
3 CONT
3 CONT Essentially, Richard J. Hancock was a conservative person.  It
3 CONT was among other qualities that enabled him to succeed in casting
3 CONT into permanent mold the dreams and aspirations of the many who
3 CONT rallied to the call for an improved hospital.
3 CONT
3 CONT Something at Lawrence Memorial should bear his name in
3 CONT perpetuity.  We can think of no more fitting tribute than to
3 CONT name the new North Wing for him.
3 CONT
3 CONT For this was a man who deserves to be remembered, to be emulated
3 CONT by all in daily living.  Humane, yet tough-minded.  An honest,
3 CONT hard-working, keen-minded professional who achieved much which
3 CONT will benefit humankind in these parts for many years to come.
3 CONT Richard J. Hancock sought no personal honors during a lifetime
3 CONT of work in behalf of this community.;  But now it is right that
3 CONT we express ourselves in meaningful terms.  Richard J. Hancock
3 CONT achieved a lot that was good for this city and for its environs.
1 BURI
2 DATE 28 December 1976
2 PLAC Waterford, New London, Connecticut

1 BURI
2 NAME Thomas Trask Wetmore
2 DATE 19 February 1947
2 PLAC Waterford, New London County, Connecticut
2 CEME Jordan cemetery
2 PLOT 387
2 SOUR Jordan cemetery records
1 OBIT
2 SOUR newspaper clipping from Mrs. Brenda Benham, probably from
3 CONT the New London "Day."
2 TEXT
3 CONT T T Wetmore,
3 CONT Antiques Dealer,
3 CONT Dies, Aged 80
3 CONT
3 CONT Thomas Trask Wetmore, 80, well known antiques dealer, died
3 CONT about 7 o'clock last night at the residence of his son, Thomas
3 CONT T Wetmore, Jr., of 73 Lower Boulevard, with whom he made his
3 CONT home.  He was stricken seriously ill last Thursday.
3 CONT
3 CONT A recognized authority on antiques, Mr. Wetmore had a shop in
3 CONT Truman street for a number of years and later was located in
3 CONT Bank street.
3 CONT
3 CONT He was born at Barton, Nova Scotia, March 13, 1866, the son of
3 CONT Daniel L. and Mary Ann Doty Wetmore.
3 CONT His family came to this country in 1869 and settled in Norwich,
3 CONT before moving to this city in 1872.
3 CONT
3 CONT Mr. Wetmore was educated in the local schools.
3 CONT He then entered the piano business with the D. S. March Co. and
3 CONT was with that concern for many years.
3 CONT Upon his retirement from that business 20 years ago, he entered
3 CONT the antiques and real estate fields.
3 CONT He owned considerable property in the Ocean Beach area and was
3 CONT identified with the development of that resort.
3 CONT
3 CONT Mr. Wetmore was twice married.
3 CONT His first wife was Margaret Ellen Kaneen and his second wife
3 CONT was Arleen Keeny Carruthers.
3 CONT The latter died May 24, 1929.
3 CONT
3 CONT Mr. Wetmore was prominent in Masonic circles, being a member of
3 CONT Brainard lodge of Masons, Union chapter, Royal Arch Masons;
3 CONT Cushing council, Royal and Select Masters; Palestine
3 CONT commandery, Knights Templar, and Pyramid temple, Mystic Shrine,
3 CONT of Bridgeport.
3 CONT
3 CONT He is survived by his son, Thomas T Wetmore, Jr.; a stepson,
3 CONT William Carruthers of East Haddam; a stepdaughter, Mrs. Charles
3 CONT Watrous of Poquonoc Bridge; and three grandsons, Thomas W.
3 CONT Benham of Burbank, Calif., Thomas T Wetmore, 3rd, a cadet at
3 CONT the Coast Guard academy, and James H. Wetmore, a student at the
3 CONT University of Connecticut, Storrs.
3 CONT
3 CONT Funeral services will be held at 2:30 o'clock tomorrow
3 CONT afternoon at Byles Memorial home.
3 CONT Burial will be in Jordan cemetery.
1 NOTE He came to Connecticut with his parents as an infant in 1868,
2 CONT making him about; he attended New London schools, and worked in
2 CONT the real estate and antiques businesses.
1 NOTE He died of heart failure, at home, 73 Lower Blvd, New London.
1 TODO Get his listings from the post-1930 New London city
2 CONT directories.

1 DEAT
2 NEWS New London Woman Commits Suicide.
3 CONT New London, May 11. -- Mrs. T. Wetmore, aged 35 years, whose home was on Montauk avenue, committed
3 CONT suicide yesterday afternnon by jumping off Alewife Cove bridge.
3 CONT Her body was recovered.
3 CONT Ill-health was the cause apparently as she had been under a physician's care for some time.
3 CONT Mr. Wetmore is employed in a local music store and when he left his home after dinner his wife
3 CONT was in the best of spirits.
3 CONT When he returned to supper he found a note from his wife announcing that she intended to drown
3 CONT herself and where the body could be found.
3 CONT She leaves, besides her husband, two children.
2 SOUR Naugatukc Daily "News", Naugatuck, Connecticut, 11 May 1900, page 2.

1 LAND Grant to John Wetmore
2 NAME John Wetmore
2 PLAC Carleton, New Brunswick, Canada
2 DATE 20 May 1785
2 DESC Volume A, page 5
2 SIZE 1.19 acres
2 SOUR New Brunswick Public Archives online index to land grants.
1 TEXT John Wetmore, Civil Engineer, a native of the town of Rye, Weschester County in the
2 CONT Colony of New York, was commissioned Deputy King's Surveyor to survey out the lands
2 CONT on the south side of the lower Kennebecasis and along the Hammond River . . . here he
2 CONT surveyed out 38 lots of different acreage in a block extending from New Portage Cove
2 CONT (now Renforth) east to Forrester's Cove. In these 38 lots are embraced the new populous
2 CONT districts of Renforth, Riverside, Rothesay, Fairvale and Gondola Point.
2 SOUR Andrew S. Beyea, "French Village: the erstwhile Kanibechachiche on the Petit Nachouac
3 CONT of the early Acadian habitats: its history and romancy." New Brunswick Museum.
1 BCHL
2 DATE 10 September 1785

2 DATE 10 February 1787
2 PLAC New Brunswick, Canada
2 CHIL
3 NAME John Wetmore
2 SOUR JCW; see his record
1 LAND
2 DATE before 17 May 1788
2 PLAC Carleton, Saint John, New Brunswick, Canada
2 INFO John Wetmore is mentioned in a land petition brought by
3 CONT Thomas Hanford and fifteen others.
2 TEXT To His Excellency Thomas Carleton, Esqr., Captain General and
3 CONT Governour Chief in and over His Majesty's Province of New
3 CONT Brunswick
3 CONT
3 CONT The memorial of the subscribed residents in Carleton humbly
3 CONT sheweth that at present they are liable to labour under a
3 CONT great inconvenience from a Lott being granted to Jn. Whetmore
3 CONT which has ever been considered as a possible landing at the
3 CONT creek upon the south side of Carleton.
3 CONT They beg leave to make your Excellency acquainted that some
3 CONT time in the winter of 1784 the father of the said Jn. Whetmore
3 CONT espoused a desire to keep school in the neighborhood which was
3 CONT readily agreed to and to assist him they put a small log hutt
3 CONT for this purpose upon one end of the Lott which was never
3 CONT finished, from which circumstances he considered the Lott as
3 CONT his own and sold it to that son who is now about building and
3 CONT improving the whole.
3 CONT Should he be suffered to do this the inconvenience that will
3 CONT attend the neighborhood by being deprived of any public landing
3 CONT urges them to explain their grievance to hope your Excellency a
3 CONT necessary inquiry to the same.
3 CONT
3 CONT [signed] Thomas Hanford and 15 others
2 INFO On the outside of the file are the following notes.
2 TEXT N.B. The within lot is No. 271, Bodney [Rodney?, Bodnig?] Street
2 TEXT 7th May 1788
2 TEXT The lot within mentioned No. 271 is to be reserved for public
3 CONT landings.

1 LAND Land petition of 1795-6
2 DATE 2 December 1795 (written) and 1 February 1796 (filed)
2 PLAC Kings County, New Brunswick, Canada
2 NOTE In 1795-6 John Wetmore petitioned for a tract of land in
3 CONT Kings County, New Brunswick.
3 CONT The petition is in the Public Archives of New Brunwick, and
3 CONT the transcription below was made from a microfilm of the
3 CONT file.
3 CONT The petition is identified as Kings County petition number 737.
2 INFO The outside of the file contains the following:
2 TEXT Petition of John Wetmore
3 CONT
3 CONT asks a tract of about 800 acres (for himself and ten children)
3 CONT near the tract formerly granted to Humphrey Butt and others on
3 CONT Hammond River.
3 CONT
3 CONT 1st Feby 1796
2 INFO Here is the transcription of the petition:
2 TEXT Petition of John Wetmore
3 CONT
3 CONT To his Excellency Thomas Carleton, Esq., Lieutenant
3 CONT Governor and Commander in Chief of the Province of New
3 CONT Brunswick, etc., etc., etc.
3 CONT
3 CONT The Petition of John Wetmore of Hampton in Kings County
3 CONT
3 CONT Humbly Sheweth
3 CONT
3 CONT That he has a wife and ten children viz: six sons and
3 CONT four daughters, seven of them natives of this Province for
3 CONT whose present support he feels himself bound to provide - after
3 CONT an appointment of several years he has found it impossible with
3 CONT diligence and the strictest economy on the lot originally drawn
3 CONT by Your Petitioner to furnish a competent present maintenance
3 CONT nor is the lot capable of being ever so divided as to make more
3 CONT settlements than one.
3 CONT Your Petitioner has therefore found it necessary to abandon his
3 CONT first purpose of performing the cultivation of that lot as a
3 CONT provision for his family and has reluctantly parted with it to
3 CONT another to the size of whose family it is better proportioned.
3 CONT Your Petitioner has explored the nonsettled lands several miles
3 CONT distant from any settlement and has found a tract consisting of
3 CONT hard wood and soft wood land and strips of intervale so
3 CONT situated as by taking in seven or eight hundred acres much of
3 CONT which is of little or no value a settlement may at some future
3 CONT time by hard labor be made for himself and some of his sons.
3 CONT He therefore begs Your Excellency will be pleased to grant him
3 CONT the tract of land last mentioned which is situated and
3 CONT described as follows viz: beginning at the south west corner
3 CONT of a tract of land petitioned for some time since by Isaiah
3 CONT Smith thence south partly on that tract and partly on
3 CONT nongranted land eighty chains thence south seventy west to the
3 CONT rear line of lands formerly granted to Humphrey Butt and
3 CONT others on Hammond River thence continuing westerly on said
3 CONT rear line to a station where a line north seventy east will
3 CONT meet the first mentioned boundary.
3 CONT Your Petitioner prays an Order of Survey whenever Your
3 CONT Excellency shall think proper to direct the same.
3 CONT
3 CONT And Your Petitioner as in duty bound will ever pray be
3 CONT
3 CONT [signed] Jn Wetmore
3 CONT
3 CONT Hampton
3 CONT
3 CONT Kings County
3 CONT
3 CONT December 2, 1795
2 INFO After John Wetmore's petition is the following statement:
2 TEXT I have seen the land petitioned for - the tract contains
3 CONT several strips of good land and a great deal of soft wood
3 CONT land of little value, but is capable of making a good
3 CONT settlement and will probably accommodate more than one of
3 CONT the family - Mr. Wetmore's ten children, if placed on
3 CONT inviting land, will doubtless become permanent settlers
3 CONT in the County, particularly as the father and his numerous
3 CONT relatives settled here, are strongly attached to the Province
3 CONT and the British Government.
3 CONT I therefore hope he will be accommodated with the land he
3 CONT asks for and he will immediately commence the settlement of
3 CONT it, in which he will be encouraged by the _____ _____
3 CONT [exertions?], already begun on the adjoining tract by Mr.
3 CONT Smith, an industrious man who also has a numerous family.
3 CONT
3 CONT [signed] Joshua Upham

2 DATE 9 April 1797

2 CHIL

2 SOUR see his record

1 EVEN wrote preamble of the Beaver River Temperance Society
2 DATE 28 April 1828
2 PLAC Beaver River, Nova Scotia, Canada
2 TEXT We the undersigned firmly believing and most assuredly
3 CONT gathering that the too great use of spirituous liquors is
3 CONT prejudicial to the body and souls of mankind in general
3 CONT both spiritual and temporal, to remedy this great and
3 CONT spreading evil, we therefore whose names are hereunto
3 CONT annexed do forever renounce the use of ardent or distilled
3 CONT spirituous liquors except what may be taken as medicine in
3 CONT case of sickness.
3 CONT And we pray Almighty God to establish our hearts and
3 CONT strengthen our hearts and strengthen our serious
3 CONT resolutions.
2 SOUR "History of Yarmouth"
1 RESI
2 DATE 1829
2 PLAC Beaver River, Nova Scotia, Canada
2 OCCU Schoolmaster
2 SOUR "History of Yarmouth"
1 EVEN rewrote preamble of Beaver River Temperance Society
2 NAME John Whetmore Senr
2 DATE 1830
2 PLAC Beaver River
2 TEXT The oldest document connected with this institution is now in
3 CONT the County Museum.
3 CONT The preamble and the first sixty-eight names are in the
3 CONT hand-writing of the late John Whitmore at that time a
3 CONT school master at Beaver River, then followed seventy-four
3 CONT original signatures.
3 CONT The value of the paper has been seriously impaired from the
3 CONT fact that the dates have been tampered with.
3 CONT But a careful comparison of all the facts show first that
3 CONT the institution was organized in 1828 and secondly that the
3 CONT document in question was copied in 1830 from the true
3 CONT original, which has very probably been long since lost.
2 SOUR notes from S. Ellis
1 EVEN became officer in Beaver River Temperance Society
2 NAME John Whetmore Senr
2 DATE 26 January 1831
2 PLAC Beaver River, Nova Scotia, Canada
2 INFO John Wetmore became the secretary of the Beaver River
3 CONT Temperance Society.
2 SOUR society transcripts, fide S. Ellis

2 SOUR Ancestry.com ship arrival records
1 DEAT
2 NAME John Wetmore
2 AGE 93 years
2 DATE 4 May 1848
2 PLAC Beaver River, Yarmouth County, Nova Scotia, Canada
2 TEXT d. Beaver River, Yarmouth, N.S., 4th inst., John WETMORE, age 93.
2 SOUR Daniel Johnson, New Brunswick Newspaper Vital Statistics Volume 12 Number 369
3 CONT 20 May 1848, New Brunswick Courier, Saint John.
1 DEAT
2 DATE 4 May 1848
2 PLAC Beaver River, Yarmouth or Digby County, Nova Scotia, Canada
2 SOUR newspaper clippings
1 DEAT
2 DATE 4 May 1848
2 TIME 3 p.m.
2 SOUR family group sheet of James Wetmore, John's father
1 TEXT
2 CONT He removed to New Brunswick in 1783, where he was government
2 CONT land surveyor till an advanced age prevented him from
2 CONT attending the duties pertaining to the office.
2 CONT He was a magistrate of Kings County, N.B., for some years,
2 CONT received during the Revolution a lieutenant's commission in
2 CONT the British army; was at the battle of White Plains, but was
2 CONT not engaged in the combat.
2 CONT On the King's troops removing to New Brunswick he was made a
2 CONT commandant of a company.
2 CONT Capt. Wetmore was a strong Royalist, as well as an ardent
2 CONT Churchman, as will be seen from the following entry on the
2 CONT fly leaf of his family Bible:
2 CONT John Wetmore, born at Rye, state of New York, July 7, 1755.
2 CONT Baptized by the Rev. James Wetmore, Rector of Rye church.
2 CONT Landed at Saint Johns, commanding a company of loyalists, with
2 CONT the rank of captain.
2 CONT Confirmed in Kingston Church by the Right Rev. Charles
2 CONT Inglish, D.D., Lord Bishop of Nova Scotia.
2 CONT Declaration.
2 CONT I, the above named John Wetmore, do hereby declare that I
2 CONT believe the United Church of England and Ireland, as by law
2 CONT established, to be a pure branch of Christ's Holy Catholic
2 CONT Church; that for nearly seventy years I have lived in her
2 CONT communion, that in it I hope to die.
2 CONT (signed) John Wetmore
2 CONT In the 89th year of age in the year of our Lord, 1844.
2 SOUR JCW
1 NOTE On a family group sheet on T. T. Wetmore Jr. letterhead, John is
2 CONT called the great grandfather to Mr. T. T. Wetmore.
1 TEXT John who moved with his father to New Brunswick, and who
2 CONT was a government land surveyor, and is said to surveyed the
2 CONT farms along the Hammond River, and was a magistrate in Kings
2 CONT County for many years.
2 CONT He was confirmed in Kingston church.
2 CONT Not known when he left French Village.
2 CONT Married Anne Van Cott of Lond [sic] Island in 1778.
2 CONT Died in Yarmouth, Nova Scotia, in 1848 aged ninety-two.
2 SOUR newspaper clipping
1 EVEN newspaper article
2 TEXT JOHN WETMORE, LOYALIST
3 CONT
3 CONT Capt. John Wetmore, of Rye, New York, came, with others of the
3 CONT Wetmore family, to New Brunswick, later removing to Yarmouth,
3 CONT where he was employed as a teacher.
3 CONT
3 CONT When he died, in May 1848, aged 93 years, he was survived by 18
3 CONT children, 130 grandchildren, 397 great-grandchildren, and five
3 CONT great-great-grandchildren - a total of 550 living descendents.
2 SOUR "Down Memory Lane" column, by Blauveldt, from a Yarmouth paper,
3 CONT no date
1 BURI
2 PLAC Beaver River, Nova Scotia, Canada
2 CEME Beaver River Burial Ground
2 SOUR Anne Marie Flewelling

1 BIRT

1 DEAT
2 DATE 7 April 1876
2 PLAC Carleton, New Brunswick, Canada
2 SOUR Anne Marie Flewelling
2 SOUR Edward A Wetmore Family Tree on Ancestry.com
2 SOUR Roots Web Wetmore Genealogy by Noreen Wetmore
1 OBIT Daily News, Provincial Archives of New Brunswick, Canada, Vol 39 No 2090 April 19, 1876.
2 TEXT In the usual place today is announced the death of James Wetmore, at age 94 years and 7 mos.
3 CONT Mr. W. was born at Rye, New York and came to this country with his parents in 1783.
3 CONT His father, John Wetmore, had served on the British side as Lt in the revolutionary war
3 CONT and was at the battle of White Plains. He was a government land surveyor of this Province
3 CONT and one of the first magistrates in Kings Co. His son, James, lived in New Brunswick until
3 CONT he was 17 years of age and then returned to New York. In 1816 he came back to N. B.;
3 CONT he lived for a time in Yarmouth, NS and then returned and for many years carried on a
3 CONT farming operation n Kings Co. For the last 21 years he has lived with his son,
3 CONT Stephen P. Wetmore, Esq in Carleton (Saint John). He was an exceedingly hardy and vigourous
3 CONT man until within a day or two of his death, was in full possession of all his faculties,
3 CONT able to walk his mile or more and able to read the newspaper without glasses.
3 CONT He leaves a widow who is in her 97th year, very large number of descendants and even
3 CONT to the fifth generation.
1 FAMC @F8@
1 FAMS @F35@
0 @I36@ INDI

1 NAME Daniel Van Cott /Wetmore/
1 NAME Daniel VanCott /Wetmore/

1 NAME Daniel Van Cox /Wetmore/
1 NAME Daniel /Wetmore/
1 NAME Daniel C /Wetmore/
1 REFN dvcw
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE 13 November 1791
2 PLAC poss Kingston, Kings County, New Brunswick, Canada
2 SOUR summary
1 NOTE
2 CONT Daniel Van Cott Wetmore was born 13 November 1791, in New
2 CONT Brunswick, probably in Kings County.
2 CONT I have not found an original record of his birth.
2 CONT His parents were John and Anna [Van Cott] Wetmore, Loyalists
2 CONT from Rye, Westchester County, New York, who removed to Kings
2 CONT County, New Brunswick, where Daniel was probably born.
2 CONT In 1802 Anna Wetmore died; between 1805 and 1807 John Wetmore
2 CONT removed to Yarmouth, Nova Scotia; Daniel probably went
2 CONT with him.
2 CONT In 1817 John was a school teacher in Yarmouth, and by the late
2 CONT 1820s he was the school master at Beaver River.
1 BIRT
2 DATE 13 November 1791
2 PLAC New Brunswick, Canada
2 SOUR JCW and computed from age at death

2 DATE 1818
2 PLAC prob Nova Scotia, Canada

1 RESI
2 DATE by 1862 to at least 1868
2 PLAC Norwich, New London County, Connecticut
2 SOUR v4
1 RESI
2 DATE poss by 1878 to 1881
2 PLAC Brooklyn, Kings County, New York
2 SOUR v5
1 NOTE Daniel Van Cott Wetmore married Hannah Trask in 1818 (from three
2 CONT sources, although none refer to an original record).
2 CONT Hannah may have been from Beaver River.
2 CONT Her father was Thomas Trask, possibly the Thomas Trask living
2 CONT in Beaver River in 1820 when a fire destroyed much property,
2 CONT including his grist mill.
2 CONT From the information available, I believe that Daniel
2 CONT and Hannah spent their first few years of marriage in Nova Scotia,
2 CONT but soon removed to New Brunswick.
2 CONT Daniel is not listed in the 1827 census of Nova Scotia, which
2 CONT includes both Yarmouth and Digby Counties.
1 NOTE Daniel and Hannah's first child may have been son Jesse Wetmore, likely
2 CONT born in 1819; he is said to have run away from home to Florida where
2 CONT he died of yellow fever; I have found no trace of him (my only
2 CONT information about Jesse and Charity [see below] come from brief
2 CONT notes quoting Thomas Trask Wetmore Sr, a grandson of Daniel Van Cott
2 CONT Wetmore).
2 CONT It is possible that the Joseph C. Wetmore, found on a few
2 CONT records in Norwich, Connecticut, may be this Jesse.
1 NOTE
2 CONT Daniel and Hannah's next child was Daniel Lorenzo Wetmore,
2 CONT born in April 1821, possibly in Yarmouth, although his exact birth
2 CONT place has not been found.
2 CONT Daniel Lorenzo Wetmore was named for Lorenzo Dow, an eccentric
2 CONT Methodist minister from Montville, Connecticut, whose wide ranging
2 CONT travels included the maritimes; Daniel Van Cott is said to
2 CONT have enjoyed reading Dow's sermons; Norwich, Connecticut, where
2 CONT Daniel Van Cott lived for many years, borders Montville.
1 NOTE
2 CONT Daniel Van Cott Wetmore and Hannah Trask had at least two daughters.
2 CONT One, Mary Ann Wetmore, married Edwin Penn Williams, of
2 CONT New Brunswick, where they lived until his death.
2 CONT They were married in 1840 in Trinity Church; on the marriage record
2 CONT Mary Ann is of Portsmouth, a neighborhood in St John; this indicates
2 CONT that Daniel Van Cott Wetmore may have been living with his family
2 CONT in St John at this time.
2 CONT A second daughter, Charity Wetmore, is said to have removed to
2 CONT Pennsylvania; I have found no trace of her.
1 NOTE
2 CONT Daniel and Hannah had at least one more son, Thomas Trask Wetmore,
2 CONT youngest of the three known sons; on his naturalization papers
2 CONT Thomas states he was born in Saint John, New Brunswick; various records
2 CONT place his birth between 1826 and 1829, with 1827 most likely.
1 NOTE
2 CONT Daniel Van Cott Wetmore married his second wife, Cynthia
2 CONT Perkins, in 1829; at that time they may have both been
2 CONT residing in Norton, Kings County, New Brunswick.
2 SENT Daniel and Cynthia had a number of children.
2 SENT Some of them were probably born at North Range, Digby County,
2 CONT where, according to land records, Daniel was a carpenter from at
2 CONT least 1848 until 1852, possibly until 1862, when he appears in
2 CONT Norwich, Connecticut, records.
1 NOTE
2 CONT Daniel lived in Norwich, Connecticut, from at least 1862 until
2 CONT the late 1870s.
2 CONT During this period Daniel and a number of his sons were
2 CONT involved in the shipbuilding trade in Norwich.
1 NOTE Daniel Van Cott Wetmore died on 13 September 1881, in Brooklyn, Kings
2 CONT County, New York, of cancer, and he was buried in Norwich,
2 CONT Connecticut, on 15 September 1881.
2 CONT His death is recorded in both the Brooklyn and Norwich vital records;
2 CONT he outlived both his wives.
2 CONT The Brooklyn death certificate states he was living in Brooklyn for
2 CONT four years before his death.
1 NOTE This is from a hand written note made by Lucille Borges Kimble when interviewing
2 CONT Thomas Trask Wetmore Sr.
2 CONT Daniel Lorenzo W. (Frank B.'s grandfather) was born 1821 - named after Lorenzo Dow
2 CONT of Oxoboxo. (Daniel's father used to read Dow's sermons).
2 CONT Daniel L. W. lived to be 83. He had an older brother Jesse, who ran away from home
2 CONT to Florida & died there, young, of yellow fever.
2 CONT Daniel had sisters - one Mary Ann Williams, whose husband was related to William Penn.
2 CONT Charity, another sister, lived in Pennsylvania.
2 CONT Daniel's wife's maiden name - Doty - her mother's, Savory.
2 CONT Daniel's dau. Emmeline Terentia (mother of Frank B.) was married in Boston
2 CONT to Michel Borges of the Azores, whose father had a large distillery in Azores -
2 CONT (by which he made the money to send Michel to Oxford to college).
2 CONT Michel was consul to Boston - also had an import business - citrus fruits from
2 CONT Azores. He killed himself when a large cargo was lot at sea - ruining his own and
2 CONT friends' investment - his son Frank a babe was brought up by Wetmore
2 CONT grandparents (Daniel, above) - and his mother remarried - a Barnes, and had
2 CONT a large family subsequently.
2 SOUR Hand written note by Lucille Borges Kimble interviewing Thomas Trask Wetmore Sr.
1 FAMC @F8@
1 FAMS @F9@
1 FAMS @F13@
0 @I42@ INDI

2 NAME David Wetmore
2 SEX M

1 FAMC @F9@
0 @I48@ INDI
1 NAME Daniel Lorenzo/Wetmore/
1 REFN dlw
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE 5 April 1821
2 PLAC prob Yarmouth, Yarmouth, Nova Scotia, Canada
2 PLAC poss Saint John, New Brunswick, Canada
2 PLAC poss Beaver River, Yarmouth or Digby, Nova Scotia, Canada
2 SOUR summary
1 NOTE Daniel Lorenzo Wetmore was born on 5 April 1821, probably in
2 CONT Yarmouth, Nova Scotia; I have not found an original record
2 CONT of his birth.
2 CONT I believe that Daniel's parents removed to New Brunswick soon
2 CONT after Daniel was born; the meager evidence suggests that Daniel
2 CONT may have grown up in a number of locations, including Kings
2 CONT County and Saint John, New Brunswick.
1 BIRT
2 DATE 5 April 1821
2 SOUR Family information sheet on T. T. Wetmore Jr. letterhead.
1 NOTE Daniel Lorenzo Wetmore married Mary Ann Doty, of Digby County,
2 CONT Nova Scotia, probably soon before 1848, the year their first
2 CONT child was born.
2 CONT By 1855, and possibly from the date of their marriage, Daniel and
2 CONT Mary Ann were living on the shore of Saint Mary's Bay, Digby
2 CONT Digby County, Nova Scotia, where Daniel was a ship carpenter.
1 NOTE Around 1870 Daniel removed to Norwich, Connecticut, where his
2 CONT father, brother Thomas Trask Wetmore, and a number of his half
2 CONT brothers were involved in the shipbuilding trade.
2 CONT Daniel removed with his family to New London, Connecticut,
2 CONT around 1873, where he was also a shipbuilder.
2 CONT On 28 June 1887 Daniel and Mary Ann Wetmore purchased
2 CONT their home at 24 Woodbridge Street, in New London, from William O.
2 CONT and Catherine Mahoney of Hoboken, New Jersey; the price
2 CONT of the property was $600.
1 LAND
2 DATE 19 January 1855
2 PLAC Saint Mary's Bay, Digby County, Nova Scotia, Canada
2 INFO to grantee Daniel Witmore from grantor Louis White and
3 CONT wife Elizabeth
2 INFO Deed of land in Saint Mary's Bay purchased for 20 pounds.
2 NOTE This land record possibly refers to Daniel Van Cott Wetmore.
2 SOUR Digby County land records, book 24 page 62
1 LAND
2 NAME Daniel L. Wetmore
2 DATE 28 January 1860
2 PLAC Saint Mary's Bay, Digby County, Nova Scotia, Canada
2 INFO registered on 21 February 1860
2 INFO grantor Daniel L. Wetmore et ux, of Weymouth, shipwright
2 INFO grantee John Clements, of Weymouth, yeoman
2 INFO book 29 page 168
2 INFO mortgage
2 INFO Daniel mortgaged his home to John Clement for three years for
3 CONT the sum of 25 pounds 9 shillings 6 pence.
3 CONT The record is signed by Daniel, Mary Ann (mark) and Emeline
3 CONT T. (mark) Wetmore.
2 INFO Description of land: south side of Saint Mary's Bay and on the
3 CONT north side of the main post road heading from Digby to
3 CONT Weymouth, where Daniel Wetmore now occupies and resides and
3 CONT contains about four acres plus or minus.
2 SOUR Digby County land records, book 29 page 168
1 CENS
2 DATE 1861
2 PLAC Digby County, Nova Scotia, Canada
2 HEAD
3 NAME Danial Wetmore
2 TOTL 2 male, 3 female, 5 total
2 MALE 1 single, 5-10 years, can't read or write
2 FMLE 2 single, 10-15 years
2 MALE 1 married, 30-40 years
2 FMLE 1 married, 30-40 years
2 SOUR 1861 Census of Nova Scotia, District 7 (on Saint Mary's Bay),
3 CONT abstract 4, number 39

3 CONT Louis White.

3 CONT property for a term of six years with a yearly rent of 5
3 CONT pounds.
3 CONT In an addition dated 25 April 1863 it is stated that Daniel
3 CONT may put up a fence.

1 PARA
2 SENT Mary Ann [Doty] Wetmore died in New London, on 7 April 1897.
2 SENT Daniel sold his New London home in 1899 and removed to
3 CONT Waterford, Connecticut.
2 SENT Daniel Lorenzo Wetmore died in Waterford, on 27 April 1903.
2 SENT He and his wife are both buried in Jordan Cemetery, Waterford,
3 CONT Connecticut.
1 DEAT
2 NAME Daniel L. Wetmore
2 DATE 27 April 1903
2 PLAC Waterford, New London County, Connecticut
2 AGE 82 years, 22 days
2 BIRT
3 PLAC Yarmouth, New Brunswick, Canada
2 RESI Waterford
2 CAUS Brights disease
2 OCCU Ship Carpenter
2 FATH
3 NAME Daniel
2 MOTH
3 NAME Hannah
2 RECR A W Nelson
2 INFO widower
2 SOUR Waterford death records
1 BURI
2 PLAC Waterford, New London County, Connecticut
2 CEME Jordan Cemetery
1 OBIT
2 TEXT DANIEL L. WETMORE
3 CONT
3 CONT LONG TIME RESIDENT AND HONORED CITIZEN DEAD.
3 CONT
3 CONT Daniel L. Wetmore, for many years a resident of this city, died
3 CONT today at the advanced age of 82 years at the residence of his
3 CONT niece, Mrs. C. C. Crocker, on the continuation of Bank street
3 CONT in Waterford.
3 CONT Mr. Wetmore was a native of Nova Scotia, but he spent a large
3 CONT part of his life in the state.
3 CONT Before coming to New London he resided in Norwich.
3 CONT
3 CONT He was a ship carpenter by trade and understood the business
3 CONT thoroughly.
3 CONT Years ago he was employed at Brainerd's shipyard, in East New
3 CONT London at the site of the Lenox Oil Co.'s plant.
3 CONT Mr. Wetmore was an honest, industrious and sober citzen.
3 CONT His reputation among his fellow men was untarnished and he was
3 CONT highly esteemed by all who knew him.
3 CONT During the past few years he has retired from active endeavor
3 CONT on account of old age.
3 CONT
3 CONT Mr. Wetmore leaves two sons, Daniel C. and Thomas T. Wetmore of
3 CONT this city and two daughters, Mrs. Charles Barnes of this city
3 CONT and Mrs. Cullen of Boston.
3 CONT The funeral will be held at 2.30 Wednesday afternoon from the
3 CONT residence of Mrs. C. C. Crocker.
2 SOUR New London "Day," 27 April 1903
1 RESI
2 DATE by 1848 to at least 1866
2 PLAC Saint Mary's Bay (Plympton and/or Barton), Digby County, Nova Scotia, Canada
1 RESI
2 DATE by 1862 to at least 1872
2 PLAC Norwich, New London County, New London
1 RESI
2 DATE 1874 to 1901
2 PLAC New London, New London County, New London
1 RESI
2 DATE 1902 to 1903
2 PLAC Waterford, New London County, New London
1 NOTE This is from a hand written note made by Lucille Borges Kimble when interviewing
2 CONT Thomas Trask Wetmore Sr.
2 CONT Daniel Lorenzo W. (Frank B.'s grandfather) was born 1821 - named after Lorenzo Dow
2 CONT of Oxoboxo. (Daniel's father used to read Dow's sermons).
2 CONT Daniel L. W. lived to be 83. He had an older brother Jesse, who ran away from home
2 CONT to Florida & died there, young, of yellow fever.
2 CONT Daniel had sisters - one Mary Ann Williams, whose husband was related to William Penn.
2 CONT Charity, another sister, lived in Pennsylvania.
2 CONT Daniel's wife's maiden name - Doty - her mother's, Savory.
2 CONT Daniel's dau. Emmeline Terentia (mother of Frank B.) was married in Boston
2 CONT to Michel Borges of the Azores, whose father had a large distillery in Azores -
2 CONT (by which he made the money to send Michel to Oxford to college).
2 CONT Michel was consul to Boston - also had an import business - citrus fruits from
2 CONT Azores. He killed himself when a large cargo was lost at sea - ruining his own and
2 CONT friends' investment - his son Frank a babe was brought up by Wetmore
2 CONT grandparents (Daniel, above) - and his mother remarried - a Barnes, and had
2 CONT a large family subsequently.
2 SOUR Hand written note by Lucille Borges Kimble interviewing Thomas Trask Wetmore Sr.
1 BURI
2 PLAC Beaver River, Yarmouth, Nova Scotia, Canada
2 CEME Founders Cemetery
2 NOTE There is a gravestone with JW carved in it that is assumed to mark John Wetmore's grave.

1 RESI
2 NAME T. T. Wetmore
2 DATE March 1894
2 PLAC Titusville, Florida, United States
2 SOUR Article in Norwich Bulletin in March 1896
2 TEXT SHIPBUILDING ON THE THAMES
3 CONT Mr. T. T. Wetmore Writes Entertainingly of Shipbuilding Between 1855 and 1866.
3 CONT
3 CONT I saw in the BULLETIN of March 5, writes T. T. Wetmore from Titusville, Florida,
3 CONT a history of shipbuilding in Norwich from away back in the "ye olden times." As I had
3 CONT something to do in that line in Norwich from 1855 to 1866, I think I can give you a
3 CONT little more definite account of the vessels built in that time than anyone else.
3 CONT
3 CONT I went to Norwich on January 1, 1855, and took the job to plank and ceil the schooner
3 CONT Col. Lester of about 250 tons, built for J. M. Huntington & Co. and Col. Lester of
3 CONT Preston, by Harrison P. Lamphier. She was launched from a yard just below the old railroad
3 CONT bridge over the Shetucket, on July 4, 1855. That winter Mr. Lamphier contracted with
3 CONT J. M. Huntington & Co. to build the barge Thames, which I build under sub contract, and
3 CONT launched her June 12, the same year. She was 140 tons. As Lamphier had this yard leased,
3 CONT and there being no other available place, I started a new yard near the Norwich and
3 CONT Worcester railroad station, just where the iron bridge abutment is now, and build the
3 CONT schooner Sally Gay, 200 tons, and launched her April 7, 1856. Then I build the schooner
3 CONT I. K. Marvel of 200 tons, which was launched November 11, 1856. These were all for J. M.
3 CONT Huntington & Co.
3 CONT
3 CONT The I. K. Marvel, commanded by Capt. Eldridge of Cape Cod, was the pioneer schooner to
3 CONT open the West India trade which in later years grew to such large proportions.
3 CONT
3 CONT In the summer of 1860 the afore-named firm built a new shipyard at Thamesville by filling
3 CONT from the high bank where Shipping street now is, the pond of water inside the railroad
3 CONT track and the flats outside the track to the bulkhead near the channel, where we put in a
3 CONT marine railway, and I commenced to build the propeller Norwich, which was intended for
3 CONT a passenger and freight boat to run from Ponce to Saint John on the Isle of Porto Rico.
3 CONT She was of 432 tons burthen and about the size of the gunboats which were ordered by
3 CONT congress and the breaking out of the war. Samuel Rook[?], naval constructor, heard of this
3 CONT boat, and when she was well along in construction, bought her for one of the sixteen
3 CONT gunboats ordered by the government. She was coppered, gun deck put it, with magazine, and
3 CONT equipped all ready for her guns and delivered in New York to the government Sept. 28, 1861.
3 CONT
3 CONT I then build the propeller Trade Wind, of the same size, and launched her April 5, 1862.
3 CONT This boat followed Admiral Farragut into New Orleans. The captain bought a cargo of sugar
3 CONT and she paid for herself the first voyage she made.
3 CONT
3 CONT The owners, J. M. Huntington & Co., presented every man who worked on her with a 25-pound
3 CONT box of sugar; myself with a barrel of 228 pounds; E. Proctor 100 pounds; S. N. Gladwin,
3 CONT foreman joiner, 100 pounds. As only three and a half pounds of suger could then be bought
3 CONT for $1, the gift was appreciated pretty highly.
3 CONT
3 CONT The third vessel built was the propeller Prometheus, 650 tons, launched in 1863; fourth,
3 CONT propeller Perrit, 713 tons, launched in fall of 1863; fifth, the propeller Whirlwind,
3 CONT 430 tons, launched early in 1864; sixth, propeller Uncas, 325 tons, built in 1864;
3 CONT seventh, propeller Chace, 515 tons, launched in 1865; eighth, propeller Hunter, built in
3 CONT 1865, 515 tons; ninth, propeller Utility, 650 tons, launched 1866.
3 CONT
3 CONT These were all double decked vessels but the Uncas which was a single deck vessel.
3 CONT As there could be no yellow pine got from the south in those days on account of the war,
3 CONT we had to depend on our own country for all the timber, plank, etc., and the towns of
3 CONT Montville, Bozrah, Preston, Scotland and Lebanon were well scoured for timber. Many an
3 CONT old farmer who got big prices for timber had occasion to bless the name of J. M.
3 CONT Huntington & Co.
3 CONT
3 CONT Mr. E. Proctor was not foreman of the yard, but was the boss machinist and built the
3 CONT engines for all the boats but the Norwich, which were built by the late Eliot Barber.
3 CONT The boilers were built by William Troland.
3 CONT
3 CONT Titusville, Fla., March 9, 1894.

1 DEAT
2 DATE 16 November 1907
3 SOUR Connecticut Deaths and Burials, 1772-1934 on Family Search
2 PLAC Florida, United States
3 SOUR Card file from Norwich "Bulletin" indicating article 19 November 1907
1 EVEN Letter to the Editor
2 DATE unknown
2 TEXT VAN COTT MILLIONS
3 CONT Eastern Connectiuct Heirs May Rightfully Claim Them.
3 CONT Thomas T. Wetmore writes from Titusville, Fla., as follows:
3 CONT "I notice in your issue of 3rd inst., that in speaking of the Van Cott estate
3 CONT you speak of D. L. Wetmore of New London, who is my eldest brother,
3 CONT as one of the heirs; that his great grandfather, John Wetmore, married
3 CONT Anna Van Cott, etc.
3 CONT John Wetmore was our grandfather, and Anna Van Cott our grandmother.
3 CONT Our father was named Daniel Van Cott after his mother's brother.
3 CONT I mention these facts to show that we are one generation nearer Anna Van Cott
3 CONT than your notice showed us to be."
3 CONT Mr. Wetmore will be remembered as the former master bridge builder of
3 CONT of the New London Northern.
2 NOTE This note clearly states the relationship between Daniel Van Cott Wetmore, father, and
3 CONT Daniel Lorenzo Wetmore and Thomas Trask Wetmore, two sons.
2 SOUR Clipping, probably from the New London "Day" or Norwich "Bulletin".
1 NEWS
2 TITL East Coast Advocate and Indian River Chronicle
2 DATE 10 February 1905
2 PLAC Titusville, Florida
2 TEXT Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Denby, of New York, who have been on an extended trip through the
3 CONT West Indies, and have been at Miami and Palm Beach this week, arrived in Titusville,
3 CONT yesterday, on a visit to Mrs. Denby's brother, Mr. T. T. Wetmore. Mr. and Mrs. Denby
3 CONT have been in Titusville several times before, and have many friends here who are
3 CONT glad to see them again.

2 DATE 23 March 1906
2 PLAC Titusville, Florida
2 TEXT Mrs. Bailey and daughter, of New London, Conn., who have been visiting Mr. and Mrs.
3 CONT Thomas T. Wetmore for several months, will leave here to-day, for home. They have made
3 CONT many friends in Titusville, who hope to see them here next winter.
1 OBIT
2 TITL East Coast Advocate and Indian River Chronicle
2 DATE 22 November 1907
2 PLAC Titusville, Florida
2 TEXT Death of Mr. Wetmore
3 CONT
3 CONT On Saturday last, Nov. 16, at 10:30 a.m., departed this life Mr. Thomas T. Wetmore,
3 CONT of Titusville, of general debility, aged 82 years on Feb. 10th. The funeral service
3 CONT was held at the Wetmore residence at two o'clock on Sunday afternoon,
3 CONT Bishop Wm. C. Gray, assisted by Dean Percy J. Robottom, officiating;
3 CONT while the Episcopal church choir sang some appropriate hymns.
3 CONT
3 CONT After the Episcopal church service, the remains were turned over to the care of
3 CONT Indian River Lodge No. 90, F.&A.M., there being about 30 members present,
3 CONT and they accompanied the body to the Titusville cemetery, where it was laid to rest
3 CONT with full Masonic honors, Dean Robottom (a Shriner) and Mr. J. N. Waller
3 CONT (worshipful master of the above Lodge) conducting the beautiful Masonic service for the dead.
3 CONT
3 CONT The grave was then filled by Masons, each throwing in a few spadefuls of dirt.
3 CONT Beautiful wreath of flowers were laid on the grave by friends,
3 CONT and one by the Order of Eastern Star. The service then terminated,
3 CONT the Masons wending their way back to Masonic hall, and the large concourse of
3 CONT friends to their respective homes.
3 CONT
3 CONT Mr. Wetmore was born at St. John, New Brunswick, and came to Florida 23 years ago.
3 CONT He was connected with the old J., T.&K.W. Railway Co. for several years, building
3 CONT wharves, bridges, etc. He was a resident of Titusville for 18 years,
3 CONT and was owner of the ice factory at this place nearly all that time.
3 CONT
3 CONT Mr. Wetmore was a member of Friendship Chapter No. 11, Order of Eastern Star, Titusville;
3 CONT and of Somerset Lodge No. 34, F.&A.M., of Norwich, Conn.
3 CONT
3 CONT He leaves a widow, two brothers and three sisters to mourn his loss,
3 CONT who have the heartfelt sympathy of the people of Titusville in their sad bereavement.
3 CONT
3 CONT Mrs. Wetmore has gone to Jacksonville to stay a while with her friend, Mrs. Webster,
3 CONT but will return and continue to reside in Titusville among her many friends.
1 WILL
2 TEXT Last Will and Testament of Thomas T. Wetmore, deceased.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT In the name of God amen.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT I, Thomas T. Wetmore, of the City of New London in the County of New London and State of
2 TEXT Connecticut, being of sound disposing mind and memory, do make, ordain, publish and declare
2 TEXT the following to be my last Will and Testament.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT First, I direct that my just debts and funeral expenses be paid by my Executrix,
2 TEXT hereinafter named.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Second, I give, devise and bequeath to my beloved wife, Lucy M. Wetmore, all the rest and
2 TEXT residue of my estate, both real and personal of every kind, name and nature, wheresoever
2 TEXT same may be situated, and of whatsoever the same my consist, to have and to hold to her
2 TEXT and her heirs Forever.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Third, I constitute and appoint Lucy M. Wetmore, my beloved wife, Executrix of this my last Will
2 TEXT and Testament. In witness whereof I have hereunto set my hand and seal at New London, this
2 TEXT 20th day of February A.D. 1885.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Thomas T. Wetmore (L.S.)
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Signed sealed published and declared by the above named testator Thomas T. Wetmore as
2 TEXT and for his last Will and Testament, in the prescence of us, who in his presence and in
2 TEXT the presence of each other, have hereunto subscribed our names as witnesses.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Peleg Williams (L.S)
2 TEXT Phil C. Dunford (L.S.)
2 TEXT Erastus I. Williams (L.S.)
2 TEXT
2 TEXT State of Connecticut
2 TEXT County of New London
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Personally appearted before me Peleg Williams and made solemn oath that he attested the
2 TEXT within will of Thomas T. Wetmore and subscribed the same in the presence of the
2 TEXT testator and in the presence of the two subscribing witnesses to said will and that they
2 TEXT also subscribed and attested said will in the prescense of the deponent and of each
2 TEXT other and in the presence of said testator and that said testator at the time of the
2 TEXT execution of said will was of sound mind and memory and signed and published said will
2 TEXT in the presence of said deponent and of the subscribing witnesses thereto.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Andrew C. Sepperts, Jr.
2 TEXT Justice of the Peace
2 TEXT
2 TEXT State of Florida
2 TEXT Brevard County
2 TEXT
2 TEXT I, B. R. Wilson, County Judge of Brevard County and state aforesaid hereby certify that the
2 TEXT foregoing instrument of writing is a true and correct copy of the last Will and Testament
2 TEXT of Thomas T. Wetmore deceased as recorded in the Book of Wills, No. 2, Page 50 on file
2 TEXT in my office. Witness my hand and the seal of the Country Court this April 6th, A.D. 1908.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT (Seal of Court) B. R. Wilson, County Judge of Brevard County.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Indorsed:
2 TEXT Certified copy of the Last Will and Testament of Thomas T. Wetmore deceased.
2 TEXT Filed April 7, 1908.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT M. I. Cox, County Judge
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Recorded by E. E. Haskell, County Judge

1 RESI
2 NAME Myra Jane Denby
2 DATE 30 November 1899
2 PLAC Montclair, New Jersey
2 SOUR Book inscription
3 TEXT To my grand nephew Thomas Trask Wetmore, third
3 TEXT from Aunt Myra Jane Denby, Montclair, N.J.
3 TEXT November 30th 1899
3 NOTE This Thomas Trask Wetmore is in the database as Thomas Trask Wetmore, Jr.;
4 CONT He is called the third here becase at the time he was the youngest of
4 CONT three living Thomas Trask Wetmores, himself, his father, and his
4 CONT great uncle, brother of his grandfather, Daniel Lorenzo Wetmore.
4 CONT Myra is half sister to this Thomas's grandfather.
1 NEWS
2 TITL East Coast Advocate and Indian River Chronicle
2 DATE 10 Februry 1905
2 PLAC Titusville, Florida, United States
2 TEXT Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Denby, of New York, who have been on an extended trip through
3 CONT the West Indies, and have been at Miami and Palm Beach this week, arrived in
3 CONT Titusville, yesterday, on a visit to Mrs. Denby's brother, Mr. T. T. Wetmore.
3 CONT Mr. and Mrs. Denby have been in Titusville several times before, and have
3 CONT many friends here who are glad to see them agian.

1 OBIT
2 TEXT WETMORE--In New London, April 7, 1897, Mary Ann Doty, wife of Daniel L. Wetmore, aged
2 TEXT 69 years, 3 months, 14 days.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Funeral from her late residence, No. 24 Woodbridge street, on Sunday, the 11th inst. at 2 p.m.
2 TEXT Relatives and friends invited to attend.
2 TEXT Interment at Jordan Cemetery
1 OBIT
2 TEXT MRS. WETMORE'S FUNERAL
2 TEXT
2 TEXT The funeral of Mrs. Daniel L. Wetmore was solemnized at her late residence, 24 Woodbridge street, at
2 TEXT 2 o'clock Sunday afternoon.
2 TEXT Rev. Franklin G. McKeever of the First Baptist church, of which the deceased was a member, officiated.
2 TEXT There was a wealth of flowers in loving remembrance of one who by her kind acts had endeared herself
2 TEXT to many hearts.
2 TEXT The bearers were four grandsons of Mrs. Wetmore: Herbert V. Wetmore, Frank Borges, Samuel Barns [sic]
2 TEXT and Charles Barns [sic], Jr.
2 TEXT The interment was at Jordan cemetery.
1 BURI
2 CEME Jordan
2 PLAC Waterford, Connecticut
2 NOTE headstone gives date of death as 1905
2 SOUR Jordan Cemetery

2 BURI
3 DATE 7 December 1927
3 PLAC Winchester, Massachusetts, United States
3 CEME Wildwood cemetery
2 SOUR Medford death records
1 DEAT
2 ADDR Dearborn Hospital, Medford
2 SOUR Obituary
1 OBIT
2 DATE 5 December 1927 [written on by hand]
2 TEXT FORMER WINCHESTER WOMAN DIED SUNDAY
3 CONT
3 CONT Mrs. Mattie E. (Wetmore) Cullin, formerly of Winchester, passed
3 CONT away Sunday, December 4th in the Dearborn Hospital, Medford, at
3 CONT the age of 75 years.
3 CONT She has been in ill health for the past four years, having
3 CONT sustained a shock then, and another shock 7 weeks ago sent her
3 CONT to the Hospital with an illness which caused her death.
3 CONT
3 CONT Mrs. Cullin was born in Nova Scotia, of New York parents, and
3 CONT spent her childhood in New London, Conn.
3 CONT She lived in Winchester then but about ten years ago took up
3 CONT residence with her daughter Mrs. William Thompson of
3 CONT Somerville.
3 CONT She was a member of the Board of Directors of the Y.M.C.A.
3 CONT Auxillary of that city, the Browning Club of Somerville of
3 CONT which she was president, and the Browning Club of Boston, the
3 CONT Heptorean Club of Somerville and the Winter Hill Congregational
3 CONT Church.
3 CONT Her ill health four years ago caused her retirement from active
3 CONT work in these organizations.
3 CONT
3 CONT Mrs. Cullin leaves two daughters, Mrs. W. M. Rice of Cambridge
3 CONT and Mrs. William Thompson of Somerville, a brother T. Trask
3 CONT Wetmore, of New London, conn., and a sister, Mrs. Charles
3 CONT Barnes of New London, Conn., and also two grandchildren. [W. J.
3 CONT Thompson and E. B. Thompson - D -- handwritten addition by W.
3 CONT J. Thompson Jr]
1 BURI
2 DATE 7 December 1927
2 PLAC Winchester, Massachusetts
2 CEME Wildwood cemetery
2 SOUR on her Medford death record

1 OBIT
2 DATE 11 February 1916
2 PLAC New London, New London, Connecticut, United States
2 SOUR New London Day
2 TEXT Death of Mrs. Kaneen.
3 CONT
3 CONT Well-Known Woman Succumbs to Apoplexy, at her Home.
3 CONT
3 CONT Mrs. Margaret Kaneen, widow of Daniel Kaneen, died today at her home, 810 Bank Street.
3 CONT Mrs. Kaneen suffered an apopletic stroke last week and failed to rally.
3 CONT She was a native of Wales, but had been in this country nearly 50 years.
3 CONT She was a member of St. James' Episcopal church.
3 CONT
3 CONT Six children survive, William, Thomas, John, Mrs. James D. Pettigrew, Mrs. Walter Shiels,
3 CONT Miss Maude Kaneen, and there are three grandchildren, Clarence W. Kaneen, of Providence
3 CONT and Miss Portia Wetmore and T. Trask Wetmore, Jr., of this city.
3 CONT
3 CONT In her long residence here, Mrs. Kaneen made many warm friends.
3 CONT She possessed admirable qualities which won for her the love and respect of her family
3 CONT and friends

1 REFN nancyscott
1 NAME Nancy Scott
1 ADDR 4858 Skyline Drive, Bluff Point, NY 14478.
1 NOTE She and husband Roger operation Scott Vineyards, a small grape
2 CONT farm, in the Finger Lakes region of western New York.
1 EVEN Email Received
2 DATE 30 August 1996
2 FROM Nancy Scott
2 EMAL scottvin@vivanet.com
2 SUBJ Wetmore ancestry
2 TEXT Mr Wetmore,
3 CONT My mother and I have been tracing the family tree and have come
3 CONT across a Wetmore line and wonder if there is any connection to
3 CONT your line.
3 CONT We have a Dorothy Wetmore b 4/4/1751 in Middletown, CT in
3 CONT our line.
3 CONT She married John Rockwell, Jr.
3 CONT Dorothy's father was Increase Wetmore born 7/2/1726 in
3 CONT Middletown, CT.
3 CONT When I saw your James Wetmore who was born 12/31/1695 in
3 CONT Middletown I couldn't help wondering if there was a connection.
3 CONT Have you ever run across an Increase Wetmore in your research?
3 CONT If you have, we surely would appreciate any info you could share
3 CONT with us on him.
1 EVEN Email Received
2 DATE 8 September 1996
2 TEXT I have a question about the information you sent on the Wetmores.
3 CONT I gave a copy to my mother.
3 CONT She had done more work on this line than I was aware and she had
3 CONT a different set of parents for Sarah Chilson, wife of Increase
3 CONT Wetmore.
3 CONT She has Sarah's parents as a John Chilson Jr and Sarah Wetmore.
3 CONT She has info on these people back about 4 generations.
3 CONT John Chilson Jr's parents are John Chilson Sr and Sarah Jenks and
3 CONT Sarah Wetmore's parents are Beriah Wetmore and Margaret Stow.
3 CONT This looks like another connection to the Wetmores, if it's
3 CONT accurate.
3 CONT My problem with her info is I'm not sure how well documented it
3 CONT is, if at all.
3 CONT She seems to have started up this line when she received an eight
3 CONT generation chart from a lady in Ohio starting with Dorothy Wetmore.
3 CONT How sure are you that Daniel Chilson is Sarah Chilson's father?
3 CONT Did you get a reference for this information somewhere?
3 CONT If so, I'd appreciate it if you would share it with me, as Mother
3 CONT may be "barking up the wrong tree", literally.
3 CONT I see in my Family Tree Maker that I have the ability to send out
3 CONT info with the GEDCOM format.
3 CONT I will hold off trying that, however, until hearing from you on
3 CONT this question.
3 CONT I obviously don't have Mother's 8 generation chart in my computer
3 CONT that deals with Dorothy Wetmore because I'm not sure it's relevant.
3 CONT If you think it might be, I'll send you a copy snail mail and will
3 CONT also include my info on Dorothy Wetmore at the same time.

1 MARR
2 DATE 10 March 1914
2 PLAC New London, New London, Connecticut
2 TEXT Wetmore-Carruthers Wedding This Morning
3 CONT Ceremony Was Performed at 10 o-Clock at Home of Bride.
3 CONT Mrs. Arline Louisa Caruthers, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. W. B. Keeney, of Hempstead street,
3 CONT who has been a trained nurse in New York for some time, was married to Thomas T. Wetmore at
3 CONT 10 o'clock this morning at the  home of the bride. The wedding was a very quiet affair.
3 CONT The ceremony was performed by Rev. Charles R. McNally.
3 CONT
3 CONT The couple were attended by Mill Portia and Trask Wetmore. The bride wore a handsome gown
3 CONT of blue with a hat to match. The couple left on the 11.15 train for Boston for a brief
3 CONT wedding trip. On their return they will reside at Ocean beach, where Mr. Wetmore has
3 CONT recently erected a new cottage.
2 SOUR New London "Day", March 10, 1914.

1 GRAD
2 DATE 1847

1 DEAT
2 DATE 16 October 1873
2 PLAC Boston, Massachusetts, United States
2 CAUS suicide by gunshot
2 SOUR article from a Boston newspaper
1 BURI
2 PLAC Cambridge, Massacuhsetts, United States
2 CEME Mt. Auburn cemetery
2 SOUR Ruth Ridgeway
2 SOUR unknown
1 NOTE Boston newspaper article
2 CONT Boston, October 17, 1873
2 CONT Melancholy Suicide
2 CONT The Portuguese Consul Shoots Himself
2 CONT Through the Head
2 CONT
2 CONT At about half-past four yesterday afternoon M. de F. H. Borges,
2 CONT Portuguese Consul and Vice Consul for Brazil, shot himself
2 CONT through the head with a pistol in an archway on Central wharf.
2 CONT He had left his office No. 27 Central Wharf but a few moments
2 CONT previous, telling his wife, who was in the office at the time,
2 CONT that he was going out, but did not say when he should return.
2 CONT He then kissed her and left the office, going directly to the
2 CONT archway, where, drawing a revolver from his pocket and holding
2 CONT it to his head, he fired, the ball entering the skull just
2 CONT above the right temple, killing him instantly.
2 CONT
2 CONT Officer Hathaway of Station Two, hearing the report hastened to
2 CONT the spot and found the unfortunate gentleman lying in a pool of
2 CONT blood.
2 CONT Sergeant Foster of Station Two arrived soon after and had the
2 CONT remains conveyed to the House of Reception, where they were
2 CONT viewed by Coroner Foye, who concluded that, under the
2 CONT circumstances, an inquest would be unnecessary.
2 CONT A gold watch and chain and a considerable sum of money were
2 CONT found upon the deceased together with a number of papers, the
2 CONT contents of which afforded no information as to the motive
2 CONT which led to the commission of the act of suicide.
2 CONT
2 CONT The pistol which was used was a six shooter of the Smith and
2 CONT Wesson pattern, and as it was stated by those who knew him
2 CONT that he was not in the habit of carrying a pistol, it is
2 CONT supposed that the weapon was obtained with a view to self
2 CONT destruction.
2 CONT
2 CONT The deceased was born in the island of Flores and came to this
2 CONT country about 25 years ago.
2 CONT He was, as will be remembered by those who knew him, a fine
2 CONT looking man and a man of excellent education, speaking several
2 CONT languages with great fluency.
2 CONT On coming to this country he entered a printing establishment
2 CONT in Charleston, where he served his apprenticeship.
2 CONT He also was the author of a book entitled "A Guide to
2 CONT Portuguese Conversation".
2 CONT He has been well known in business circles in this city for a
2 CONT number of years, having been engaged particularly in the trade
2 CONT with the Western Islands, which he aided materially in
2 CONT developing.
2 SOUR from a Boston newspaper account
1 FAMS @F5269@
1 FAMS @F22@

1 DEAT
2 NAME Edwin Cullin
2 DATE 22 June 1911
2 PLAC Hull, Massachusetts, United States
2 SEX M
2 AGE 63 years, - months, 20 days
2 RESI
3 ADDR 222 Broadway, Somerville, Massachusetts
2 OCCU Provision Merchant
2 BIRT
3 PLAC Maine
2 FATH
3 NAME John Cullin
3 BIRT
4 PLAC New Brunswick, Canada
2 MOTH
3 NAME Elizabeth Pickett
3 BIRT
4 PLAC Maine
2 CAUS angina pectoris
2 BURI
3 PLAC Winchester
3 CEME Wildwood
2 SOUR Hull vital records, certified [but retyped] copy
1 BURI
2 PLAC Winchester, Massachusetts
2 CEME Wildwood Cemetery
2 SOUR Hull vital records
1 OBIT
2 TEXT Edwin Cullin died on Thursday of last week (1911) while seated
3 CONT in the Waveland station at Hull, where he was waiting for a
3 CONT train for Boston.
3 CONT Death was due to angina petoris, with which he had been
3 CONT affected for the past three years.
3 CONT
3 CONT Mr. Cullin was sixty-three years of age and a native of
3 CONT Robbinston, Me.
3 CONT His parents were John W. and Elizabeth (Fickett) Cullin.
3 CONT On reaching his majority, he came to Boston and entered the
3 CONT employ of John P. Squire & Co. as salesman at 21 and 22 Fanueil
3 CONT Hall market.
3 CONT He left to engage in the wholesale provision for himself, and
3 CONT for thirty-three years had been in business in the market
3 CONT district.
3 CONT On account of poor health the past few years, the active
3 CONT management had been left largely with men in his employ, but at
3 CONT the time of his death he was on his way to Boston to see his
3 CONT men.
3 CONT He was for sixteen years a resident of Charlestown, Ma. before
3 CONT coming to Somerville seventeen years ago, when he built his
3 CONT residence at 222 Broadway.
3 CONT He was a member of Henry Price Lodge A.F. and A.M., Coeur de
3 CONT Lion commandery and Hunker Hill lodge I.O.O.F. also the Saint
3 CONT Croix Valley association.
3 CONT While living in Charlestown he was prominently identified with
3 CONT the Trinity Methodist Church, serving as steward for several
3 CONT years.
3 CONT At the time of his death, he was a member of the Winter Hill
3 CONT Congreational Church.
3 CONT In 1875 he married at New London, Conn. to Miss Mattie M.
3 CONT Wetmore of that place, and besides his widow he is survived by
3 CONT two daughters, Mrs. H.S. Stephenson of Winchester, Ma. and Mrs.
3 CONT William J. Thompson of Somerville.
3 CONT One child died in infancy.
3 CONT A brother, J. Wesley Cullin, resides at West Somerville, and a
3 CONT sister, Mrs. Bernard Rogers, at Pembroke, Maine.
3 CONT He was held in high regard by business associates and friends,
3 CONT and was a devoted husband and father.
3 CONT
3 CONT The funeral services were held on Sunday at 2 o'clock at the
3 CONT family residence 222 Broadway, and were largely attended.
3 CONT Rev. Charles L. Noyes D.D. officiated and the selection "Nearer
3 CONT My God to Thee", "The Eternal Goodness" and "Passing Out of the
3 CONT Shadow" were sing by George Wiley of Winchester, a friend of
3 CONT the family.
3 CONT There was a profusion of flowers from the lodges with which Mr.
3 CONT Cullin was connected, neighbors, and friends.
3 CONT After the service flowers were sent to the Home for the Aged,
3 CONT and the Childrens Home.
3 CONT The interment was at Wildwood Cemetery, Winchester, Mass.
3 CONT The following acted as pallbearers: Samuel C, Darling, Charles
3 CONT T. Hall, representing the Winter Hill church, George Brundage,
3 CONT Charles Eastman, Frank and ALbert Warren from the market
3 CONT district of Boston.
2 SOUR copied from a transcript of the obituary that was typed by
3 CONT William J Thompson Jr

1 RESI
2 DATE 1906
2 EMPL U.S. Navy
2 RANK chief carpenter's mate
2 SOUR Slocum Genealogy
1 DEAT
2 DATE 20 or 21 May 1933
2 PLAC Newport, Rhode Island
2 SOUR Helen Pratt
1 NOTE served in Spanish American War and World War I
1 OBIT
2 TEXT Herbert Van Cott Wetmore was the eldest of two sons of Nova Scotian-born shipwright,
2 TEXT Herbert Van Cott Wetmore [sic] and Charlotte R Slocum of Connecticut.
2 TEXT He enlisted in the US Navy in 1897 and was assigned to the battleship, USS Iowa,
2 TEXT where he served as a shipwright during the Spanish American war and until 1903.
2 TEXT He was promoted to Carpenter (warrant officer) in 1909, the same year he married his
2 TEXT Finnish-born wife, Amalia Tilus in Manhattan (11/20/09).
2 TEXT He was only the second Carpenter on the battleship, USS Texas (BB-35) were he was
2 TEXT assigned from 1915 until February 1918. He had one daughter, Helen, born in 1917.
2 TEXT He maintained his residence at Newport, Rhode Island, where he built his own home.
2 TEXT Carpenter Wetmore died suddenly in May 1933 at the age of 58 while stationed at the
2 TEXT Naval Training Station, Newport, RI.
2 TEXT He was posthumously advanced in rank to Lieutenant, in the Construction Corps.
2 SOUR Find-a-Grave

2 SOUR New London marriage records
1 TEXT New London Dec 2nd .. [1921]
2 CONT Dear Hurbie & famley / Sory to think you have to go so soon /
2 CONT we sent the trunk wed you must / have it by this time the
2 CONT other one was / to poor.  I shant forget your & Mollie /
2 CONT kindness to me when down it is something / to think about for
2 CONT some time I went / to see a specilist on my trouble & / he
2 CONT says its my heart the Blood dont go thrue as it aught to so
2 CONT I / may not be hear when you all / get back but I have to go
2 CONT some time // just hurd of Portia Benham deth / she went to
2 CONT the Hospital yesterday / & died at 12 30 I feel very sory / for
2 CONT all of them she was so young & / something to live for.  I am
2 CONT glad / she came home about a month / ago.  I think Trask & Tom
2 CONT will take / it very hard.  Ralph was down & he / & family are
2 CONT well.  Kristeen [?] is hear / to help me clean up the Dr says
2 CONT / I must stop working, as Mollie / told me last summer I dont
2 CONT / know how. to let others do for me / & I think she all right
2 CONT // & she is a good person & the I / see of her the dearer she
2 CONT is to me / dont let Hellen forget her Gramma / Leah left us
2 CONT at Bridgeport. they / said they come up on some / Sunday
2 CONT soon / this will be all this time / love to all kiss Hellen
2 CONT for Gramma / answer / Mother
2 SOUR a letter in the possession of Helen Pratt that is very
3 CONT probably from this person; the Hurbie would Herbert Van
3 CONT Cott Wetmore; Mollie his wife.

2 DATE 18 February 1923
2 PLAC New London, Connecticut
2 SOUR Karen Morgan family group sheet
