0 @I144@ INDI
1 NAME James /Wetmore/
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE 19 December 1727
2 PLAC Rye, Westchester County, New York, United States
2 SOUR @S1@
1 RESI
2 PLAC Rye, Westchester County, New York, United States
1 EVEN letter
2 DATE 10 January 1777
2 PLAC Rye, New York
2 INFO This is a letter written by James Wetmore
2 TEXT Revd Sr
3 CONT I have this day drawn a Set of Bills for five pounds
3 CONT sterling upon William Symondson, Esqr, the Venerable
3 CONT Societys Treasurer, Payable to the Revd Samuel Seabury.
3 CONT I beg leave to inform the venble Society that I deligently
3 CONT taught the School in Rye until the 23d day of Octbr last.
3 CONT I had under my Tuition the last six months upwards of
3 CONT sixty scholars, many of which I never did nor do expect one
3 CONT Copper Reward for from their parents.
3 CONT For more than a year before the 23d of Octbr, I was lookt
3 CONT upon as a friend of Government and I had reason to expect
3 CONT continually to be made a Prisoner.
3 CONT I though myself then under an absolute necessity of
3 CONT escaping, being detected in assisting a number of persons
3 CONT in escaping from the Rebels to the Kings Troops.
3 CONT I have one son carried 200 miles from [here] and closely
3 CONT confined for his Loyalty, part of the time in Irons.
3 CONT I have another son engaged in his Majesties Service.
3 CONT I have another son too young for the service with me.
3 CONT My wife and six children are in the Power of the Rebels.
3 CONT My brother, Timothy Wetmore Esqr made a narrow escape with
3 CONT his wife and seven children and has almost all his effects
3 CONT destroyed by the Rebels.
3 CONT Our unfortunate Minister, Mr. Avery, was found dead near
3 CONT his House the beginning of Novbr Last.
3 CONT I pray God soon enable our Gracious Sovereign to reduce
3 CONT Americans to their Allegiance.
3 CONT
3 CONT I am, Revd Sr/ Your Humble Servt/ James Wetmore
2 SOUR NYGBR, 1974, vol 104, no 2, pg 120
1 LAND Land grant to James Wetmore
2 NAME James Witmore
2 DATE 9 August 1784
2 PLAC Lancaster, Saint John, New Brunswick, Canada
2 PLOT 10 acres
2 SOUR fide J.R. Elliott
1 LAND Land grant to James Wetmore
2 NAME James Whitmore
2 DATE 11 August 1784
2 PLAC Hammond River, Hampton Parish, New Brunswick, Canada
2 PLOT 250 acres
2 SOUR fide J.R. Elliott
1 FACT
2 DATE 25 December 1787
2 PLAC Kingston Parish, Kings County, New Brunswick, Canada
2 NOTE James Wetmore was mentioned in a letter written by Frederick
3 CONT Dibble to the Society for the Propagation of the Gospel,
3 CONT written in Waterbury, Connecticut, 25 December 1787.
2 TEXT The people at Kingston are in very great need of a schoomaster,
3 CONT being unable without some assistance to give their children a
3 CONT tolerable education.
3 CONT Should the society think proper to appoint one, Mr. James
3 CONT Wetmore, formerly S.P.G. schoolmaster at Rye, wishes to be the
3 CONT person.
2 SOUR typescript entitled "Trinity Churh, Kingston, N.B.," by Rev. W.
3 CONT O. Raymond, on LDS microfilm #0862071.
1 DEAT
2 DATE 10 February 1798
2 PLAC Hammond River, Kings County, New Brunswick, Canada

2 SOUR Acadiensis

3 INFO Church of England, New York
2 TEXT d. Kings Co., 10th inst, age 71, James s/o Rev. James WETMORE Church of England, New York.

1 BURI
2 NAME James Wetmore
2 BIRT
3 DATE 1727
2 DEAT
3 DATE 1798
2 PLAC French Village, Kings County, New Brunswick, Canada
2 SOUR note from Kings Co. Hist. Soc., attributed to Judge Keirstead
1 BURI
2 PLAC Hampton, Kings County, New Brunswick, Canada
2 SOUR Acadiensis
1 BURI
2 PLAC French Village, New Brunswick, Canada
2 CEME Acadian Loyalist Cemetery
3 ADDR 930 French Village Road (Route 860)
2 POST Kings County, New Brunswick Board at Ancestry.com
3 TITL Title of thread is Acadian Loyalist Cemetery French Village
3 TEXT I was at the cemetery today. It is at 930 French Village Rd. ( Route 860).
4 CONT The farm is now owned by someone else, but I just drove down by the right side
4 CONT of the barn and the cemetery came into view. For driving directions,
4 CONT I would advise (coming from Saint John on the highway to Sussex) to exit at the exit
4 CONT JUST PAST the exit to Gondola Point Arterial / Kingston Peninsula ferry.
4 CONT Sorry I don't know the exit number. Then drive a couple of k's until you see
4 CONT "Stock Farm Rd." on the right and turn onto it. Follow the Stock Farm Rd.
4 CONT which crosses under the highway and turn left. You will be on route 860/ French Village Rd.
4 CONT Soon you will go through the covered bridge that crosses the Hammond River.
4 CONT Keep going until you see the sign for No. 930 on the right. Drive in and go to
4 CONT the right of the barn. I did not have time to photograph or record today.
4 CONT There were about 50 headstones, some very old, some this year's.
4 CONT By the way, Google Earth did not do that road. :( Hope this helps, Suzanne Carter
2 POST Kings County, New Brunswick Board at Ancestry.com
3 TITL Title of thread is Acadian Loyalist Cemetery French Village
3 TEXT I located the marker for my ancestor's, James Wetmore,grave.
4 CONT His wife, Elizabeth Abrahams, is also buried there.
4 CONT It was on the left side of the cemetery, down the hill from a large maple tree.
4 CONT I imagine that when he was buried there, the gravesite was on a promontory that
4 CONT overlooked the Hammond River; today the trees block much of the river view
4 CONT but it's still a beautiful spot.
4 CONT Thanks again for your scouting trip
4 CONT Amy (Young?)
1 INFO The Dwight book gives his birth as 9 Dec 1727.

2 SOUR sheet on T.T. Wetmore Jr. letterhead
1 REMV
2 DATE 1783
2 PLAC New Brunswick, Canada
2 INFO Loyalist
2 SOUR JCW
1 REMV
2 DATE about 1783
2 PLAC Jamaica, West Indies
2 SOUR Acadiensis
1 REMV
2 PLAC New York
2 DATE after many years in the West Indies
2 SOUR Acadiensis
1 DEAT
2 DATE 6 February 1790
2 PLAC Marlborough, New York
1 TEXT He, on the breakout of the Revolution, remained loyal to the
2 CONT crown.
2 CONT He signed the Manifest, or Declaration, in company with his
2 CONT father and uncle.
2 CONT He removed to New Brunswick, at about the close of the war.
2 CONT He died in New York, Feb. 6, 1790.
2 CONT His widow subsequently married Sylvanus Whitney.
2 CONT She died in Saint Johns [sic], about 1804.
2 SOUR JCW
1 TEXT Abraham Wetmore, the oldest child of James Wetmore, was born in
2 CONT Rye, N. Y., Nov. 29th (9th?), 1747.
2 CONT He was among the Loyalists of the Revolution, but did not
2 CONT come to these provinces.
2 CONT Together with his father and uncle, he was one of the
2 CONT eighty-three who signed the Declaration of Loyalty above
2 CONT noted.
2 CONT He was a captain of cavalry under Sir Henry Clinton, and at
2 CONT the close of the war he went to Jamaica, W. I., and settled
2 CONT there.
2 CONT After many years he returned to New York, and died at
2 CONT Marlborough, in that state, on the 6th Feb., 1790.
2 CONT Two of his older [sic] brothers came to this Province with
2 CONT their grandparents.
2 SOUR Acadiensis

2 NAME Azraiah Wetmore
2 NOTE Family consists of 1 male 16 or older, one male under 16, and 4 females. This would have
3 CONT been Izrahiah, his son Bush, his wife Elizabeth, and three daughters Ester, Rebecca
3 CONT and Elizabeth. Daughter Nancy died in her first year.
2 NOTE Azraiah/Izrahiah is the head of the only Wetmore household in Rye. All other brothers and
3 CONT and uncles have removed to New Brunswick.
2 SOUR 1790 U.S. Census of Rye, New York
1 REMV
2 PLAC New Brunswick, Canada
1 DEAT
2 DATE 7 February 1838
2 PLAC Rye, Westchester County, New York
1 NOTE He was a loyalist.
1 TEXT He resided at Rye.
2 CONT He was a loyalist and signed at White Plains, April 13, 1775,
2 CONT with three hundred other freeholders and inhabitants of the
2 CONT county of Westchester, the famous protest "against the
2 CONT assembling of all unlawful congresses and committees."
2 CONT (Bolton Hist. of W., II, 351-2.)
2 CONT He died Feb. 7, 1838, and was buried in the old yard attached
2 CONT to Christ Church, not far from the grave of his grandfather,
2 CONT the Rev. James.
2 CONT His wife died in the fall of the year 1853, in her 93rd year,
2 CONT and her remains rest beside those of her husband.
1 SOUR JCW

3 SOUR Baird/Wetmore Family Tree, Ancesty.com
2 PLAC Norton, Kings County, New Brunswick, Canada
2 INFO He died at the home of a son.
1 BURI
2 NAME David Brown Wetmore
2 AGE 81 years
2 PLAC Bloomfield, Kings County, New Brunswick, Canada
2 CEME Christ Church Anglican Cemetery
2 SOUR New Brunswick Cemeteries Database, New Brunswick Provincial Archives
1 TEXT David Brown Wetmore was the original patriarch who was given
2 CONT eight sections of land which became known as Clifton, so
2 CONT named around 1852.
2 SOUR Notes from Kings Co. Hist. Soc.
1 TEXT He was a loyalist, and removed with his father to New
2 CONT Brunswick in 1783, and resided for several years in the
2 CONT parish of Hampton; from thence he removed to Saint Johns [sic],
2 CONT where he lived a short time, from thence to Kingston, county
2 CONT of Kings, in 1820.
2 CONT He was a colonel of the first battalion of Kingston militia,
2 CONT and was a representative in the General Assembly of the
2 CONT Province for many years, and a Judge of the Common Pleas and
2 CONT Quarter Sessions.
2 CONT He died at Norton, Kings co., Dec. 17, 1845, in his 82d
2 CONT year.
2 CONT His wife, Ruth Sherwood, died Dec. 17, 1795.
2 CONT Her father, Justus Sherwood, was a loyalist, and resided at
2 CONT Cortlandt Manor, Westchester co., N.Y.
2 CONT He, with his brothers Abijah and Jonathan, were grantees of
2 CONT Saint John, N.B., in 1783; he died in Kings co., in 1836, at
2 CONT the age of eighty-four (Am. Loyalists, 612).
2 CONT Mrs. Elizabeth Whitney Wetmore, died ____; her father,
2 CONT Sylvanus Whitney, was also a loyalist, and resided in
2 CONT Stamford, Conn.
2 SOUR JCW
1 TEXT David Brown Wetmore born in Rye, 1764, moved with his father to
2 CONT Saint John and to French Village.
2 CONT Married in 1787 to Ruth Sherwood daughter of Justus Sherwood
2 CONT of 1795, Hampton parish.
2 CONT Lived at French Village until about twelve years after his
2 CONT father's death, moved to Saint John and lived there for a
2 CONT short time.
2 CONT Moved to Kingston in 1800-1820.
2 CONT Colonel of the first batallion of Kingston militia.
2 CONT Was a representative in the general assembly at Fredericton,
2 CONT and later became a judge of the common pleas and quarter
2 CONT session.
2 CONT Died at the home of a son in Norton in 1845.
2 CONT Buried at Kinston.
1 INFO I also have a death date of 1846 for him.

3 SOUR Roots Web Wetmore Genealogy by Noreen Wetmore

1 CENS
2 DATE 1861
2 PLAC Toxteth Park, Liverpool, Lancashire, England
2 NAME Daniel Wetmore
2 SEX M
2 AGE 40

2 STAT Married

3 PLAC New Brunswick, Canada
2 SOUR 1861 England Census
1 NOTE
2 CONT Powell, Rev. Frank Joseph, M.A., Vicar of Knotty Ash, and Chaplain of Alder Hey Hospital.
2 CONT
2 CONT Vicarage, Knotty Ash, Liverpool (Phone: Old Swan 258; Telegrams: Broad Green, Liverpool).
2 CONT Born: February 25th, 1858, at Chester; son of John and Martha Powell (English).
2 CONT Educated: The King's School, Chester; Oxford University; B.A., First Class Theological Honours;
2 CONT M.A., Denyer and Johnson Theological Scholarship.
2 CONT Married: June 5th, 1885, to Phoebe Elizabeth, daughter of the late Daniel Wetmore,
2 CONT of Liverpool and Lima, and has issue two sons and three daughters:
2 CONT Phoebe Mildred, M.D.
2 CONT Lois Etheldreda (serving as V.A.D. Nurse in France),
2 CONT Rev. Frank Osmund Standish, M.A.,
2 CONT Cuthbert Albar Wetmore, B.Eng., serving in France (Lieut, in South Midland Royal Engineers), and
2 CONT Joyce Frideswide.
2 CONT Profession: Vicar of Knotty Ash, Liverpool.
2 CONT Appointment: Chaplain of Alder Hey Hospital.
2 CONT Publication: "Lenten Self Discipline."
2 CONT Masonic Lodge: Lodge of Prudence 2114 (P.M., P.P.G.C.); Saint John of Jerusalem Chapter (P.Z., P.P.G.J.).
2 SOUR "Lancashire: Biographies, Rolls of Honour," W. Ralph Hall Caine, London, 1917.
3 PAGE 319
1 NOTE
2 CONT DANIEL WETMORE-LIVERPOOL, ENGLAND
2 CONT Daniel Wetmore was born in Saint John, New Brunswick Canada on 4/8/1820.
2 CONT He later removed to Liverpool England at an unknown date.
2 CONT At different points of time he was in Lima and Callao Peru with his brother Jesse.
2 CONT He was married to Elizabeth Roberts.
2 CONT Would appreciate any information no matter how small.
2 CONT Would at least like to find out when Daniel died.
2 SOUR Query on Genealogy.com's GenForum for United Kingdom Genealogy Forum
3 CONT Query posted by Dana Callis, 20 January 2000 on Wetmore GenForum
1 NOTE Query response to abover from Katharine (Bobby) Pinkerton, June 8, 1999
2 CONT In Reply to: Daniel Wetmore b 1820 Canada by Dana Callis
2 CONT Dear Dana, I'd love to correspond with you - are you a relative?
2 CONT Daniel was my maternal great-grandfather.
2 CONT I have only just started researching my family so have not gone too far.
2 CONT I do not have his date of birth but have just received my grandmother's birth certificate which states
2 CONT that her mother's name was Elizabeth Roberts.
2 CONT I have found the reference to ER and DW's marriage in the St Catherine's House Index
2 CONT (which we have here in Canberra, Australia) and I have sent to England for that certificate.
2 CONT The marriage took place in the December quarter of 1858.
2 CONT I have found the family in the 1881 census (but searched last night at the LDS History Centre
2 CONT for Daniel but he was not in England in 1881 - intersting!).
2 CONT My grand mother, Phoebe, was the eldest child, followed by Douglas and 2 girls
2 CONT (one of which I vaguely remember as a very old woman in 1945).
2 CONT All the children are listed in the census as having been born in Liverpool!
2 CONT I can give you as many details as I have, perhaps you can help me!! Best wishes for now.
1 RESI
2 PLAC Liverpool, England
1 EMAL
2 DATE 15 July 2010
2 FROM Katharine Bobby Pinkerton
2 ADDR akspink@pcug.org.au
2 TEXT
3 CONT Hi Thomas'
3 CONT
3 CONT Thank you for your email.  I have completely lost Daniel!  He was my great
3 CONT grandfather, and was heard of no more after the birth of the youngest
3 CONT daughter in 1867.  When my grandmother was married in 1885, it was stated in
3 CONT the newspaper that she was daughter of the 'late Daniel Wetmore of Liverpool
3 CONT and Lima'.  I cannot find his death anywhere and have jumped to the
3 CONT conclusion that he pushed off, and probably took up with a Peruvian woman!!!
3 CONT Apart from being a mariner, publican and various other things, he was listed
3 CONT as railway architect!!  presumably this was because of his time in Peru.
3 CONT There is quite a bit on the net about Jesse, who seems to have made a
3 CONT success of his life.
3 CONT
3 CONT Are you a descendant of his son Douglas, or from another branch of the
3 CONT family.  There is a lot about Wetmores  in various places and I have quite
3 CONT an extensive family tree.  They seemed to have huge families, and each
3 CONT person seemed to marry several times!
3 CONT
3 CONT I do hope you have some information about Daniel.  He was married at least
3 CONT once before he married my little Welsh great granny, and indeed called the
3 CONT child of the first Liverpool marriage Phoebe Elizabeth (the same name as my
3 CONT grandmother!, but that child died as an infant (I bought that first marriage
3 CONT certificate and the child's birth certificate).  I, again, assume that the
3 CONT Liverpool wife Ann, died sometime before he married my great granny,
3 CONT Elizabeth Roberts.
3 CONT
3 CONT I am sure we can solve a problem or two if we put our heads together!!  Are
3 CONT you in USA?  I am in Australia.
3 CONT
3 CONT Best wishes
3 CONT Katharine Pinkerton

1 EVEN Email Received
2 DATE 9 May 1996
2 FROM Suzanne Clark
2 EMAL Suzanne.Clark@quickmail.llnl.gov
2 SUBJ Wetmore Family
2 TO Tom Wetmore, ttw@shore.net
2 TEXT Dear Mr. Wetmore,
2 TEXT I'm doing family research on the Wetmore's of California.
2 TEXT I only go back to Jesse Lamereux Wetmore who came to Calif. in
2 TEXT 1853 from Portland, Maine.
2 TEXT He was a native of News Brunswick and died in Calif. in 1903.
2 TEXT Your Jesse Lamereux Wetmore (b1790, d1853) is the wrong generation
2 TEXT to be my ancestor.
2 TEXT What do you know of your Jesse Wetmore b1819?
2 TEXT Do you have a middle name for him or more life history?
2 TEXT Thank you,
2 TEXT Suzanne Clark
1 EVEN Email Received
2 DATE 10 May 1996
2 FROM Suzanne Clark
2 EMAL Suzanne.Clark@quickmail.llnl.gov
2 SUBJ Wetmore Family
2 TO Tom Wetmore <ttw@shore.net>
2 TEXT Tom,
2 TEXT I guess you know how excited I am to find the family of Jesse
2 TEXT Lamereux Wetmore.
2 TEXT Your information is very special to my family and others
2 TEXT interested in California state history.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT What I know about JLW is that he was probably born in New Brunswick, Canada
2 TEXT and died Jan. 1, 1902 in Oakland, CA.
2 TEXT He was married in 1843 to Matilda.
2 TEXT He worked as a builder in Boston and Portland, Maine.
2 TEXT He came to California about 1853.
2 TEXT He went to Chile to work on the railroad with "Honest" Harry Mieggs
2 TEXT in 1861.
2 TEXT In 1866 he was in Bolivia; then more railroad building in the
2 TEXT Andes of Peru; came back to Oakland in 1873 to work in the real
2 TEXT estate business.
2 TEXT Matilda died May 5, 1901 in Oakland, CA.
2 TEXT They had four children that I know of: Clarence J., Charles A.,
2 TEXT Ida Matilda, Anna Louise.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Clarence J. was born in Portland. Maine.
2 TEXT He had one child, Philomena who married H. L. Hubbard.
2 TEXT Clarence went into the wine business with his brother Charles in
2 TEXT Livermore, CA.
2 TEXT Philomena was living in Paradise, CA in 1980.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Charles A. was born in 1847, died June 10, 1927 in San Francisco.
2 TEXT He was married to Anna D. Smith.
2 TEXT Charles A. was in the first graduating class of what became the
2 TEXT University of California.
2 TEXT Charles worked as a newspaper reporter then went into the wine
2 TEXT business in Livermore, CA.
2 TEXT Charles is considered the 'father' of the California wine industry.
2 TEXT They had five children: John B., Louis S., Charles A. Jr,
2 TEXT Elizabeth S., Henrietta Victoria.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT John and Louis were in the wine business and had no children.
2 TEXT Charles A. Jr.  lived the longest, never married, he was an
2 TEXT attorney for the state and in private practice in Marysville, CA.
2 TEXT He's the one that sold the family winery, Cresta Blanca, which
2 TEXT eventually shut down.
2 TEXT Elizabeth was a school teacher, never married.
2 TEXT Henrietta Victoria taught school and married twice.
2 TEXT The first time to Ray Acker.
2 TEXT He died in 1918.
2 TEXT They had one child, Jesse (a daughter).
2 TEXT Henrietta married again July 4, 1919 to Ernest Darwin Mendenhall.
2 TEXT They had twin boys in 1920, John Louis and Charles Darwin.
2 TEXT Jesse Acker married John Shields and has two daughters Martha and
2 TEXT Mary.
2 TEXT Martha and Mary are both married and have children.
2 TEXT John Louis Mendenhall (a trucker) married Alice Joseph and had
2 TEXT four children: John Louis Jr., Douglas Dale, Suzanne Elaine, and
2 TEXT Victoria Ann.
2 TEXT John Louis Jr. (Jack) is single and has no children.
2 TEXT The rest of us (Doug, Suzanne, and Vicki) are married with children.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Charles Darwin Mendenhall was a newspaper reporter and then taught
2 TEXT journalism at Cal Poly where he died in 1977.
2 TEXT He never married.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Ida Matilda was never married and died in 1937.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Anna Louise never married and died May 1, 1915 in Piedmont, CA.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT After you plug my line into your database, please let me know our
2 TEXT relationship.
2 TEXT As you can see from my family line, the California Wetmores often
2 TEXT did not marry , and the ones that did, did not have large broods.
2 TEXT I am happy to share what I know about the Wetmores.
2 TEXT I know I am missing significant dates from recent history.
2 TEXT I can send you my immediate family history too if you want it for
2 TEXT your database.
2 TEXT FYI: My father and Aunt Jesse are still living.
2 TEXT They're both tall.
2 TEXT Dad's 6' and Aunt Jesse is 5'10" at 83 years old!
2 TEXT
2 TEXT I would love to hear about Jesse Lamereux Wetmore's siblings.
2 TEXT Was he the only one that travelled?
2 TEXT Did anyone come out to California after him?
2 TEXT
2 TEXT The name Lamereux has always interested me too.
2 TEXT I am interested in the female lines too, for me, the Wetmore line
2 TEXT is a female line.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Thanks,
2 TEXT Suzanne Clark
1 SOUR @S1@
2 PAGE 264
1 SOUR Suzanne Clark, descendent
1 BIO
2 SOUR monutainviewpeople.blogspot.com
2 TEXT Clarence Wetmore (1851-1936) First to register at Univerity of California, Berkeley
2 TEXT Clarence Wetmore???s father, Jesse Lamereaux Wetmore, was one of those adventurous 49ers who
3 CONT came to California on the trail of gold. He returned home to Maine to father the second of
3 CONT his sons, Clarence, born in 1852, and then Jesse brought his wife and his two sons, Charles
3 CONT and Clarence back to the Golden State. The family settled first in San Francisco, but by 1861
3 CONT had settled in Oakland at their new home at Clay and Tenth.
2 TEXT But Jesse had wandering feet. He left again, this time for South America, engaged in railroad
3 CONT building in Chile and later, Bolivia. The family survived, and Charles became the
3 CONT valedictorian of the Class of 1868 at the College of California in Oakland. In 1869,
3 CONT Clarence became the first student to register at the newly established University of California
3 CONT (chartered in 1868 to be the successor to the College of California). Clarence???s class attended
3 CONT classes for all four years at the old Oakland campus of the College of California, but on their
3 CONT graduation day in 1873, this group of pioneering students received their diplomas at the first
3 CONT event ever held on the Berkeley campus.
2 TEXT Clarence married Mary Camden, a California native, and with his brother Charles, founded
3 CONT Cresta Blanca Winery in the Livermore Valley in 1882. The Cresta Blanca Winery property is today
3 CONT the home of Wente Brothers Sparkling Winery and the Wente Brothers Restaurant.
2 TEXT [Wetmore bio courtesy of Barbara Smith and the Mountain View Cemetery docent program]
1 NEWS
2 DATE 4 July 1873
2 INFO The New York Times
2 TEXT RAILROAD BUILDING IN PERU
2 TEXT Noting the recent reutrn of Mr. Jesse L. Wetmore of San Francisco, the "Alta" of that city says:
3 CONT "Mr. Wetmore came to California in '49, and was at one time well known in this city as a street
3 CONT contractor. During the last twelve years he has been connected with railroad operations in Chili
3 CONT and Peru, and was the first to work the extensive guano mines at Mexillones, Boliva.
3 CONT He built and established the first Protestant church in the City of Santiago, Chili, about
3 CONT eight years ago. In June, 1871, he undertook the work of constructing the eastern division
3 CONT of the Lima and Oroya railroad in Peru. The work of grading was commenced at the little
3 CONT Indian town of Oroya, which takes its name from the swinging bridge erected across a rapid
3 CONT torrent of the eastern water-shed of the Andes. Here the altitude is 12,200 feet above the
3 CONT level of the sea. The line going west toward the Pacific rapidly ascends the Andes to an
3 CONT an altitude of over 15,000 feet, where the summit tunnel is located. In all the country
3 CONT embracing the interior basin of the Andean chain, no firewood is obtained, and lumber for the
3 CONT most ordinary purposes is very costly. Poles are brough on the backs of mules from the eastern
3 CONT base of the cordilleras, a distnce of over twenty-five leagues, and boards are packed in
3 CONT short piees across the great snow ridge from the Pacific coast. For light packing, great
3 CONT numbers of llamas are found cerviceable ans superior to asses or mules, inasmuch as they
3 CONT can be subsisted on the coarse grasses that grow on the elevated pampas, while the other
3 CONT beasts of burden are sustained by alfalfa raised in the Tarma and other valleys, whence the
3 CONT cost of transportation is considerable. Notwithstanding the difficulties, the cold
3 CONT weather, the extreme rarity of the atmosphere, the scarcity of all articles necessary in
3 CONT the preparation of railroad work, and the indolent character of the native Inca Indian
3 CONT laborer, the work is now accomplished, and the roadbed is ready to reeive the ties and
3 CONT rails as soon as the western division is made to connect, so that the iron and wood may
3 CONT be brought up on the finished track.
2 TEXT Mr. Wetmore, wife, and daughter have been living recently as Visca, occupying an old church
3 CONT near the summit of the Andes, at an altitude higher than that of Mont Blanc.
3 CONT The ladies seem to have endured the extraordinary hardship imposed by the climate of
3 CONT such an elevated region with remarkable fortitude, and have come down from the snows
3 CONT and the clouds with buoyant spirits and good health. They were obliged to cross
3 CONT altitudes of over 16,500 feet, and have traveled on several occasions twelve and
3 CONT fiftenn leagues a day over great reidges and folds of these Titan mountains,
3 CONT and all the time being above the sea from 10,000 to 16,000 fee. Miss Wetmore as brought
3 CONT with her a collection of valuagle archaeological specimens, relics of the ancient
3 CONT life that once was diffused throughout the desolate mountain valleys and ridges.
3 CONT Among them are skulls of the Aymara Indians, pottery from old Inca graves, &c.
3 CONT Fine wool llama skins and specimens of minerals--silver, lime, &c., are also
3 CONT brought with her."
2 SOUR New York Times, 4 July 1873

0 @I228@ INDI
1 NAME James /Wetmore/
1 SEX M
1 TITL Reverend
1 BIRT
2 DATE 31 December 1695
2 PLAC Middletown, Connecticut Colony
1 GRAD
2 DATE 1714
2 INST Yale College
1 GRAD
2 DATE 1717
2 INST Yale College
1 WILL
2 TEXT The Last Will and Testament of James Wetmore, Clerk.
3 CONT
3 CONT In the Namd of God, Amen.  The sixth day of August, in the year
3 CONT of our Lord, 1759, I, James Wetmore, of Rye, in the County of
3 CONT Westchester, and Province of New York, Clerk, being of sound
3 CONT mind and memory; but calling to mind the uncertainty of life,
3 CONT and that 'tis appointed for man once to die, after that, the
3 CONT judgment; do make and ordain, and appoint this, my last will and
3 CONT testament, in manner following: That is to say: First of all, I
3 CONT bequeath my soul to God who gave it, hoping in his mercy, for
3 CONT everlasting life, through the alone merits of my blessed
3 CONT Redeemer; and my body to the earth, to be buried in a
3 CONT christianlike manner, at the discretion of my executors
3 CONT hereinafter named, in an assured expectation of its being raised
3 CONT up again at the last day by the Almighty power of my Redeemer,
3 CONT to a state of greater glory and perfection, to remain forever;
3 CONT and as to the small portion of my worldly estate, with which it
3 CONT has pleased God to bless me, I will bequeath, and dispose of the
3 CONT same in manner following, viz:
3 CONT
3 CONT Imprimis:  I give, and bequeath unto my loving wife, Anna
3 CONT Wetmore, instead of a legal dowry, the use and emolument of all
3 CONT that land, orchard, meadow, and pasture, which Samuel Lane sold
3 CONT to Raphael Jacobs, lying in the town of Rye, with the house
3 CONT thereon, and all appurtenances thereto belonging, and also that
3 CONT pasture lot adjoining thereto, which formerly belonged to Peter
3 CONT Brown, on the east side of the Road leading to Harrison's
3 CONT purchase, to the sole use of my said wife and her assigns,
3 CONT during the term of her natural life; also one equal half of
3 CONT linnen, bedding and other household furniture, and the
3 CONT priviledge of what firewood she shall have occasion for her own
3 CONT use; also theree cows and one horse.
3 CONT
3 CONT Item, I give, devise, and bequeath to my loving son, James
3 CONT Wetmore, the privilege of the shop, and dam upon Blind brook,
3 CONT for accommodating a fulling mill, with the utensils belonging to
3 CONT such mill; also the wood and pasture lott above the first stone
3 CONT fence, to extend from Abraham Brundige's land, south-westerly,
3 CONT half the width of my land bought of Joseph Haight, and from the
3 CONT stone fence that runs across my land near Brundige's house,
3 CONT north-westerly to the next fence that nowruns across my land,
3 CONT together with a privilege to cart and drive cattle thereto, from
3 CONT the bridge to the fulling mill, to him, his heirs, and assigns
3 CONT forever.
3 CONT
3 CONT Item, I give and bequeath to my loving son, Timothy, that house,
3 CONT barn, and improvements, bought of Mr. Jacobs, lying in the town
3 CONT of Rye, with all the land lying on the west side of the road
3 CONT which formerly belonged to Peter Brown, and also that part of my
3 CONT land bought of Joseph Haight, on the west side of Blink brook,
3 CONT running from said brook, north-westerly to the stone fence that
3 CONT now runs cross my land, near Abraham Brundige's, and to extend
3 CONT northerly to the land I have sequestered for a glebe, which, at
3 CONT the upper end, by the stone fence, is to be half the width of my
3 CONT lot, to him, my said son Timothy, his heirs and assigns forever.
3 CONT
3 CONT Item, I give and bequeath unto my loving daughter, Alethea, wife
3 CONT of the Rev. Joseph Lamson, L[pounds]30, bo be paid by my
3 CONT executors in one year after my decease.
3 CONT
3 CONT Item, I give, devise, and bequeath unto my loving daughter Anne,
3 CONT wife of Gilbert Brundige, so much of my land at Bullock's
3 CONT meadow, as will be included by a line bearing the same course
3 CONT with the line between said Gilbert Brundige's land and that part
3 CONT of my land he adjoins to, to begin at the south-east corner of
3 CONT said Brundige's lot, bought of Hentry Strang, to run cross
3 CONT meadow and woods, the course before specified, unto the land of
3 CONT William Haight, comprising that part of my farm that is north of
3 CONT said line, unto my said daughter Anne Brundige, her heirs and
3 CONT assigns forever; also L[pounds]10, to be paid by my executors
3 CONT unto my said daughter, within a year after my decease.
3 CONT
3 CONT Item, I give and bequeath unto my loving daughter, Charity, wife
3 CONT of Josiah Purdy, L[pounds]30, to be paid by my executors in one
3 CONT year after my decease.
3 CONT
3 CONT Item, I will devise and bequeaqth to my loving daughter, Esther
3 CONT Wetmore, the reversion of all that house, orchard, meadow, and
3 CONT pasture, which was formerly Samuel Lane's, and that pasture lot
3 CONT which did belong to Peter Brown, eastward of the road that leads
3 CONT to Harrison's purchase, with all the priviledges and
3 CONT appurtenances thereto belonging, after the decease of my wife,
3 CONT to whom I have given the use for life, the reversion and
3 CONT remainder to my said daughter; Esther Wetmore, to her heirs and
3 CONT assigns forever.  I also give and bequeath unto my loving
3 CONT daughter, Esther, one half part of all my linnen bedding, and
3 CONT other household furniture, the same to be equally divided
3 CONT between my wife and said Daughter.  All the residue and
3 CONT remainder of my estate, real and personal, after payment of
3 CONT above legacies, and all my just debts, I will devise and
3 CONT bequeath to my two loving sons, James Wetmore and Timothy
3 CONT Wetmore, to each in severalty, to be equally divided between
3 CONT them, after the sale of so much as shall be necessary for
3 CONT payment of my just debts and legacies, unto them, their heirs
3 CONT and assigns forever; and I do hereby nominate and appoint my
3 CONT said loving sons, James and Timothy, to be executors of this my
3 CONT last will and testament, disannulling all former wills by me
3 CONT made, or executors by me nominated, and do confirm this,
3 CONT contained in these two pages, alone, to be my last will and
3 CONT testament.
3 CONT
3 CONT In witness whereof, I have hereunto affixed my name and seal.
3 CONT
3 CONT James Wetmore [seal.]
3 CONT
3 CONT Signed, sealed, pronounced and declared to be his last will and
3 CONT testament, in disposing mind and memory.  In presence of
3 CONT Hachaliah Brown, Roger Park, Jr., Benjamin Brown, Jr.
2 DATE 6 August 1759
1 DEAT
2 DATE 15 May 1760
2 PLAC Rye, Westchester County, New York Colony
2 CAUS small pox
1 PROB
2 DATE 3 June 1760
1 SOUR JCW
1 NOTE James has a biography in "Yale Biographies and Annals, 1701-1745"
1 SOUR Westchester Patriarchs
1 SOUR Descendants of John Dwight of Dedham
1 SOUR notes from Kings Co Hist Soc
1 SOUR family tree from 1983 reunion

1 FAMC @F40@

0 @I231@ INDI
1 NAME Timothy /Wetmore/
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE about 1737, about 1736
2 PLAC Rye, Westchester County, New York
1 NOTE There is some confusion about his birth year.
2 CONT One record source gives it as about 1729.
1 NOTE In 1753 or 1754 he was the teacher for the parish of Rye.
1 GRAD
2 DATE 1758
2 PLAC New York, New York
2 INST Kings College (now Columbia University)
1 RESI
2 PLAC Westchester County, New York
1 REMV
2 DATE 1783
2 PLAC Saint John River, Nova Scotia (now New Brunswick)
2 SHIP Montague
1 OCCU Lawyer
1 REMV
2 DATE about 1806
2 PLAC New York, New York
1 DEAT
2 DATE 21 March 1820
2 PLAC New York City, New York
2 AGE about 83 to 85 years
1 DEAT
2 DATE 21 March 1820
2 PLAC New York, United States
2 TEXT d. New York, 21st ult., Timothy Wetmore, Esq., age 85, one of first two graduates of Columbia College.
2 SOUR Daniel Johnson, New Brunswick Newspaper Vital Statistics Volume 2 Number 841
3 CONT 5 April 1820, City Gazette, Saint John.
1 OBIT
2 TEXT DIED -- Yesterday morning, of a lingering illness, which he bore with
3 CONT christian resignation, Timothy Wetmore, Esq., in the 85th year of his age.
3 CONT Mr. Wetmore was one of the first two who graduated in Columbia College.
3 CONT His friends and relatives are respectfully invited to attend his funeral,
3 CONT at half-past 4 o'clock, from No. 307 Bowery, first house above First Street.
2 SOUR Quoted in "Ogden Family History in the Line of Benjamin Ogden of New York," Anna S. Vermilye.
1 SOUR @S1@
1 TEXT Timothy Wetmore
2 CONT Rye's first lawyer is said to have been Timothy Wetmore, who,
2 CONT it appears, was a man versatile and influential, and of many
2 CONT activities, his reputation extending throughout the county.
2 CONT While, perhaps, he may have been the first regularly licensed
2 CONT lawyer in the town, and doubtless was the first lawyer who
2 CONT lived in what is now the town of Rye, he, neverthe less, was
2 CONT preceded by several persons who became prominent in the law and
2 CONT identified with the county judiciary, such as John Thomas,
2 CONT Edward Thomas, William Willett, and Gilbert Willett, all of
2 CONT whom lived in that part of Rye township then known as
2 CONT Harrison's Purchase. Timothy Wetmore was a son of the Rev. James
2 CONT and Anna (Dwight) Wetmore. The Rev. James Wet- more was born
2 CONT at Middletown, Conn., December 31, 1695, and educated at
2 CONT Saybrook Academy and Yale University, receiving from the latter
2 CONT the degrees of A.B. and A. M. He was ordained in 1718, as first
2 CONT pastor of the Congregational Church of North Haven, Conn., and
2 CONT continued his labors there for about four years. Doubting the
2 CONT validity of his ordination, he resigned his charge, and, in 1723,
2 CONT went to England where he was ordained deacon and priest of the
2 CONT Church of England. He returned to America in 1726, and was
2 CONT inducted as rector of the parish of Rye, which then extended
2 CONT considerably beyond the present confines of the town. Here he
2 CONT remained until his death of the smallpox, May 15, 1760.
2 CONT His wife died February 28, 1771. Besides Timothy, their other
2 CONT children were James ; Alethea, wife of Rev. Joseph Lamson;
2 CONT Anna, wife of Gilbert Brundage; Charity, wife of Josiah Purdy;
2 CONT and Esther, who first married David Brown, and secondly Jesse
2 CONT Hunt, high sheriff of the county in 1780. It is said of the
2 CONT Rev. Mr. Wetmore that, such was his zeal for episcopacy, he once
2 CONT declared he would rather join in worship with a Jewish synagogue,
2 CONT than with a Presbyterian church. He must have been a man of no
2 CONT inconsiderable intellectual attainment, having published a
2 CONT letter against Dickinson in defense of Waterland's discourse
2 CONT on regeneration; a vindi cation of the professors of the Church
2 CONT of England in answer to Hobart's sermon in favor of Presbyterian
2 CONT ordination; a rejoinder to Hobart's serious address; an appendix
2 CONT to Beach's vindication, and other papers. Timothy Wetmore was
2 CONT born in Rye in or about the year 1736. He first studied for the
2 CONT ministry, but circumstances prevented his going to England for
2 CONT ordination. He was among the first graduates of Kings, now
2 CONT Columbia, College, in 1758. He subse quently studied law and was
2 CONT licensed to practice April 26, 1770. Mr. Wetmore first married
2 CONT October 21, 1756, Jane Haviland, of Rye. Of this marriage were
2 CONT born James, Jane, Anna, Timothy, Fletcher, Thomas, Luther,
2 CONT Theodore, and Robert Griffith. His second marriage was to Rachel,
2 CONT widow of Benjamin Ogden, of New York, of which marriage there
2 CONT was no issue. About 1753, he was appointed schoolmaster in
2 CONT Rye Parish by the Society for the Propagation of the Gospel in
2 CONT Foreign Parts, and continued to teach until 1769. In 1763,
2 CONT soon after the death of his father, he owned and was living in
2 CONT the Square House, now the municipal hall of Rye village, and
2 CONT which his father had owned and lived in. It is possi ble that
2 CONT Timothy Wetmore was born in this historic structure. By this
2 CONT time he had become a figure of com manding influence in the
2 CONT town. After his father's death, the Rye Parish was for some
2 CONT time without a rector. This was bitterly complained of by
2 CONT some of the people, and, on May 6, 1761, Timothy Wet- more
2 CONT addressed a letter to the secretary of the society, voicing
2 CONT his complaint of the lack of a minister and stating that he
2 CONT had assumed to read the services and administer the sacraments.
2 CONT In July, 1762, the Rev. Ebenezer Punderson, of New Haven, was
2 CONT called and commenced his labors. In November, 1764, a number
2 CONT of the inhabitants united in a pe tition to the lieutenant
2 CONT governor of the province asking incorporation of the parish.
2 CONT This petition, which was granted in the following month, contained
2 CONT the signatures of Timothy Wetmore and John Thomas, who afterward
2 CONT became bitter enemies. Troublous times were now upon the
2 CONT inhabitants of the town, a great many of whom, particularly
2 CONT those of the Established Church, sided with the Crown. Timothy
2 CONT Wetmore became a pronounced tory and joined with others, on
2 CONT September 14, 1774, in a declaration of loyalty, expressing
2 CONT their "great desire and full resolution to live and die
2 CONT peaceable subjects to our gracious sovereign, King George
2 CONT the Third, and his laws." In November, 1774, however, Mr.
2 CONT Wetmore issued a statement in which he explained and qualified
2 CONT his endorsement of the declaration of loyalty, but he still
2 CONT protested his loyalty to the King. It is related that a certain
2 CONT George Harris, who was also a school teacher in the town, in
2 CONT addressing a petition to the convention of New York State,
2 CONT in 1776, referred to Timothy Wetmore as "that arch Tory or enemy
2 CONT to his country, who has and does yet keep up the spirit of
2 CONT Toryism in Rye. " At the close of the war in 1783, Mr. Wetmore
2 CONT removed to the Province of New Brunswick, and at the opening
2 CONT of the supreme court in St. John, 1788, was admitted to the Bar.
2 CONT He settled at Gagetown, where he held a number of county offices.
2 CONT His son, Thomas, was admitted as attorney in 1788, and a
2 CONT copartnership between father and son was afterward formed.
2 CONT The following is a copy of the copartner ship notice:
2 CONT LAW OFF1CE At the house lately occupied by Mr. Fitzsimon,
2 CONT King Street, St. John, where constant attendance will be given.
2 CONT Having also an office at Fredericton, the seat of the Government,
2 CONT they will have it in their power to transact business with the
2 CONT utmost dispatch the rules of government will admit.
2 CONT T1MOTHY WETMORE,
2 CONT THOMAS WETMORE.
2 CONT 16th July, 1793.
2 CONT In 1800, Timothy Wetmore returned to New York, where he took up
2 CONT his residence. He died there in March, 1820, in the eighty-fifth
2 CONT year of his age. It would be interesting to speculate upon what,
2 CONT if any, controversies took place between Timothy Wet- more, the
2 CONT Tory, and John Jay, the Patriot, who both at one time lived in
2 CONT the town of Rye, and who must have been thrown in frequent contact
2 CONT with each other.

1 DEAT
2 DATE between 26 August 1742 and 28 June 1743
3 INFO between will codicil and inventory
2 PLAC Middletown, Connecticut
1 DEAT
2 DATE about 1742/3, 1743, about 1743
2 PLAC Middletown, Connecticut
1 WILL
2 NAME Israhiah Wetmore
2 DATE 26 March 1741
2 PLAC Middletown, Connecticut
2 TEXT The Last Will and Testament of Israhiah Wetmore
3 CONT I, Israhiah Wetmore of Middletown, in the County of Hartford, do
3 CONT make this my last will and testament:  I give to my beloved wife
3 CONT Hannah the improvement of so much of my dwelling house as she
3 CONT shall have occasion for during her continuance there, and also a
3 CONT comfortable maintenance during her continuance under my roof, to
3 CONT be performed by my executor after named;  but if she shall see
3 CONT cause to remove from under my roof, then my will is that she
3 CONT shall have a bed, bedding and furniture that we usually lodged
3 CONT on, and also the chest and box that she brought with her, with
3 CONT the lining and other things therein, and also half the pewter,
3 CONT brass and iron and other moveables that she brought with her, to
3 CONT be to her and her heirs forever.  And further, my will is that
3 CONT in case she departs from my house, my executor shall pay her #3
3 CONT per annum so long as she remains my widow.  And whereas it has
3 CONT pleased the sovereign God to smite her with the numb palsy,
3 CONT under which difficulty she now labors, whereby an extraordinary
3 CONT charge is brought upon my son Josiah for her support and
3 CONT comfort, my will is that the 50 shillings per annum that my son
3 CONT Seth and Jeremiah promised to give me when I gave them deeds of
3 CONT land (of which I have received none) shall be paid to Josiah,
3 CONT and what that falls short of paying the extraordinary charge he
3 CONT shall be at in paying doctors, nurses, etc., for my wife, shall
3 CONT be paid out of my moveable estate before any distribution
3 CONT thereof be made.  To my son Israhiah's heirs I give and bequeath
3 CONT what I gave their father by deed of gift, and also 1/6 part of
3 CONT my lott in the third division of land on the east side of the
3 CONT Great River;  this I give them and their heirs forever.  To my
3 CONT son James Wetmore I give and bequeath, besides what I have
3 CONT already given him, 1/6 part of my lott in the third division of
3 CONT land on the east side of the Great River.  To my son Seth
3 CONT Wetmore, besides what I have already given him, I give and
3 CONT bequeath 1/6 part of my lott in the third division on the east
3 CONT side of the Great River.  And also, on consideration of the
3 CONT lawsuit he maintained against Hope Hawley, I give him 1 equal
3 CONT half of my lott called the new lott; but in case he sells it, my
3 CONT will is that Josiah can have the refusal of it.  I give to my
3 CONT son Jeremiah, besides what I have already given him, my bond
3 CONT lott on the east side of the Great River; also 1/6 part of my
3 CONT lott in the third division of lands there.  I give to my son
3 CONT Caleb, besides what I have already given him, 1/6 part of my
3 CONT lott in the third division of land on the east side of the Great
3 CONT River; also 1/4 and 1/2 quarter of my interest in the sawmill
3 CONT and half the land adjoining.  I give to my son Josiah Wetmore
3 CONT the remainder of my homelott after Seth and Jeremiah hath
3 CONT measured off to them what I gave them by deed, together with all
3 CONT the buildings standing thereon;  and also the whole of my two
3 CONT meadow lots, viz., my lott just within the meadow gate and that
3 CONT near the Ferry River; and also the equal half of my lott called
3 CONT the new lott; and also my pasture at Indian Hill; and also 1/6
3 CONT part of my lott in the third division of land on the east side
3 CONT of the Great River; 1 and 1/2 quarter of my interest in the
3 CONT sawmill, also 1/2 of the land adjoining.  Also, I give him all
3 CONT my husbandry tools and carpentry tools and tackling of what name
3 CONT soever, obliging him to pay all my just debts, funeral charges,
3 CONT and legacies to my wife, except the extraordinary charge of my
3 CONT wife's illness, for which I have made some provisions in this
3 CONT will.  And I do hereby order him to pay to Sara, the wife of
3 CONT Daniel Prior, Jr., #5 money within one year after my decease.
3 CONT I give to my grandson Israhiah Wetmore 1/4 of my interest in the
3 CONT sawmill.  And further, my will is that what shall remain of my
3 CONT moveable estate (two notes under Josiah's hands: the one dated
3 CONT 15 April, 1736, for the sum of #60 money, the other dated 9 May,
3 CONT 1737, for the sum of #30 money, and my stock in Josiah's hands,
3 CONT viz: two oxen, two cows, one horse valued at #10, two swine and
3 CONT 15 sheep) shall be equally divided among my sons, accounting
3 CONT Israhiah's heirs in his stead.  And I appoint my son Josiah to
3 CONT be sole executor to this my last will, and desire Mr. Jabez
3 CONT Hamlin to be overseer.
2 SIGN Israhiah X Wetmore, ls.
2 WITN Henry King
2 WITN Ebenezer Sage
2 WITN Charles Hamlin.
2 SOUR Early Connecticut Probate Records
3 PAGE 475 to 477 [assume the published version]
3 PAGE 87 to 89 [assume from the original register]
3 FROM Woody; from Middlesex Historical Society.
1 CODL Codicil
2 DATE 26 August 1742
2 TEXT I, Israhiah Wetmore, before named testator, being at this time
3 CONT (through the goodness of God) of sound and disposing memory,
3 CONT and observing a disposition in my grandson Israhiah Wetmore
3 CONT before named to learning, and considering the disadvantage that
3 CONT it will be to the sawmill to be sub-divided into so small
3 CONT rights, do see cause to make this following alteration in my
3 CONT before going will.  Whereas, I have given to my grandson
3 CONT Israhiah Wetmore 1/4 of my interest in the sawmill and yard, my
3 CONT will now is that the sd. 1/4 belong to my two sons, Caleb and
3 CONT Josiah; and I do now give unto my two sons, Caleb and Josiah,
3 CONT and their heirs forever, equal parts in the sd. quarter of my
3 CONT interest in the sawmill and yard, they paying unto my grandson
3 CONT Israhiah Wetmore each #8 money, which is #16 in the whole,
3 CONT within a reasonable time after my decease, to help him forward
3 CONT in his learning.  And this alteration is agreeable to my mind
3 CONT and will, and is a part thereof.
2 SIGN Israhiah X Wetmore, ls.
2 WITN Henry King
2 WITN Ebenezer Sage
2 WITN Charles Hamlin.
2 SOUR Early Connecticut Probate Records
3 PAGE 475 to 477 [assume the published version]
3 PAGE 87 to 89 [assume from the original register]
3 FROM Woody; from Middlesex Historical Society.

1 NOTE I have accepted that two George H Wetmores were born in
2 CONT Norwich, Connecticut, in 1862, one a son of George C Wetmore
2 CONT (the one recorded here), and the other a son of Joseph C
2 CONT Wetmore.
2 CONT Note that the son of George C Wetmore was not named on his
2 CONT birth record in Norwich, whereas the son of Joseph C Wetmore
2 CONT was.
2 CONT If the death record shown here is correct, then the unnamed son
2 CONT of George C Wetmore was this George H Wetmore.
2 CONT Until proven otherwise I will consider this to be true.
1 OBIT
2 TEXT DEATH OF GEORGE WETMORE
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Former Resident of Norwich and Member of Local Fire Department.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT George Wetmore, died Tuesday at the residence of Zebediah Noyes, in Vauxhall street.
2 TEXT The cause of his death is assigned as acute Bright's disease.
2 TEXT He was a native of Norwich, 40 years of age and for 20 years a resident of this city.
2 TEXT Mr. Wetmore has been for a long period employed by the Perry Ice Co.
2 TEXT He was a member of the W. B. Thomas Hose Co., and that organization will hold a special
2 TEXT meeting this evening to take action on his death.
2 TEXT Mr. Wetmore has been boarding for some time on Bayonet street, but was calling at the
2 TEXT Noyes house when taken sick.
2 SOUR New London "Day", February 11, 1903
2 DATE 11 February 1903

1 NOTE There is lack of certainty here.
1 NOTE There was definitely a daughter of Charles D Barnes born 12
2 CONT April 1867; she had no name on her birth record.
1 NOTE Her mother is listed as Mary Ann Barnes on the birth record;
2 CONT I assume that this is Mariette Daniels.
1 NOTE Shirley Mitsko cannot place an Irene Barnes that she believes
2 CONT to belong in this family.
1 NOTE For the time being, I will consider Irene Barnes and this baby
2 CONT girl one in the same person.

0 @I275@ INDI
1 NAME William /Wetmore/
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE 31 August 1772
2 PLAC Rye, Westchester County, New York, United States
2 SOUR JCW
1 NOTE He removed to New Brunswick with his father in 1783 where he
2 CONT resided.
2 SOUR JCW
1 NOTE William Wetmore came to Springfield parish about 1818 to his
2 CONT grant of land at Hatfield Point.
2 CONT This piece of land was a leftover strip that Captain Thomas
2 CONT Spragg wanted the Governor to set aside for a school lot and
2 CONT a church glebe in 1798(?), but this was later given to
2 CONT William Wetmore for a farm.
2 CONT A grandson of his was also later granted another leftover
2 CONT piece of land to the eastward of William Wetmore's place.
2 CONT William Wetmore's grant was between the Belleish[?] bay lots
2 CONT and the Spragg grants in what is now called the "Grant" and
2 CONT is now abandoned farms.
2 SOUR notes from Kings Co. Hist. Soc.

1 DEAT
2 DATE 1873
2 SOUR 21pp
1 TEXT Resides in Clifton, Kings co., N.B.
2 CONT In early life was extensively engaged in ship building.
2 CONT Served for many years in the military service of the
2 CONT province, holding the several offices in succession from a
2 CONT cornet to major commanding 1st battalion Kings co. militia,
2 CONT which latter office he still holds.
2 CONT About 1850, was appointed one of the justices of the Common
2 CONT Pleas Court of Kings co.
2 SOUR JCW, pg 251
1 TEXT Justus Sherwood, "Boss Wetmore," famous shipbuilder and
2 CONT contractor of Kingston parish.
2 CONT Built Gondola Point Church.
2 CONT (Erected tombstone to James W. in this graveyard, French
2 CONT Village).
2 CONT Major militia, judge of common pleas, married his cousin,
2 CONT Esther Wetmore;
2 SOUR genealogical newspaper clipping

0 @I393@ INDI
1 NAME Escott Oliver /Smith/
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE 20 November 1925
2 PLAC New London, New London, Connecticut, United States
2 SOUR Thomas T. Wetmore III
1 DEAT
2 DATE 8 October 2015
2 PLAC Waterford, New London, Connecticut, United States
1 OBIT
2 DATE 11 October 2015
2 NEWS New London Day
2 TEXT Waterford - Escott Oliver Smith, 89, passed away on Oct. 8, 2015.
2 TEXT He was born on Nov. 25, 1926, in New London, to Alida (Armstrong) Smith and Clyde Raymond Smith Sr.
2 TEXT Escott married Phyllis Baker on Aug. 18, 1951, in Northampton, Mass.
2 TEXT He is survived by his wife, Phyllis; his son, Escott II; and daughters, Kristin Wallach and Pamela Marino.
2 TEXT He also has six grandchildren, Escott III and Hannah Smith, Elicia Wallach, Hubach and Kylen Wallach,
2 TEXT and Jake and Tatum Marino; as well as a large extended family of great-nieces, great-nephews, and cousins.
2 TEXT Escott was in the U.S. Navy and later graduated from Springfield College and received his master of
2 TEXT arts degree from Columbia Teacher's College.
2 TEXT He spent many years on his continuing education, culminating in many professional certifications.
2 TEXT Escott worked in the education system as a teacher in Tolland, a guidance counselor in Waterford,
2 TEXT and later in New London as a teacher, guidance counselor and school psychologist.
2 TEXT He was involved in a number of activities including tennis, biking, golf, skiing, playing piano,
2 TEXT and woodworking, continuing most of these well into his 80s.
2 TEXT Escott and his wife Phyllis raised their three children in Waterford, and since retiring have spent their
2 TEXT years traveling the world and enjoying their wonderful seaside location on the Waterford coast.
2 TEXT He and his wife personally built their home in Waterford and their ski cabin in Vermont.
2 TEXT Calling hours are from 4 to 6 p.m. Tuesday, Oct. 13, at Byles Memorial Home, 99 Huntington St., New London.
2 TEXT A private graveside ceremony will be held for the family on Wednesday, Oct. 14, with a reception for all
2 TEXT who would like to attend from 1 to 3 p.m. at Langley's Restaurant, Lamphere Road, Waterford.
2 TEXT In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Community Foundation of Eastern Connecticut Funds,
2 TEXT The Child and Family Agency of Southeastern CT, Visiting Nurse Association of SECT, and
2 TEXT The Center: A Drop-In Learning and Resource Center (www.cfect.org), or
2 TEXT the Bulkeley Alumni Fund, PO Box 1, New London, CT 06320.

1 NOTE Jan was possibly also known as Jan Fish or Jan Grendafish.
1 NOTE Jan served in the German army; he lived in the west of Poland near
2 CONT the German border in a town with a name (from Anthonhy Grenda)
2 CONT something like Ostrovnibrinsk); he deserted from German army after
2 CONT altercation with a German officer (he was ordered to stop reading
2 CONT a Polish newspaper; he refused; the officer pulled a knife; Jan
2 CONT took it and cut or stabbed the officer.
2 SOUR family tradition
1 NOTE Jan came to the U.S. first (port of exit and entry unknown), and
2 CONT Theofila and Frances followed (port of entry Philadelphia).
1 NOTE German soldiers came looking for Jan at his home;
2 CONT he may have been serving or living in Westfalen at the time.
1 NOTE Jan was a farmer in Poland, and was a coal miner in the
2 CONT Pittsburgh area.
1 NOTE Jan had a brother, Frank, who settled in New York, he came to U.S.
2 CONT later than Jan.
1 NOTE By one account Jan and Theofila had had 12 children when they
2 CONT left Poland; Frances was the only child still alive (this doesn't
2 CONT seem plausible).
1 NOTE He was a sharpshooter instructor in the German army.
1 NOTE He may have lived near the German/Polish border; may have been in
2 CONT Westphalen at time of emigration; may have lived in town with a
2 CONT name like Ostrava.

0 @I552@ INDI
1 NAME Antoinette/Schroeffel/
1 SEX F
1 NOTE Sister Aelred, Order of Saint Francis.
1 BIRT
2 DATE 10 October 1910
1 ALIV
2 DATE 10 October 2010
2 SOUR Clipping in newspaper mentioned her 100th birthday.
1 DEAT
2 DATE 23 June 2014
2 PLAC Millvale, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, United States
1 OBIT Sister Aelred Schroeffel, OSF, 103, of Millvale, died Monday, June 23, 2014.
2 CONT She was a daughter of the late Anthony and Anna Schroeffel;
2 CONT and sister of the late Anthony, Joseph and Louis Schroeffel, Gertrude Collins, Helen Schroeffel,
2 CONT Margaret Grenda, Elizabeth Schroeffel and Celine Heimbuecher.
2 CONT Sister entered the Sisters of St. Francis in 1927.
2 CONT For most of her years in community, she was a high school teacher excelling in the teaching of science.
2 CONT For several years during summer breaks, she taught at Duquesne University,
2 CONT as well as St. Francis Hospital in Pittsburgh, where she instructed inhalation therapy students
2 CONT in chemistry and physics.
2 CONT Her love and interest in her pupils was well known because, up to her death,
2 CONT many of them still kept in contact through visits and the writing of letters or cards.
2 CONT During her stay in the community's health care unit, sister endeared herself in a special
2 CONT way to the nurses and aides who tended to her by her display of humor, prayerfulness
2 CONT and genuine concern for others.
2 CONT At the age of 103, she left a legacy that few will forget.
2 CONT Visitation from 2 to 7 p.m. Tuesday at the Mt. Alvernia Motherhouse Chapel,
2 CONT 146 Hawthorne Road, Millvale, where funeral Mass will be at 11 a.m. Wednesday.
2 CONT Memorial contributions may be made to the Sisters of St. Francis Ministry,
2 CONT Formation or Retirement Fund, 146 Hawthorne Road, Pittsburgh, PA 15209.
2 CONT Professional services entrusted to D'ALESSANDRO FUNERAL HOME and CREMATORY LTD.,
2 CONT Lawrenceville. http://www.dalessandroltd.com.

2 CONT James Colburn, of Lunenburg, on 12 August 1742, not marrying

2 CONT Topsfield.

1 FAMC @F143@
0 @I687@ INDI
1 NAME Timothy Fletcher /Wetmore/
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE 3 October 1764
2 PLAC Rye, Westchester County, New York
2 SOUR JCW
1 NOTE He was christened by Mr. Seabury of Jamaica.
2 SOUR JCW
1 DEAT
2 DATE January 1799
1 NOTE letter written about Timothy
2 TEXT Your uncle Timothy F. Wetmore, studied Physic with Dr. Seabury
3 CONT (who was afterwards Bishop of Connecticut and Rhode Island),
3 CONT and practiced Physic a number of years in New Brunswick; he
3 CONT came to New York in 1793, attended the lectures of Columbia
3 CONT College for 3 years, wrote and published a dissertation on
3 CONT Puerperal Fever, and took the degree of M.D. with honor, but
3 CONT poor dissapointed soul, he was cut off in his youth, and in the
3 CONT most promising part of life, like many of his fellow mortals.
3 CONT He died in Jan., 1799; he was a dear brother to me; his manners
3 CONT were pleasing and gentlemanly, and he was no less esteemed for
3 CONT his respect of religion than skill in his profession.
2 SOUR letter from Rev. Robert Griffith Wetmore, Timothy's brother, to
3 CONT Robert's daughter, Jane, quoted in JCW
1 FAMC @F143@
0 @I688@ INDI
1 NAME Thomas/Wetmore/
1 SEX M
1 TITL Judge
1 BIRT
2 DATE 20 September 1767
2 PLAC Rye, Westchester County, New York
1 CHR
2 DATE 25 October 1767
2 BY Reverend Ephraim Avery
1 EVEN appointed Attorney General of New Brunswick, Canada
2 DATE 26 July 1809
1 DEAT
2 DATE 22 March 1828
1 SOUR @S1@
1 TEXT Thomas Wetmore was born in the town of Rye, September 20, 1767.
2 CONT He was the son of Timothy Wetmore, who has been credited with being
2 CONT Rye's first lawyer, and Jane Haviland Wetmore.
2 CONT
2 CONT Thomas Wetmore removed with his father, at the close of the
2 CONT Revolutionary War, to the province of New Brunswick, and after
2 CONT studying law in the office of Ward Chipman, one of the most
2 CONT prominent lawyers of the province, was admitted as an attorney
2 CONT in the year 1788.
2 CONT In 1793, he and his father formed a copartnership, and engaged
2 CONT in the practice of law at St. John, maintaining an office at
2 CONT Fredericton, which was then the seat of the government.
2 CONT Mr. Wetmore was recorder for the city of St. John in 1809-1810,
2 CONT and attorney-general of the province 1809-28.
2 CONT
2 CONT We are indebted to the Hon. J. B. M. Baxter, until lately
2 CONT attorney-general for the province of New Brunswick, for much
2 CONT information concerning both Timothy Wetmore and Thomas Wetmore.
2 CONT In "Judges of New Brunswick and Their Times," a copy of which
2 CONT has been presented to us by the Hon. Mr. Baxter, there
2 CONT appears the following:
2 CONT
2 CONT "Thomas Wetmore, in 1793, married, at Gagetown, a daughter of
2 CONT James Peters, and on the death of Colin Campbell, in 1796, was
2 CONT appointed Clerk of the Crown of the Supreme Court.
2 CONT The year 1809 was a red-letter one to Thomas Wetmore, as on the
2 CONT appointment in that year of Ward Chipman to the Bench,
2 CONT he succeeded to the recordership of St. John, and on the
2 CONT appointment of Jonathan Bliss as Chief Justice, he succeeded
2 CONT to the office of Attorney-General, and was elected as one of
2 CONT the members of the Legislature for the City of St. John.
2 CONT Shortly afterwards, Mr. Wetmore removed with his family to
2 CONT York County. His daughter Margaret married Thomas Carleton Lee,
2 CONT and another daughter, Ann Peters, married Dr. John Head;
2 CONT the latter died at an early age, leaving a daughter, who
2 CONT subsequently became the wife of the Rev. Canon Ketchum, Rector of
2 CONT St. Andrews; Sarah married George Pidgeon Bliss; Susan,
2 CONT George J. Dibblee; and Emma, John Bedell.
2 CONT
2 CONT "There were four sons, George Ludlow Wetmore, father of the
2 CONT Honorable A. Rainsford Wetmore, a puisne Judge of the Supreme
2 CONT Court of New Brunswick, and Charles P. Wetmore, for nearly fifty
2 CONT years Clerk of the House of Assembly, who died at Fredericton
2 CONT in 1883, in his 86th year,  the latter's son, E. L. Wetmore, is a
2 CONT judge in the Province of Saskatchewan, Canada.
2 CONT Timothy R. Wetmore, the third son, held an important office in
2 CONT Queens County; he died at Gagetown in 1883, aged 82 years;
2 CONT a daughter married the Honorable D. L. Hanington, a Judge of the
2 CONT Supreme Court of New Brunswick; Thomas, the youngest son, followed
2 CONT the medical profession, and in 1840 married a daughter of the
2 CONT Honorable F. Robinson, Auditor-General, who died at Fredericton.
2 CONT Attorney-General Thomas Wetmore has been described as a man eminently
2 CONT distinguished for his talents, benevolence, and hospitality.
2 CONT His hand was always open to the poor, and he was a friend to all.
2 CONT As a lawyer and advocate, he stood high in his profession.
2 CONT He died at his residence, Kingswood, York County, March 22, 1828,
2 CONT aged 62 years."
2 CONT
2 CONT Thomas Wetmore seems also to have been promi nent in Masonic circles,
2 CONT reference being made to him in Bunting's History of Freemasonry in
2 CONT New Bruns wick, showing that on September 28, 1816, acting as Grand Master,
2 CONT he laid the corner stone of the Ma sonic hall in St. John.
1 FAMC @F143@
1 FAMS @F605@
0 @I689@ INDI

1 SEX F
1 BIRT

0 @I709@ INDI
1 NAME Thomas James /Wetmore/
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE 13 May 1848
2 PLAC Woodstock, Yarmouth County, Nova Scotia, Canada
1 DEAT
2 DATE 29 March 1939
2 AGE nearly 90 years
2 PLAC Richmond, Nova Scotia, Canada
1 OBIT Thomas James Wetmore, one of Yarmouth Co. oldest residents,
2 CONT passed away on Thursday, March 29, 1938, at the home of his
2 CONT grandson Edgar Crosby, Richmond.
2 CONT The deceased would have been ninety had he lived until May
2 CONT 13.
2 CONT Most of his life was spent in Richmond.
2 CONT He was born at Woodstock, Yarmouth Co.
2 CONT Since January he had been in failing health, having suffered
2 CONT a slight shock, and his death, although sudden was not
2 CONT entirely unexpected.
2 CONT His wife the former Sarah A. Goudy of Yar. predeceased him 26
2 CONT years ago.
2 CONT The deceased is survived by three daughters; Mrs. George
2 CONT Killiam, Mrs. Horton Crosby, both of Richmond; Mrs. Frank
2 CONT Rollin, West Farmington, Me.
2 CONT One son Staley G. Wetmore of Dryden, Maine.
2 CONT A sister Mrs. Elizabeth Porter of Woodstock; two brothers,
2 CONT John of Boston, and Charles of Orange, Mass.
2 CONT Also surviving are 18 grandchildren and 9 great
2 CONT grandchildren.
2 CONT Funeral services were held on Friday afternoon in the Bay
2 CONT View United Baptist Church, Port Maitland, of which he was a
2 CONT member.
2 CONT Interment was made at Island Cemetery, Port Maitland.
1 SOUR notes from B. Churchill

1 NAME Thomas/Whitmore/
1 NAME Thomas/Whitmore/Sr
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE about 1615
2 PLAC west of England
2 SOUR @S1@
3 NOTE unsubstantiated
1 ARRV
2 DATE 1635
2 AGE 20 years
2 FROM west England, embarked from Bristol
2 TO Boston, Massachusetts
2 SOUR @S1@
3 CONT family tradition, unsubstantiated
1 NOTE In a genealogical record written by Judge William Wetmore of Boston
2 CONT in 1792 for the use Rev. Robert Griffeth Wetmore is the
2 CONT statement, "He [Thomas Whitmore] came to Hartford from the west of
2 CONT England, as his grandson Beriah told my father, who informed me,
2 CONT in 1635, when he was twenty years old."
2 SOUR @S1@
1 LAND
2 DATE 1639/40

2 NOTE recorded as owner of certain lands
2 SOUR @S1@

3 CONT Whitmore.

1 WILL
2 NAME Thomas Whitmore Senior
2 DATE 20 July 1681
2 AGE about 66 years
2 CHIL
3 NAME John Whitmore
3 AGE 36 years
2 CHIL
3 NAME Elizabeth Whitmore
3 AGE 32 years

3 NAME Mary Whitmore
3 AGE 31 years

3 NAME Thomas Whitmore
3 AGE 29 years

3 NAME Hannah Whitmore

3 NAME Samuel Whitmore
3 AGE 26 years
2 CHIL
3 NAME Jzrahiah Whitmore
3 AGE 25 years
2 CHIL
3 NAME Berriah Whitmore
3 AGE 23 years
2 CHIL
3 NAME Nathaniel Whitmore
3 AGE 20 years
2 CHIL
3 NAME Sarah Whitmore
3 AGE 17 years
2 CHIL
3 NAME Joseph Whitmore
3 AGE 18 years
2 CHIL
3 NAME Josia Whitmore
3 AGE 13 years
2 CHIL
3 NAME Mehetable Whitmore
3 AGE 13 years
2 CHIL
3 NAME Benjamin Whitmore
3 AGE 7 years
2 CHIL
3 NAME Abigail Whitmore
3 AGE 3 years
2 CHIL
3 NAME Hannah Whitmore junior
3 AGE 1 year
2 SOUR @S1@
1 WILL
2 TEXT The Last Will and Testament of Thomas Whitmore Senior, aged about
3 CONT sixty and six years, being at present under some considerable
3 CONT weakness of body, yet having through ye mercy of God,
3 CONT ye comfortable use of my understanding as formerly, is as
3 CONT followeth:
3 CONT
3 CONT After committing my soul to God as to a faithful creator, and my
3 CONT body to a decent burial, I doe here leave this as my last Will
3 CONT and testament for the disposal of that portion of worldly estate
3 CONT Which God hath given me, amongst these my children and relations
3 CONT which I shall leave behind me as followeth:
3 CONT
3 CONT Imprimis.  I give to my son John Whitmore a part of my lot in ye
3 CONT boggy meadow quarter.  That is twenty rods wide of yt part of ye
3 CONT land Within the fence that now is to lie on ye south west side
3 CONT that lot, and to go from yt fence as far east as my land goeth,
3 CONT Moreover I give to my said son three quarters of my great lott
3 CONT that lyeth westward from the town, to take the whole breadth,
3 CONT half ye length, beginning at ye farther end and likewise the
3 CONT half ye breaadth of ye other half next ye town and to take it
3 CONT on ye North Side.  And my Will is yt my son Berriah shall have
3 CONT the other half of that part next the Town.  Moreover it is my
3 CONT will yt my said son John shall have all my proportion and
3 CONT interest in the three mile lott on the east side of ye great
3 CONT river, that is the farther three miles on yt side eastward,
3 CONT Moreover I give to my said son a part of my meadow at Wauggunk
3 CONT being that piece which lying athwart east and west and from the
3 CONT north side of yt on the east of my meadow to Deacon Allyns meadow.
3 CONT
3 CONT It.  I give to my son Thos Whitmore my long meadow lott lying on
3 CONT the north side, Moreover I give to my said son Thomas half my
3 CONT lott at Longerchunk and the other half to my daughter Hanna Stow
3 CONT to be equally divided between them as they shall agree or if
3 CONT they agree not, as indifferent men which they shall choose shall
3 CONT judge equal.
3 CONT
3 CONT It.  I give my son Samuel Whitmore a parcell of land on ye North
3 CONT Side of ye three Mile River which I bought from Goodman Savage
3 CONT by exchange of land being about ten acres lying at ye west End
3 CONT Goodman Savage's lott, only Reserving fourteen acres of yt land
3 CONT for my Daughter ____ if she survives me, Moreover I give my said
3 CONT Son two acreas of meadow lying in ye farther neck; and a piece
3 CONT of swamp in the Round meadow swamp being one acre and sixteen
3 CONT rods lying between Capt Harris's swamp and swamp which was Thos
3 CONT Hubbards.  Moreover I give my said son Round Meadow lott being
3 CONT near six acres only Reserving and Willing a third part of it
3 CONT for my daughter Abigaill if she survive me or else to Remain to
3 CONT Samuel.
3 CONT
3 CONT It.  I give to my son Jzrahiah Whitmore my upland lott, on the
3 CONT east side of the Great River being about twenty and two acres
3 CONT lying the ye half mile lott, as also a piece of meadow at
3 CONT Wauggunk adjoining to his Brother John's line from John's North
3 CONT to a piece of meadow we call Flee Meadow, as also four acres in
3 CONT ye pond on the east side ye great River between Ensign Cheeny
3 CONT and Mr Nathaniel Collin's meadow.  I give my said son one
3 CONT parcell of land in ye last half mile division on ye east side
3 CONT the Great River, that is all I have in yt division on yt side.
3 CONT
3 CONT It.  I give my son Berriah Whitmore that piece of meadow at
3 CONT Waugunk called ye Flee Meadow, and it is my will herein that my
3 CONT sons yt have meadows there, shall all of them allow each other a
3 CONT lane highway, as shall be needful to come to their land there.
3 CONT Moreover I give to my said son yt parcell of upland in my
3 CONT westermost lott by his brother John's as above specified.
3 CONT Moreover I give to my said son one acre of my home lott next the
3 CONT Great River, on this condition that he come settle upon it but if
3 CONT not he shall not have it, but it shall remain to the lott for
3 CONT them I shall appoint that lott to, On further consideration, I
3 CONT see not cause to give my said son that acre of my house lott.
3 CONT
3 CONT It.  I give to my son Nathaniel Whitmore half my land in the
3 CONT boggy meadow quarter of that which lyeth without the fence as it
3 CONT now standeth, and the other half to my son Joseph Whitmore
3 CONT Northward to be on the north Side that land and Joseph on the
3 CONT south side, and the other part within ye fence which is not
3 CONT disposed of to John Whitmore, I give to Nathaniel and Joseph to
3 CONT be delivered equally between them.  Nathaniel on the north side,
3 CONT and Joseph next John, and it is my will herein to reserve a
3 CONT piece of land in Nathaniels part of the two acres which lieth
3 CONT within the compass of ye swamp, to be for my wife, as long as
3 CONT she liveth, and in order hereunto I do appoint & it is my will
3 CONT herein, that John and Nathaniel and Joseph, shall clear and
3 CONT break up that to fit it for improvement, Moreover I give to my
3 CONT said Sons Nathaniel and Joseph part of my boggy meadows, That
3 CONT is all the Westermost end coming down to the head of John Stow's
3 CONT answering the Crook of the River, and I do herein engage on yt I
3 CONT doe interest in yt meadow not to hinder each other for water
3 CONT courses through ye land, where shall be for ye good of ye whole.
3 CONT
3 CONT It.  I give to my Daughter Sarah Whitmore & my son Josia
3 CONT Whitmore & my Daughter Mehetable, my great lott at the Straits
3 CONT Hills to be equally divided among them three, Sarah first, and
3 CONT Josia next and Mehetable last from ye homeward side.
3 CONT
3 CONT It.  I give Katheren my loving wife the rest of my home lott,
3 CONT with all the housing thereon, during her natural life as also,
3 CONT the one half of my long meadow on the south side of yt lott and
3 CONT a parcell of land which I have at Paschoug on the east side the
3 CONT Great River, and the remainder of my boggy meadow to be devided
3 CONT between my wife aned my son Thomas, and after my wife's decease,
3 CONT my will is that my son Thomas shall possess as his own.  My home
3 CONT lott, that is all but that disposed of and the other half of my
3 CONT long meadow & also my land at Pascouchoug.  Moreover I give to
3 CONT my loving wife my field lott during her natural life or until
3 CONT Benjamin fulfill the age of twenty-one years and then it shall
3 CONT be settled on him as his, Moreover as I received of my wife
3 CONT Katheren twenty pounds of her estate, six pounds whereof I have
3 CONT already paid her, yet I appoint and my will is that twenty be
3 CONT paid her out of my estate in household stuff and stock, so as
3 CONT may be most convenient to her and not hurtful to ye estate.
3 CONT Moreover I give to my loving wife two Cows, the two Cows to be a
3 CONT part of the twenty pounds above specified.
3 CONT
3 CONT It.  I give to my Daughters Sarah, Mehetable, Abigaill and Hanna
3 CONT junior, six pounds apiece out of my estate & to this my youngest
3 CONT daughter Hanna one piece of land of twenty acres lying near the
3 CONT straits on the west side of the Great River.  To my other three
3 CONT daughters I give ten shillings a piece as a Remembrance of me,
3 CONT they being already disposed of and provided for.
3 CONT
3 CONT Further, I give Thomas and Joseph my Carpentering tools between
3 CONT them.  Moreover it is my will to leave my loving wife and my son
3 CONT John my sole Executors of this my last will and testament,
3 CONT appointing yt when my just debts are paid out ye estate and ye
3 CONT legacies likewise paid also, if then, the Estate arise to leave
3 CONT anything more my will is that my Executors shall have the one
3 CONT half of that as theirs, and the other to be devided equally, to
3 CONT my children which are yet unnmarried to be paid to them at their
3 CONT mothers death, or at her marriage if she marry again.
3 CONT
3 CONT Further it is my will that my son Thomas at my decease shall
3 CONT enjoy one acre of my home lott next the great river for his
3 CONT present use with the housings that are there upon it, and I
3 CONT intend herein and it is my will that my son Thomas, shall take
3 CONT care of the orchard to look after it, and that his mother and he
3 CONT shall part the fruit as they shall agree, as also Thomas shall
3 CONT have the liberty to make use of a part of the barne for his own
3 CONT use and this is my full intent in this My last Will and Testament,
3 CONT I testify by seting to my hand and fixing my seal July 20th 1681.
3 CONT
3 CONT Thomas Whitmore Senior, seald.
3 CONT
3 CONT Signed sealed and delivered in presence of us Deacon Samuel
3 CONT Stocking, John Hall, Senior
3 CONT
3 CONT I all request my loving and trusty Friends, Deacon Samuel
3 CONT Stocking and my brother John Hall to answer to this my last
3 CONT will, to lend their help and advise to the performance thereof
3 CONT as need shall be.
2 NOTE The names of his children are recorded in the Probate office at
3 CONT Hartford, immediately after the will, and their ages are annexed.
1 DEAT
2 DATE 11 December 1681
2 AGE 66 years
2 PLAC Middletown, Connecticut
2 SOUR @S1@
1 DEAT
2 DATE 11 December 1681
2 PLAC Middletown, Connecticut
2 SOUR Records of Middletown, Vol. 1
1 TEXT Thomas Whitmore was the progenitor of the Wetmore family in
2 CONT North America.
2 CONT He was probably born in 1615, possibly in the west of England.
2 CONT No definite record of his birth has been found.

1 INFO I have a record that says he resided in Middletown from 1645.
1 NOTE Samuel preached at Middletown, Connecticut, after graduating
2 CONT from Harvard College.

2 CONT and only preacher in Middletown until 1668.
2 CONT He graduated from Harvard College in 1645 where he had
2 CONT studied for the ministry.
2 CONT He soon became the pastor of the orthodox congregational
2 CONT society of Middletown.

1 NAME Ebenezer /Porter/
1 SEX M
1 NOTE He was a Loyalist from Massachusetts.
2 SOUR EAD
1 NOTE He was a grantee of land on Sissiboo River, Digby County,
2 CONT Nova Scotia, on 5 March 1791.
2 SOUR IWW
1 INFO The following records are from the vital records of
2 CONT Massachusetts Towns, collected in an attempt to identify
2 CONT this Ebenezer Porter.
1 INFO From Taunton, Mass VRs:
2 LINE Ebenezer Porter [or Foster] married Bethia Crossman, both
3 CONT of Taunton, 20 Dec 1763
1 INFO From Ipswich, Mass VRs:
2 LINE Ebenezer Porter m Lydia Cummins, 17 Dec 1755
2 LINE Ebenezer, twin son of Nehemiah and Hannah Porter, b 16 Jul
3 CONT 1732
2 LINE Ebenezer, son Ebenezer and Lidia Porter, b 22 May 1758
2 LINE Ebenezer, son Nehemiah and Rebekah Porter, bap 22 Oct 1758
1 INFO From Wenham, Mass VRs:
2 LINE Ebenezer Porter m Hannah Creecey, of Salem, int 20 Sep 1740
2 LINE Ebenezer, son Ebenezer and Hannah Porter, b 25 Jan 1745
2 LINE Ebenezer, son Ebenezer and Hannah Porter, bap 15 Jan 1748/9
2 LINE Ebenezer Porter, d 3 Mar 1800, ae 86
1 INFO From Beverly, Mass VRs:
2 LINE Ebenezer, son William Jr and Lydia Porter, bap 8 Oct 1738
2 LINE Ebenezer Porter, of Wenham, and Hannah Cresy, m 2 Apr 1741
2 LINE Ebenezer Porter and Sarah Raymond, m 20 Nov 1760
1 INFO There are also Ebenezer Porters in Salem, Massachusetts.
1 FAMS @F167@
0 @I800@ INDI

1 SEX M

0 @I873@ INDI
1 NAME Jeremiah /Sabin/
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE 26 August 1703
2 PLAC Rehoboth, Massachusetts
1 DEAT
2 DATE after 1736
1 TEXT Jeremiah went to York Co., then MA now ME, about 1724 with his
2 CONT brothers Samuel and Israel, who served in the militia.
2 CONT Possibly Jeremiah was the "Joshua" Sabin who also served as
2 CONT private from 6/14/1725 or 11/28/1725, for no Joshua Sabin can
2 CONT be identified.
2 CONT "Jer Sabens," signing by mark, conveyed to Mary's brother
2 CONT Thomas Abbot, all right, claim, etc. in the Berwick estate of
2 CONT "our" father Joseph Abbot, deceased."
2 SOUR "Mayflower Famililes in Progress, John Billington"
1 TEXT This Jeremiah Sabin, or his son, may have been the "Jeremiah
2 CONT Sabean" who signed a Casco Bay ME petition in Nov. 1760; and
2 CONT that man was the "Jereh Sabins," grantee of Penobscot Township,
2 CONT 27 Jan. 1764.
2 CONT The son Jeremiah was surely the man who, with his family,
2 CONT "first settled at Argyle, Nova Scotia in 1762, then moved to
2 CONT the mouth of the Sissiboo River there."
2 CONT No death or probate record for Jeremiah Sabin appears in York
2 CONT County.
2 CONT The church records of Berwick show that on 8 May 1729 Mary
2 CONT Sabins owned the covenant, and "their" children were baptized
2 CONT subsequently.
2 SOUR "Mayflower Famililes in Progress, John Billington"

1 FAMS @F178@

1 TEXT Funeral Plans Made
2 CONT Funeral arrangements have been completed for Mrs.
2 CONT Fannie Church Wetmore, of 7 Boston Port Rd., Waterford, a
2 CONT former New London resident who died Sunday night at Lawrence
2 CONT Memorial Hospital.
2 CONT
2 CONT Mrs. Wetmore, wife of Ralph W. Wetmore, will be laid to rest
2 CONT tomorrow in Jordan Cemetery following a 2 p.m. funeral
2 CONT service at Byles Memorial Home.
2 CONT
2 CONT Calling hours will be from 7 to 9 o'clock tonight
2 SOUR clipping

2 CONT of 7 Boston Post Rd., Waterford, aged 76 years.
2 CONT
2 CONT Funeral services will be held at the Byles Memorial Home, 99
2 CONT Huntington St., on Wednesday afternoon, Jan. 20 at 2 o'clock.
2 CONT Interment in Jordan Cemetery.
2 CONT Friends my call this Tuesday evening 7-9 P.M.
