1 OBIT
2 DATE 8 June 1995
2 TEXT Daniel Wetmore
3 CONT
3 CONT New London - Daniel Wetmore, 84, of Ashtabula, Ohio, formerly
3 CONT of New London May 8 in the Ashtabula Care Center Nursing Home.
3 CONT
3 CONT He was born April 27, 1911 in New London, son of Fannie Church
3 CONT Wetmore and Ralph Wetmore.  As a young person he was in the
3 CONT Boston Marathon and was a lifeguard at Ocean Beach.  He was a
3 CONT welder at Electric Boat and Charleston Naval Yard.
3 CONT
3 CONT He was a bowler for 30 years and president of the South Carolina
3 CONT bowling Association three times.  He had owned M&M Bowling Lanes,
3 CONT Charleston, S.C.
3 CONT
3 CONT He was the husband of Jane Francis Wetmore.  She died in 1991.
3 CONT
3 CONT He was predeceased by one brother, Elwood Wetmore.
3 CONT
3 CONT Mr. Wetmore is survived by a brother, Clarence Wetmore of
3 CONT Ashtabula.
3 CONT
3 CONT A memorial service will be held at Jordan Cemetery, Waterford at
3 CONT a later date.  Ducro Funeral Service, Elm Avenue, Ashtabula, is
3 CONT in charge of arrangements.
2 SOUR New London "Day,", June 8, 1885
1 OBIT
2 TEXT Daniel M. Wetmore
3 CONT
3 CONT ASHTABLUA - Daniel M. Wetmore, 84, of Ashtabula, died Monday,
3 CONT May 8, 1995, in Ashtabula Care Center.
3 CONT
3 CONT Born April 26, 1911, in New London, Conn., he was the son of
3 CONT Ralph and Fannie (Miller) Wetmore.
3 CONT
3 CONT In 1936, Mr. Wetmore married Jayne Frances Wetmore.
3 CONT
3 CONT Prior to his retirement, he managed a bowling alley in
3 CONT Charleston, S.C., with his wife.  He had also been employed as
3 CONT an insurance salesman.
3 CONT
3 CONT He was an avid bowler.
3 CONT
3 CONT Survivors include a brother, Clarence, a niece, Beverly Terry,
3 CONT and a grandniece, Lisa Terry, all of Ashtabula.
3 CONT
3 CONT He was preceded in death by his wife, in 1991; a brother,
3 CONT Elwood; and his parents.
3 CONT
3 CONT Following cremation, a memeorial service will be held at the
3 CONT convenience of the family in Jordan Cemetery, Waterford, Conn.
3 CONT
3 CONT Ducro Funeral Services and Crematory, 45242 Elm Ave., Ashtabula,
3 CONT is in charge of arrangements.
2 SOUR clipping from an Ashtabula paper sent by Helen Pratt
1 NOTE Daniel had diabetes.

1 OBIT
2 DATE 22 September 2004
2 TEXT Clarence R. Wetmore
2 CONT ASHTABULA ??? Clarence R. Wetmore, 87, of Norwood Drive, died Monday, September 20, 2004, at Carington Park.
2 CONT He was born Sept. 16, 1917, in New London, Connecticut, the son of Ralph and Fannie (Church) Wetmore,
2 CONT and had been an Ashtabula resident most of his life.
2 CONT Prior to his retirement, he drove a truck for 30 years for Bell Transit-Linde Air, which is now PraxAir.
2 CONT Mr. Wetmore was involved with the Army???Navy Union and was a member of VFW Post No. 943.
2 CONT He enjoyed bowling and golfing.
2 CONT His survivors include one daughter, Beverly Terry, of Ashtabula; and one granddaughter,
2 CONT Lisa Terry of Ashtabula.
2 CONT He was preceded in death by his wife, Alice (Ball); one son, Larry Wetmore; two brothers,
2 CONT Daniel and Elwood Wetmore; and his parents.
2 CONT A memorial service will be held Thursday, Sept. 23, 2004, at 1 p.m. at Greenlawn Memory Gardens
2 CONT Mausoleum prior to his burial. Rev. Kenneth Roberts, Pastor of Pentecostal Church of God, will be officiating.
2 CONT No calling hours will be observed.
2 CONT Memorial contributions may be made to Ashtabula VFW Post #943.
2 CONT DUCRO FUNERAL SERVICE AND CREMATORY, 4524 Elm Avenue, is in charge of arrangements.
2 SOUR Star Beacon Newpaper
1 BURI
2 CEME Greenlawn Memory Garden Cemetery
2 ADDR 3140 East Center St., North Kingsville, OH 44068
2 PLAC North Kingsville, Ohio
2 NOTE He was a Corporal in the U.S. Army during World War II.

2 CEME Cedar Hill Cemetery
2 SOUR transcription by Dan Johnson, fide John Elliott
1 SOUR Amy Young
1 NOTE Maj. Percy Woodforde Wetmore b. 24OCT1878 (ca. 1880 in 1881), d. Saint John Co., NB 12NOV1946,
2 CONT m. Saint John Co., NB 27SEP1899 Edith Jean Carleton (b. Saint John West, Saint John Co.,
2 CONT NB 6MAR1878), d/o James and Matilda (Long) Carleton.
2 CONT A son of William and Elizabeth (Carroll) Carleton, James Carleton was from Comolin (Comlin?),
2 CONT Ireland (possibly in Wexford) ca. 1850-9.
2 CONT Percy W. Wetmore was in Guys Ward, Saint John, Saint John Co., NB in 1901 where his date-of-birth
2 CONT is given as 24OCT1878. Edith J. was b. 6MAR1878; and one son was Leigh C. b. 22JUL1900.
2 CONT Since the dates in this census for Edith and Leigh match birth records, presumably Percy???s is correct;
2 CONT although it contradicts his age in 1881.
2 CONT Major Percy Woodforde Wetmore enlisted in the CEF (Overseas Siege Battery) 2AUG1916
2 CONT (the day after his son.) Here his birth-date is given as 24OCT1877 in Gibson, York Co., NB.
2 CONT He was a merchant, lived on Lowell Saint Saint John West, and his next-of-kin was his wife,
2 CONT Edith Jean Wetmore. He was Church of England. Notations on his attestation indicate that
2 CONT he was in the reserve, the 3rd C. G. A, and had been made acting-adjutant of that
2 CONT unit 23APR1915, and acting-officer commanding 6MAR1916.
2 CONT As the commanding officer he signed his own attestation as the recruiter and the recruited.
2 CONT He commanded the No. 9 Overseas Siege Battery ca. 1916-18.
2 CONT In 1911, Percy was a Senior Grand Warden of the Grand Lodge of New Brunswick.
2 CONT In 1907, he had been Grand Pursuivant.
2 CONT P. W. Wetmore of Saint Stephen, Charlotte Co., NB, had a daughter b. 27APR1902.
2 CONT In 1901, Percy W. Wetmore was in Guys Ward, Saint John, Saint John Co., NB. In 1911,
2 CONT he was in Lancaster Parish (Town), Saint John Co., NB.

1 MARR
2 DATE 21 November 1858
2 PLAC Toxteth, Walton-on-the-Hill, Liverpool, Lancashire, England
2 CHUR Saint Michaels
2 HUSB
3 NAME Daniel Wetmore
3 STAT Widower
3 AGE 38
3 OCCU Shipwright
3 RESI
4 PLAC Liverpool
5 ADDR Nile Street
3 FATH
4 NAME Jesse Wetmore
4 OCCU Joiner
2 WIFE
3 NAME Elizabeth Roberts
3 STAT Spinster
3 AGE 16 (17 in December)
3 RESI Toxteth Park, Liverpool, England
4 ADDR Mann Street
3 FATH
4 NAME Elias Roberts
4 OCCU Mill-man
2 TEXT 21 November 1858 Marriage at St Michaels, Toxteth, Walton-on-the-Hill
3 CONT between Daniel Wetmore (Widower) age 38, Shipwright of Nile Street Liverpool,
3 CONT son of Jesse Wetmore, Joiner and Elizabeth Roberts (spinster) age 16 (17 in December) of
3 CONT Mann Street, Toxteth Park, daughter of Elias Roberts, Mill-man
2 SOUR Katharine Pinkerton presumably from official marriage record

1 NOTE Place: Holy Trinity Church, Parish of Holy Trinity, Leicester, Borough of Leicester, England.
1 NOTE Groom's Father: Joseph Clark Wetmore (deceased), Ship carpenter.
1 NOTE Bride: Hannah le Blais George, of full age, widow, no occupation, no address.
1 NOTE Bride's Father: John Bromley, gentleman.
1 NOTE Witnesses: Sarah Ann Cooke and Henry Bias Livingston.
1 NOTE Officiator: Married after banns by W. Earle, curate.

1 FAMS @F3187@
0 @I1218@ INDI
1 NAME Susan Christine /Bell/
1 SEX F
1 BIRT
2 DATE 30 May 1952
2 PLAC Berkeley, California
2 SOUR Ruth Ridgeway
1 RESI
2 PLAC Carmel, New York
2 ADDR 304 Drew Lane
1 DEAT
2 NAME Susan Bell Borges
2 AGE 39 years
2 DATE 3 May 1992
2 PLAC Danbury, Connecticut
2 HOSP Danbury Hospital
2 CAUS infer cancer
1 OBIT
2 TEXT
3 CONT Susan Borges
3 CONT Waterford -- Susan Bell Borges, 39, of 304 Drew Lane,
3 CONT Carmel, N.Y., wife of Waterford native Robert Borges, died
3 CONT Sunday at Danbury Hospital, Danbury.
3 CONT She was born May 30, 1953 in Berkeley, Calif., the daughter
3 CONT of Charles Bell and the late Elizabeth Martino Bell.
3 CONT She married Robert Borges on May 6, 1989.
3 CONT Besides her husband and father, she is survived by a
3 CONT sister, Elizabeth Figueroa of Manassas, Va.
3 CONT The funeral service will be at 10:30 a.m. Wednesday at
3 CONT Beecher Funeral Home, 1 Putnam Terrace, Brewster, N.Y.
3 CONT Burial will be in Ivandale Cemetery, Somers, N.Y.
3 CONT Calling hours will be 7-9 tonight.
3 CONT Donations in her memory may be made to the Americal Cancer
3 CONT Society, Glenida Avenue, Carmel, N.Y. 10512.
1 BURI
2 PLAC 6 May 1992
2 PLAC Somers, New York
2 CEME Ivandale Cemetery
1 SOUR Ruth Ridgeway
1 SOUR Newspaper obituary

2 DATE 29 October 2015
2 PLAC Pennsylvania, United States
1 OBIT
2 TEXT Violet F. (Vasil) Girhiny, age 88 on Thursday, October 29, 2015 of Mt. Oliver Wife of the
2 TEXT late Michael Girhiny. Beloved mother of Linda E. Moloney and Carole Clark.
2 TEXT Grandmother of Sean Moloney, Christopher and Taylor Clark.
2 TEXT Also survived by 5 Great Grandchildren.
2 TEXT Friends received Tuesday, November 3rd from 4-8 PM at the Readshaw Funeral Home, Inc.
2 TEXT 1503 Brownsville Road, Carrick
2 TEXT Funeral Prayer Wednesday, November 4th at 10:15 AM in Funeral Home
2 TEXT followed by a Mass of Christian Burial 11:00 AM St. John Vianney Parish.
2 TEXT Interment St. John Vianney Cemetery.
2 TEXT Violet was an accomplished pianist, loved to dance with her husband, cherished the arts ,
2 TEXT was dedicated to her children, grandchildren, great grandchildren and had an affection for cats.
2 TEXT Send condolences to www.readshawfuneralhome.com

1 NAME Israel /Sabin/
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE 8 June 1673
2 PLAC Rehoboth, Massachusetts
1 DEAT
2 DATE after 25 March 1718
1 RESI
2 DATE 25 March 1718
2 PLAC Barrington, Rhode Island [then Massachusetts]
1 TEXT Israel Sabin lived in Rehoboth continuing the family trade as
2 CONT miller until he and his mother sold their share of the mill and
2 CONT homestead in 1700.
2 CONT Styled husbandman or yeoman in later deeds, he moved to Swansea
2 CONT ca. 1712.
2 CONT He, "of Swanzey" on 7 May 1717, with wife Elizabeth and mother
2 CONT Mary Sabin sold Rehoboth land that had been part of the estate
2 CONT of Samuel Sabin, Sr.
2 CONT In the last record found, Israil Sabin was of Barrington 25
2 CONT March 1718 when he sold his rights of commonage in Rehoboth.
2 CONT It is probably that he died soon afterward, for his children
2 CONT scattered at an early age.
2 CONT No probate record in Bristol County has been discovered.
1 SOUR "Mayflower Families in Progress, John Billington"

0 @I1266@ INDI
1 NAME Samuel /Sabin/
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE about 1640
1 DEAT
2 DATE 23 September 1699
2 PLAC Rehoboth, Massachusetts
1 TEXT The family lived at Rehoboth, where Samuel Sabin was called
2 CONT planter and miller.
2 CONT He served in King Philip's War, and in the Phips expedition to
2 CONT Quebec in 1690.
2 CONT The will of Samuel Sabin of Rehoboth, written 14 July 1690,
2 CONT "called forth to war against the French," was presented 16 Oct.
2 CONT 1699.
2 CONT Mentioned in it were his wife, sons Samuel and Israel to have
2 CONT the real estate, daus. Mercy and Sarah each to have three
2 CONT pounds, and the same sum to the youngest dau. at her marriage.
2 CONT The son Samuel was named executor with his mother, but in a
2 CONT lengthy written agreement, Samuel renounced executorship in
2 CONT favor of administration by his brother Israel and mother widow
2 CONT Mary Sabin.
2 CONT The agreement described property in the estate inherited from
2 CONT "grandfather William Sabin," and land purchased from "Uncle
2 CONT John Martin."
2 CONT John Kingsley was one of the bondsmen in administration of the
2 CONT estate.
1 TEXT On 1 Aug. 1707 Mary Sabin of Rehoboth joined her sisters
2 CONT Elizabeth Patte, Dorcas May and Mercy Martin, wife of John
2 CONT Martin, in conveying their rights to the Middleboro land of
2 CONT their deceased father, Francis Billington, "for love" to their
2 CONT niece Desire Billington, daughter of their brother Issac.
1 SOUR "Mayflower Families in Progress, John Billington"

1 FAMS @F291@
0 @I1286@ INDI
1 NAME Francis /Billington/
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE about 1606 to 1609
2 PLAC England, prob Lincolnshire
1 DEAT
2 DATE 3 December 1684
2 PLAC Middleboro, Massachusetts
2 AGE 80 years
1 TEXT Francis Billington lived at Plymouth until 1669, when he moved
2 CONT to Middleboro and occupied land granted to him as one of the
2 CONT "First Comers."
2 CONT He lived there until his death, except for a few years during
2 CONT King Philip's War when he fled to Plymouth for safety.
2 CONT On 18 April 1642 his daughter Elizabeth was apprenticed; and 14
2 CONT January 1642/3 he bound out son Joseph, aged "vi or vii" and
2 CONT two daughters, probably Martha and Mary, one five years old and
2 CONT the other even younger.
2 CONT Bradford stated in 1651 that Francis Billington had eight
2 CONT children.
1 TEXT In his old age Francis was dependent on his son Isaac for
2 CONT support and died intestate.
2 CONT No probate record appears, although son Isaac petitioned the
2 CONT probate court in 1703/4 for title to all his father's
2 CONT Middleboro lands, stating he had had sole care of his parents
2 CONT in their old age.
2 CONT A Plymouth County Court case of Sept. 1722, brought by Isaac's
2 CONT daughter Desire4 [Billington] Bonney and her husband, James,
2 CONT shows that Francis Billington died intestate leaving issue two
2 CONT sons and five daughters, viz: sons Joseph (eldest, who
2 CONT inherited a double portion) and Isaac; daughters Elizabeth,
2 CONT Mary, Dorcas, Mercy and Martha, with a total of eight shares in
2 CONT the estate.
2 CONT A 1719 quitclaim deed from Francis's grandson Francis
2 CONT Billington, reading "my father Francis and grandfather
2 CONT [unnamed] Billington" seems to imply a son Francic, Jr.
2 CONT But in the absence of any mention of such a son in
2 CONT contemporaneous Plymouth records, coupled with the fact that
2 CONT Francis4's deed evidently transferred the shares of Joseph
2 CONT Billington, we conclude that the deed contains a clerical
2 CONT error.
2 CONT The original must have read "my father Joseph and grandfather
2 CONT Francis Billington."
2 CONT Indications are that the seven children named in the Bonney
2 CONT suit and their progeny were the only survivors of Francis
2 CONT Billington.
2 CONT A more detailed account has been published.
1 SOUR "Mayflower Families in Progress, John Billington"
1 FAMC @F295@
1 FAMS @F292@

1 ARRV
2 DATE 1620
2 SHIP Mayflower
2 PLAC Plymouth, Plymouth Colony
1 DEAT
2 DATE September 1630
2 PLAC Plymouth Colony
2 NOTE executed for murder
1 NOTE Although Bradford states that the Billington family joined the
2 CONT Mayflower Company from London, there is evidence that they were
2 CONT originally from Lincolnshire.
2 CONT In 1612 Francis Longland, gent., of Lincolnshire named Francis
2 CONT Billington, son of John Billington, as one of his two heirs in
2 CONT a lease of Crown land.
1 NOTE John Billington and his family received three acres in the 1623
2 CONT Division of Land at Plymouth and in May 1627 he, his wife and
2 CONT sons John and Francis were named in the Division of Cattle.
2 CONT In 1651 Bradford wrote: "John Billington, after he had been
2 CONT here ten years, was executed for killing a man, and his eldest
2 CONT son died before him, but his second son is alive and married
2 CONT and hath eight children."
1 SOUR "Mayflower Families in Progress, John Billington"
1 FAMS @F295@
0 @I1298@ INDI

1 SEX F
1 BIRT
2 DATE about 1580
2 PLAC England, perhaps Lincolnshire
1 DEAT
2 DATE after 2 March 1642/3
1 NOTE Although Bradford's History and Plymouth Colony records often
2 CONT refer to her as "Ellen" or "Helen," when whe and her son stated
2 CONT her name in their own deeds of 1638-1643, it is invariably
2 CONT written "Ellinor."
1 SOUR "Mayflower Families in Progress, John Billington"

0 @I1301@ INDI
1 NAME Richard /Nason/
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 PLAC England, poss Stratford-on-Avon
2 TEXT He may have come from Stratford-on-Avon, where there many of
3 CONT his name.
3 CONT A Richard Nason was bapt. at Stratford-on-Avon, 3 Aug. 1606.
3 CONT He was the son of John Nason who married Elizabeth Rogers, 28
3 CONT Oct. 1600.
1 RESI
2 DATE 1639
2 PLAC Pipe Stave Landing [New Hampshire?]
1 RESI
2 PLAC Kittery, Maine
2 SOUR CAT
1 RESI
2 PLAC Dover, New Hampshire
2 SOUR CAT
1 DEAT
2 DATE after 14 July 1694 and before 15 March 1696/7
2 TEXT He died after 14 July 1694, the date of his will, and before 15
3 CONT March 1696/7, when his will was probated.
1 TEXT Richard Nason was a planter and often assisten in surveying.
2 CONT He was a juryman in 1649 and was accused of "blasphemy" in
2 CONT 1665.
2 CONT The General Court did "not judge him so guilty of that fact as
2 CONT that by our lawe he ought to die," but put him under bonds of
2 CONT forty pounds for good behavior.
2 CONT Philip Chesley of Oyster River was witness against him.
2 CONT The inhabitants of Kittery showed their opinion of him and of
2 CONT his offense by electing him as Deputy to the General the next
2 CONT year, along with Thomas Withers.
2 CONT The Court refused to allow Nason his seat, and the persons who
2 CONT elected him in Kittery were called to an account.
2 CONT He was presented at York in 1655 for not attending meeting, and
2 CONT in 1659 he was fined five pounds and disfranchised for
2 CONT entertaining Quakers.
2 CONT He was ensign in 1653, was selectman and held other town
2 CONT offices.
2 CONT His lot of 200 acres was confirmed to him by the town.
1 TEXT In 1654 John Baker was presented at Court in New Hampshire "for
2 CONT beating Richard Nason that he was black and blue and for
2 CONT throwing a fire shovel at his wife."
2 CONT Baker was fined five shillings.
2 CONT This John Baker was probably Richard Nason's father-in-law.
1 SOUR Old Kittery and Her Families

1 TEXT Richard Ely came to Boston from Plymouth, England, in 1661
2 CONT (some sources say between 1660 and 1663), and after his second
2 CONT marriage settled in Lyme (then part of Saybrook), Connecticut.
2 CONT The interests of her second wife, who with her brother owned
2 CONT large estates near the mouth of the Connecticut River, led to
2 CONT his settlement there.
2 CONT There was considerable trouble over his wife's estate.

1 NOTE He was with the "Mayflower" when it originally sailed, but
2 CONT after the return and abandonment of the "Speedwell," his
2 CONT father gave up the family's place for others; they arrived
2 CONT the next year in the "Fortune."

2 CONT aged 14 only, and on return of his father next month given to
2 CONT Gov Bradford, who brought him up, was chosen Ruling Elder
2 CONT 1649, after Brewster, and ordained 6 April.
2 CONT This "precious servant of God" died 10 December 1691, aged
2 CONT 83.

0 @I1516@ INDI
1 NAME Robert/Cushman/
1 NAME Robert/Cutchman/
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE 1577/8
2 SOUR CAT
1 CHR
2 DATE 9 February 1577/8
2 PLAC Rolvenden, Kent County, England
2 PLAC Rolveden, Kent County, England
2 SOUR J. A. Cushman, 1964
1 ARRV
2 SHIP Fortune
2 DATE 10 November 1621
2 PLAC Plymouth, Massachusetts
1 DEAT
2 DATE January or February 1625
2 PLAC London, England
2 SOUR J. A. Cushman, 1964
1 NOTE He was married once before he married Sarah Reder.
2 CONT The mother of his first three children was Sarah Reder.
2 CONT The mother of the fourth child is not known.
1 TEXT Robert, Plymouth, one of the most active promoters of the
2 CONT migration from Holland in 1620 of the pilgrims in the
2 CONT Mayflower, of which he was one, but when adverse
2 CONT circumstances compelled that ship to put back, he gave up his
2 CONT place for the good of other companions in the Speedwell,
2 CONT which was abandoned; came next year in the Fortune, arrived
2 CONT 10 November 1621, the first ship after the Mayflower, with
2 CONT son Thomas, yet staid here only one month, went home in the
2 CONT same little bark, and came again no more.
2 CONT He had married at Leyden, 3 June 1617, Mary Singleton (on the
2 CONT Dutch record spelled Chingelton), of Sandwich, he being
2 CONT designated a woolcarder from Canturbury, both in Co Kent.
2 CONT The first sermon preached in New England was by him, on the
2 CONT highly appropriate subject of self-denial.
2 CONT He was constant in service at London for the emigration and
2 CONT in December 1624 spoke of his hope of coming in the next
2 CONT season; but Governor Bradford notes that he was dead before
2 CONT receipt of his answer from Plymouth of June 1625; and his
2 CONT family came soon after to partake in the fortunes of the
2 CONT plantation.
2 CONT By general consent, he was assigned a share in the division
2 CONT of land with the comers of the Mayflower.
2 SOUR Savage
1 SOUR MFIP, I. Allerton

2 DATE 1624
2 SHIP Zouch Phenix
2 FROM Weymouth, England
2 SOUR GGT
1 NOTE He was among the founders of Salem, Massachusetts Bay Colony.
1 RESI
2 PLAC Salem, Massachusetts Bay Colony
1 WILL
2 DATE 15 May 1666
1 DEAT
2 DATE 16 May 1666
2 PLAC Salem, Massachusetts
1 TEXT William, Salem, one of the first settlers before Endicott,
2 CONT perhaps in 1626.
2 CONT He requested admission as freeman 19 October 1630, but was
2 CONT never sworn in (that we can find) yet was captain in 1632,
2 CONT rep in 1635, 6, 7 and 9, had com in the expedition under
2 CONT Endicott, 1637, against the Pequots.
2 CONT For that service his modest petition of 1661 is printed in
2 CONT GR:VI:370 and the grant of 400 acres then made was in
2 CONT addition to one of 250, bestowed soon after the war of 1637.
2 SOUR Savage
1 NOTE William may have had two wives, both named Sarah, and the
2 CONT second Sarah may have been the mother of the last two or
2 CONT three children; one of the Sarahs (if were two) was baptised
2 CONT 14 September 1656.

1 INFO Other Freemans on the "Abigail" were Mary (age 50), John (35),
2 CONT Thomas (24), John (9), Cecilia (4), Edward (34) and wife

2 CONT Edmund (15), Elizabeth (12) and John (8).

2 CONT that Elizabeth (35) is his wife.
2 CONT See Savage.

1 FAMC @F480@
0 @I2023@ INDI
1 NAME Helen Louise /Wetmore/
1 SEX F
1 BIRT
2 DATE 14 April 1917
2 PLAC Brooklyn, New York, United States
2 SOUR Helen Pratt
1 DEAT
2 DATE 19 December 2014
2 PLAC Middletown, Rhode Island, United States
2 SOUR Her obituary.
1 NOTE Mentioned on here mother's passport application as "daughter Helen Wetmore, age 7 years"
2 CONT when applied for on 14 April 1924.
1 OBIT
2 TEXT Middletown, RI - Helen L. (Wetmore) Pratt, 97, of Middletown, RI, passed away on Friday December 19, 2014
2 TEXT at Forest Farm Health Care Center in Middletown.
2 TEXT She was the wife of the late Charles E. Pratt
2 TEXT Born in Brooklyn, NY on Apr. 14, 1917, she was the daughter of the late Herbert and Amalia (Tilus) Wetmore.
2 TEXT Mrs. Pratt was a 1935 graduate of Rogers High School, a 1939 graduate of RI School of Design and 1940
2 TEXT graduate of Katherine Gibbs.
2 TEXT She worked as a secretary and blue print reader at Ocean Techniques Inc., then for Federal Civil Service
2 TEXT in Baltimore, MD.
2 TEXT Mrs. Pratt enjoyed international travel.
2 TEXT She was a member of the Order of Eastern Star, the Calvary United Methodist Church, the National Association
2 TEXT of Retired Federal Employees, the Literary Volunteers of America and she also volunteered in
2 TEXT the Newport Education system.
2 TEXT She leaves her daughter Amelia "Amy" Pratt of Louisville, KY.
2 TEXT She was the mother of the late Stephen Pratt.
2 TEXT Her family would like to thank the staff at Forest Farm for the exceptional and loving care that
2 TEXT she received while living there.
2 TEXT Burial will be private.
2 TEXT Memorial donations may be made to Robert Potter League for Animals, PO Box 412, Newport, RI 02840.

0 @I2119@ INDI
1 NAME Benton /Ridgeway/
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE 25 January 1908
2 PLAC Oldham, Crompton, Lancaster, England
2 SOUR Ruth Ridgeway
1 REMV
2 PLAC Baltic, Connecticut
2 SOUR Ruth Ridgeway
1 DEAT
2 DATE 8 June 1990
2 PLAC Willimantic, Connecticut
2 SOUR newspaper obituary
1 OBIT
2 TEXT Benton Ridgeway/ Retired local banker/ Jan. 25, 1908 - June 9, 1990
3 CONT South Windham - Benton Ridgeway, 82, of Pigeon Swamp Road,
3 CONT South Windham, retired banker and former vice-president at the
3 CONT Connecticut Bank and Trust, husband of Ruth (Borges) Ridgeway,
3 CONT died Friday morning at the Windham Community Memorial Hospital.
3 CONT
3 CONT Mr. Ridgeway was born Jan. 25, 1908, in Oldham Lancashire,
3 CONT England.  He was the son of the late James and Clara (Hallas)
3 CONT Ridgeway.  He came with his family to Baltic at the age of 2.
3 CONT
3 CONT He entered the employ of the Old Windham National Bank on his
3 CONT graduation from Windham High School in 1927.  He retired in 1970.
3 CONT
3 CONT When active in community affairs he was treasurer of the
3 CONT Visiting Nurse Assoc., the Guilford Smith Memorial Library in
3 CONT South Windham and the Windham Fish and Game Club.  He was a
3 CONT member of the Windham Historical Society, Eastern Star Lodge #44
3 CONT AF&AM and the First Congregational Church of South Windham,
3 CONT where he served as a deacon from 1945 to 1960.
3 CONT
3 CONT Besides his wife, survivors include two sons, Hallas Ridgeway of
3 CONT Chaplin and Michel Ridgeway of Malvern, Pa.; a daughter, Judith
3 CONT Coon of Coventry; a sister, Mrs. Alfred (Constance) Charron of
3 CONT Baltic; nine grandchildren; several nieces and nephews.
3 CONT
3 CONT Potter Funeral Home, 456 Jackson St., Willimantic, is in charge
3 CONT of the arrangements.
1 OBIT
2 TEXT RIDGEWAY - in Willimantic, June 8, 1990, Benton Ridgeway, 82, of
3 CONT South Windham.  A Memorial Service will be held Saturday, June
3 CONT 16 at 2 p.m. at the First Congregational Church of South
3 CONT Windham.  Burial will be at the convenience of the family.
3 CONT There are no calling hours.  In lieu of flowers memorial
3 CONT contributions may be made to the Windham Historical Society,
3 CONT c/o Alice Fowler, 50 Hayden St., Willimantic, 06226.  Potter
3 CONT Funeral Home, 456 Jackson St., Willimantic, is in charge of the
3 CONT arrangements.

1 NAME Alice Marie/Ball/
1 NAME Alice/Ball/
1 SEX F
1 BIRT
2 DATE 2 January 1922
2 PLAC Ohio
2 SOUR Beverly Wetmore, her daughter, I think
1 DEAT
2 DATE 2 January 1989
2 PLAC Ashtabula, Ohio
2 SOUR Beverly Wetmore, her daughter, I think
1 SOUR letter from Clarence Wetmore, her husband, to Helen Pratt, her
2 CONT husband's cousin
1 TEXT Dear Helen,
2 CONT I believe I received this letter by mistake so am returning
2 CONT it.  It was good to hear from you and to know about the
2 CONT family.  My news is not so good Clare left me before
2 CONT Christmas for another woman.  I am working in a delicatessen
2 CONT 6 days a week but only 5 hrs a day it is enough to get me bye
2 CONT as long as Clare pays the bills but he hasn't been too good
2 CONT at that either.  It is a long story but to cut it short he is
2 CONT just a completely changed man from what he was some say age.
2 CONT He doesn't give me an answer.  Bev graduated in 1971 and has
2 CONT worked in the lab at the hospital for 2 1/2 yrs.  She is 22
2 CONT and not married.  Larry graduated in 1974 and is not
2 CONT married.  He is looking for work right now.  He got mixed up
2 CONT with a group of boys and has given me a few problems, but I
2 CONT guess things will get better for him soon.  Don't know
2 CONT any-thing about Elwood.  Clare & I saw Dan & Jayne last year
2 CONT in Cincinnati at a bowling tournament.  Will write more
2 CONT later.  Everything has been quite mixed up for me since
2 CONT Christmas.
2 CONT Love, Alice
2 SOUR letter from Alice Wetmore to Helen Pratt

0 @I2320@ INDI
1 NAME Thomas Saunders /Wetmore/
1 SEX M
1 TITL Doctor
1 BIRT
2 DATE Friday 26 November 1813
2 PLAC Kingswood, Kingsclear parish, York County, New Brunswick, Canada
1 GRAD
2 DATE 1833
2 PLAC New Brunswick, Canada
2 INST Kings College
1 TEXT Graduated at Kings College, N. B., in 1833, was for some years
2 CONT clerk assistant of the House of Assembly of New Brunswick.
2 CONT Studied medicine, and by his own exertions and energy, he was
2 CONT enabled to proceed to Scotland, in 1835, for the purpose of
2 CONT perfecting himself in his profession, at the universities of
2 CONT Glasgow and Edinburg.
2 CONT He took the degree of M. D. at Glasgow University, in 1839,
2 CONT and a diploma at the Royal College of Surgeons in Edinburgh,
2 CONT the same year.
2 CONT While in Glasgow he filled the clerkship of the Fever
2 CONT Hospital and other departments of the Royal Infirmary, in
2 CONT which institution he became house surgeon.
2 CONT He returned to New Brunswick about 1839-40.
2 CONT Since which time he has been successfully engaged in his
2 CONT profession, in the city of Saint Johns [sic]; has been 18
2 CONT years surgeon to the Provincial Penitentiary of New
2 CONT Brunswick, and is has been said of him that he has conducted
2 CONT that institution as midical officer withough the use of
2 CONT mercury or bleeding; nor has he used mercury in his private
2 CONT practice, 'tis said, for 15 years.
1 SOUR JCW, pg 260

0 @I2322@ INDI
1 NAME Abraham Kierstead Smedes /Wetmore/
1 SEX M
1 TITL Judge
1 BIRT
2 DATE 6 June 1802
3 SOUR JCW, pg 261
2 PLAC Rye, New York
3 SOUR Anne Marie Flewelling
2 PLAC New York
3 SOUR Larry Wetmore, Needham, Mass.
1 CHR
2 BY Rev. Evan Rogers, of Rye
2 INFO His sponsors were his parents, and Timothy Wetmore, A. K.
3 CONT Smedes, and Esther Hunt.
2 SOUR JCW, pg 261
1 RESI
2 DATE 30 September 1824
2 PLAC Miramichi, Northumberland County, New Brunswick, Canada
2 INFO This is from the record of his marriage with Eliza Peters.
2 SOUR Daniel Johnson, New Brunswick Newspaper Vital Statistics Volume 3 Number 241
3 CONT 7 October 1824, City Gazette, Saint John.
1 DEAT
2 DATE 7 August 1862
2 PLAC Woodstock, New Brunswick, Canada
1 DEAT
2 DATE 1862
2 PLAC Woodstock, New Brunswick, Canada
2 SOUR Larry Wetmore, Needham, Mass.
2 SOUR Anne Marie Flewelling
1 TEXT Prior to the death of Mr. Wetmore's father, Abrm K. Smedes,
2 CONT then a merchant of wealth in the city of New York (a
2 CONT gentleman who had been a sincere and devoted friend of the
2 CONT Rev. Robert Griffith [sic] W.), adopted the subject of this
2 CONT notice as his son, and from him it, will be perceived, he
2 CONT received his Christian names.
2 CONT From this noble specimen of the very best of men (now many
2 CONT years deceased), did Mr. W. receive his early education, and
2 CONT those principles which have so much contributed to the
2 CONT success that has attended him since that time.
2 CONT In 1819, Mr. Wetmore removed to the province of New
2 CONT Brunswick, and entered as a student the office of his uncle
2 CONT Thomas, the then attorney general.
2 CONT In 1823 was admitted an attorney of the Supreme Court, and
2 CONT in 1825 was called to the bar and enrolled as a barrister.
2 CONT In 1834 he received the appointment of clerk of the peace,
2 CONT and of the inferior court of Common Pleas, for the county of
2 CONT Carleton, where he as ever since resided.
2 CONT In 1850 the county of Carleton became divided into two
2 CONT counties, the new county known as that of Victoria.
2 CONT In the commissions of the peace and of the inferior court of
2 CONT Common Pleas for the new county, the distinguished position
2 CONT of senior justice was assigned to him; so that he now stands
2 CONT at the head of the two commissions, and has held other
2 CONT offices of minor importance.
2 CONT Is deputy provincial grand master of the grand lodge of New
2 CONT Brunswick.
2 CONT In that official capacity he had the honor of presenting the
2 CONT masonic address from the grand lodge to H. R. H. the Price of
2 CONT Wales, in his recent visit to New Brunswick (1860).
2 SOUR JCW, pgs 261-2, direct quote

1 OBIT
2 TEXT Frank O. Wetmore
2 TEXT
2 TEXT The death of Frank O. Wetmore, husbnd of Audrey (Young) Wetmore, occurred at Bloomfield Station on Jan. 26.
2 TEXT He was born at Bloomfield Station, where he was a life-long resident.
2 TEXT He was a son of the late Oscar and Emily Wetmore, and was a member of the Bloomfield United Church.
2 TEXT He is survived by his wife; two sons, Stanley E. and Walter G., at home;
2 TEXT two daughters, Helen R. Wetmore, Toronto, and Mrs. Jack Smith, Missouri; one grandson;
2 TEXT and two half-sisters, Miss Julia P. Wetmore, Hampton Station, and Miss Ada C. Wetmore, California.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT The funeral was held from Sherwood's Funeral Home, Midland, on Saturday at 2:30 p.m., with
2 TEXT Rev. Eric LeDrew, Hampton.
2 TEXT The pallbearers were Raymond Wetmore, Maurice Wetmore, Seldon Coulter, Robert Grass, Harold
2 TEXT Ganong and Murray Mercer.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Floral tributes were:
2 TEXT Pillow -- Wife and Boys.
2 TEXT Sprays -- Florence and Frank; Robert Grass and family; Nellie and Murray; Mack, Gen and Ronnie;
2 TEXT Helen, Ray, Eileen and Maurice; George, Oda and Jasper; Sandy, Betty and Deane
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Cut Flowers -- Ethel Thomas; Walter and Seldon; Lois and Mildred; Marion and Wendell Wiggins;
2 TEXT Bloomfield United Church; students of 9A, Hampton Consolidated School; advanced department, Bloomfield School.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT FUNERAL TRIBUTE
2 TEXT Tributes received at the funeral of Frank O. Wetmore, Bloomfield Station, included:
2 TEXT Heart Fund, George Beckett; Laurence and Wyn Parlee; Donald and Mary Parlee; Nora and Jim and family;
2 TEXT Harold and Lu; Julia wetmore

1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE 29 June 1899
3 SOUR Daphne Baird Wetmore research.
2 DATE 1899
3 SOUR 21pp.
2 PLAC Saint John, New Brunswick, Canada
3 SOUR Obituary below.
3 SOUR Daphne Baird Wetmore research.
1 DEAT
2 DATE 24 September 1991
2 AGE 93 years
2 PLAC Sydney, Nova Scotia, Canada
2 HOSP Sydney Community Health Centre
2 ADDR 65 Holyrood Drive
2 SOUR Obituary below
1 OBIT
2 SOUR Halifax Mail-Star, Wednesday, 25 September 1991
2 TEXT Educator Horace Wetmore dies
2 TEXT
2 TEXT WETMORE, Horace Hannington - 93, 65 Holyrood Dr., Sydney,
2 TEXT died Tuesday in Sydney Community Health Center.
2 TEXT Born in Saint John, N.B., he was a son of the late Dr. Horace
2 TEXT and Louise (Hannington) Wetmore.
2 TEXT He is the last surviving member of his immediate family.
2 TEXT He was a deacon at United Baptist Church, Sydney.
2 TEXT He was a past president and bulletin editor of Westmount Y's
2 TEXT Men's Club.
2 TEXT He was an avid bridge player and served on the local
2 TEXT Duplicate Bridge Club for many years.
2 TEXT He was educated in Saint John, N.B. and graduated from Acadia
2 TEXT University in Engineering with a B.Sc. (Honours) and an M.A.
2 TEXT While at Acadia, he distinguished himself in various
2 TEXT athletics.
2 TEXT Later he graduated from the Ontario College of Education and
2 TEXT went on to become a leading educator in public schools in New
2 TEXT Brunswick and Nova Scotia for almost 45 years.
2 TEXT He began his teaching career at Pictou Academy in 1921 and
2 TEXT later taught at Horton Academy in 1924.
2 TEXT In 1929, he was appointed principal of Kings County Academy
2 TEXT and supervisor of Kentville schools.
2 TEXT Several years later, he became principal and supervisor of
2 TEXT schools in Yarmouth, a position he held for 16 years.
2 TEXT During this time, he instituted music, speech and drama
2 TEXT festivals within that school system.
2 TEXT During the Second World War, he served with the RCAF in the
2 TEXT recruiting and counseling divisions.
2 TEXT Following the war, he taught at Saint John High School.
2 TEXT In 1950, he became principal of Riverview High School in
2 TEXT Coxheath, Cape Breton, where he served until his retirement
2 TEXT in the late 1960's.
2 TEXT Throughout his years at Riverview, he took a very active role
2 TEXT in student affairs, especially drama and public speaking.
2 TEXT He introduced a general course program, the first of its kind
2 TEXT in the area.
2 TEXT His many contributions to education include: president of the
2 TEXT Cape Breton local of the Nova Scotia Teachers Union, member
2 TEXT of various provincial committees with NSTU, president of Nova
2 TEXT Scotia Teachers Union (1941-1942).
2 TEXT He also served on several curriculum and advisory committees
2 TEXT for Nova Scotia Department of Education.
2 TEXT He was honoured by being appointed to the Board of Governors
2 TEXT of Acadia University.
2 TEXT He is survived by two daughters, Elizabeth (Mrs. John
2 TEXT Matheson), Marion Bridge; Catherine (Mrs. Eric Smith), Truro;
2 TEXT a son, Roy Whetmore, Kanata, Ont.; 15 grandchildren; several
2 TEXT great-grandchildren.
2 TEXT he was predeceased by his wife, the former Blanche Harris;
2 TEXT two brothers, Francis, Richard.
2 TEXT The body is in T. W. Curry's Parkview Chapel, visiting 2-4,
2 TEXT 7-9 p.m. today.
2 TEXT Funeral will be 2 p.m. Thursday in United Baptist Church,
2 TEXT Rev. Willis Henderson officiating.
2 TEXT Burial will be in Forest Haven Memorial Gardens.
2 TEXT Donations maay be made to Riverview Rural High School
2 TEXT scholarship fund or any charity.
1 BURI
2 DATE 26 September 1991
2 PLAC probably Sydney, Nova Scotia, Canada
2 CEME Forest Haven Memorial Gardens
2 SOUR obituary

1 NAME Maurice Parker/Wetmore/

1 BIRT
2 DATE 14 September 1919
3 SOUR Daphne Baird Wetmore research.
3 SOUR Baird/Wetmore Family Tree, Ancesty.com
2 DATE 1919
3 SOUR 21pp.
2 PLAC Bloomfield, Kings County, New Brunswick, Canada
3 SOUR Daphne Baird Wetmore research.
3 SOUR Baird/Wetmore Family Tree, Ancesty.com
1 DEAT
2 DATE 10 May 2004
2 PLAC Fredericton, New Brunswick, Canada
2 SOUR Daphne Baird Wetmore research.
2 SOUR Baird/Wetmore Family Tree, Ancesty.com
1 OBIT WETMORE, MAURICE P. - The death of Maurice Parker Wetmore of Fredericton, N.B.
2 CONT occurred on May 10, 2004 at the Veteran's Health Unit Fredericton. Born in
2 CONT Bloomfield, N.B. on September 14, 1919, he was the son of the late Boyd and
2 CONT Elsie Wetmore. Maurice graduated from UNB in 1942 (B.Sc. Forestry) and served
2 CONT in the RCAF overseas during WWII. He worked as a Forester for the provincial
2 CONT government until his retirement in 1978. He was an active member of Gibson Memorial
2 CONT United Church and enjoyed many hobbies including gardening, woodworking and photography.
2 CONT He is survived by his loving wife of 54 years, Eileen (Reicker); five children,
2 CONT Harvey (Barb), Ralph, Ronald (Noreen), Norma (Chuck) and Elsie (Georges); 10 grandchildren.
2 CONT Also survived by one sister, Bernice (Rev. Arthur Murray). Maurice was predeceased by two
2 CONT brothers, Raymond and Howard and two sisters, Edith and Lois. A memorial service will be
2 CONT held at Gibson Memorial United Church on Thursday, May 13th at 2:00 pm. A reception will
2 CONT follow in the church hall. Cremation has taken place and a private family burial service
2 CONT will be held at a later date in the Narrows United Church Cemetery. In lieu of flowers
2 CONT donations to the Alzheimers Society or to a charity of the donors choice would be
2 CONT appreciated by the family.
2 SOUR Daphne Baird Wetmore research.

1 NOTE The obituary of his father, Horace H. Wetmore, gives his name as
2 CONT Roy Whetmore.
1 OBIT Roy Harris Whetmore 80, Halifax Roy Whetmore died Jan. 29, 2009, at Northwood Centre,
2 CONT Halifax, N.S. Born in Windsor, N.S., Roy was the son of Blanche and Hoarce Wetmore of
2 CONT Coxheath, C.B.
2 CONT Early in his career, Roy served in the navy onboard ship and later as a hospital
2 CONT administrator holding rank of lieutenant commander at HMCS Cornwallis during the
2 CONT 1950s and 60s and later Stadacona Naval Base in Halifax. Following his retirement
2 CONT from the armed forces, he held executive positions at the 'old' Infirmary
2 CONT and Abbey Lane hospitals in Halifax. During this time his volunteer work included
2 CONT the development board of the original Cobequid Centre in Lower Sackville as well as
2 CONT a similar project later in Kanata, Ont. The move to Ottawa during the 1980s and 90s
2 CONT saw him holding a management position at the Queensway Carleton Hospital and volunteer
2 CONT work with Meals on Wheels.
2 CONT During the latter part of the 1990s he and his wife Mary, spent three years in Dalmeny, Sask.,
2 CONT where he was again active volunteering at the local seniors home. Following the death
2 CONT of his wife in Saskatchewan he moved back to Ottawa to be with family and then
2 CONT again to Nova Scotia in the early 2000s where he made his final home at the Berekley
2 CONT Manor in Bedford where he enjoyed a full and active life until the end.
2 CONT Roy is survived by his children, daughters, Kristene Murdock (husband Gavin), Bear River,
2 CONT N.S., Peggy Lynne Lacroix, Dartmouth, N.S., Roxanne (Autumn) Whetmore, Wellington, England;
2 CONT sons, Michael Whetmore (wife Becky), British Columbia, Patrick Whetmore (wife Maisie),
2 CONT Beaver Bank, N.S., MCpl Robert Whetmore CD1 (wife Fletia), Fredericton, N.B.,
2 CONT Sgt Richard Whetmore CD1, Whitehorse, YT. Grandchildren include Vanessa Murdock,
2 CONT Scott Murdock, Christopher Lacroix, Nicholas Autumn, Colin Whetmore, Jeremy Whetmore,
2 CONT Travis Whetmore, Tori Whetmore, Roxanne Whetmore and Logan Whetmore.Roy is survived by
2 CONT two sisters, Elizabeth Matheson, Marion Bridge, C.B., and Catherine Smith, Truro, N.S.
2 CONT He was predeceased by his wife, Mary Logan. A funeral service will be held for Mr. Whetmore
2 CONT at Cruikshank's Funeral Home Chapel, 2032 Robie St., Halifax, on Thursday, Feb. 5 at 2 p.m.
2 CONT Online condolences may be placed by visiting http.www.mem.com.
2 SOUR Daphne Baird Wetmore research.

1 DEAT
2 DATE 18 April 2008
2 PLAC Saint John, New Brunswick, Canada
2 SOUR Daphne Baird Wetmore research.
1 OBIT WETMORE, THOMAS O. (1948-2008)- Tom Wetmore passed away peacefully on
2 CONT April 18, 2008 after a long and courageous battle with Huntington's Disease.
2 CONT The son of the late Wilfred O. and Leona A. Wetmore and brother, David, Tom
2 CONT is survived by wife, Sharon (Keith) Wetmore; daughter, Kelli Wetmore and
2 CONT grand daughter, Chloe Wetmore, along with special nieces, Robyne and Brandi
2 CONT and many other beloved family members. Tom was employed with Peoples Jewelers
2 CONT as a Manager and Regional Supervisor, making many friends, coworkers and
2 CONT customers alike, throughout his career. He was a devoted family man, an avid
2 CONT sports fan and a loyal and reliable friend. He enjoyed the outdoors and many
2 CONT sports associated activites, among his favorites hockey and golf. Following
2 CONT cremation, visitation will take place at Brenan's Select Community Funeral Home,
2 CONT 111 Paradise Row, Saint John, NB, (634-7424) on Tuesday, April 22, 2008 from
2 CONT 7-9 pm. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, April 23, 2008 from All
2 CONT Saints Anglican Church, Clifton Royal at 11:00 am. Interment will take place in
2 CONT All Saints Anglican Church Cemetery. Remembrances may be made to the Huntington
2 CONT Society of Canada. www.brenansfh.com
2 SOUR Daphne Baird Wetmore research.

1 NAME Eric Lawrence /Teed/
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE 1926
2 SOUR 16pp
1 OBIT
2 TEXT
3 CONT Obituary
3 CONT Eric Teed
3 CONT May 19, 1926 to December 30, 2010 - We sadly announce the sudden passing of
3 CONT Eric Lawrence Teed, O.C.,C.D, Q.C., Kt.D., B.Sc., B.C.L., B.A of Saint John, New Brunswick, Canada
3 CONT on December 30, 2010. Born in Saint John on May 19, 1926, he was the son of
3 CONT Muriel Vivian (Wetmore) and John Francis Hannington Teed, Q.C.
3 CONT Survived by his wife of 61 years, Lois Anita (Smith), sons: Robert,
3 CONT Peter (Cathie Hurley) of Saint John, Christopher (Brenda) of Saint Stephen,
3 CONT Terrence (Karen) of Moncton, David (Julia) of Saint John,
3 CONT grandchildren: Allyson, Gregory, Sheena, Elliott (Anna), Laura, Daniel, Harrison, Stephanie,
3 CONT Emily and Andrew, and two great-grandchildren, Oliver and Dawson.
3 CONT Also survived by his brother Hugh (Betty) of Toronto,
3 CONT and sisters Gloria Trivett (Donald) of Clifton Royal, NB and Mary Gillis of Nova Scotia,
3 CONT he was predeceased by his brother George, and sisters Hazel Hazen, Beth Young, and Alice.
3 CONT Called to the Bar of NB in 1949, he had a distinguished law career for 60 years,
3 CONT retiring in June 2009. Appointed a Master of the Supreme Court of NB in 1958
3 CONT and Queen's Counsel in 1966, his list of service to his profession is extensive
3 CONT and there are few committees at the provincial or national level in which he did not participate.
3 CONT Extremely knowledgeable and passionate about law, he loved to share his knowledge and lectured
3 CONT on environmental, municipal, labour and civil liberties law at UNBSJ.
3 CONT Founding Editor of the University of New Brunswick Law Journal,
3 CONT he also served as a Member of the Board of Governors for University of New Brunswick,
3 CONT a Member of the UNBSJ Senate, and as President of the UNB Alumni (Saint John Chapter).
3 CONT It was during his tenure as Mayor for the City of Saint John that the Tucker Park lands
3 CONT were granted to establish the current UNBSJ campus. Eric's service to his community,
3 CONT for which he had great passion and love, was extensive.
3 CONT He served two terms as Mayor of Saint John from 1960 to 1964;
3 CONT served as an MLA for Saint John from 1970-74;
3 CONT and as a Councillor of the City of Saint John from 2001-2004.
3 CONT He served with the New Brunswick Scottish Regiment, attaining the rank of Captain,
3 CONT He was appointed a Knight of the Order of Dannebrog for his many years
3 CONT service as the Danish Consul in New Brunswick. Eric was a Freemason and
3 CONT a Past Master of Albion Lodge, and was an Honorary Member of the
3 CONT Bricklayers, Masons and Plasterers International Union. In recognition of his long standing
3 CONT community service, he was appointed an Officer of the Order of Canada in 1987.
3 CONT He was awarded the Queen's Silver Jubilee Medal in 1977 and the Queen's 50th Jubilee Medal in 1992.
3 CONT His opinion, knowledge and expertise were often sought concerning human rights and civil liberties.
3 CONT Involved in numerous organizations, he had served as President of the Saint John Charter Rights
3 CONT and Civil Liberties Association, President of the John Howard Society of New Brunswick, Canada
3 CONT (Saint John Branch), a founding member of the Elizabeth Fry Society,
3 CONT Secretary of the NB Human Rights Association, President of the Multicultural
3 CONT Association of Saint John, Honorary Counsel for the NB Anti-Poverty Association,
3 CONT and he had a lifelong commitment to the Scouting movement, serving as a Scout Master
3 CONT and later as Honorary Counsel for Scouts New Brunswick. Eric was a passionate historian and
3 CONT worked to ensure that Saint John's role in the history of New Brunswick was recognized.
3 CONT Over the years he served as Historian and President of the Saint George's Society of Saint John,
3 CONT Chairman of the Fort La Tour Development Authority, President of the Saint John
3 CONT Horticultural Association, as a member of the Rockwood Park Advisory Board,
3 CONT Editor of the NB Historical Society Collections, President of the Loyalist Zone NB
3 CONT Senior Citizens Federation, and President of Seniors Information and Resource Centre.
3 CONT Eric was a published author and enjoyed contributing to the local news media.
3 CONT Eric and Lois enjoyed traveling, and visited all corners of the world.
3 CONT Eric Lawrence Teed's passion and generosity will be sadly missed by his family,
3 CONT his friends, the legal community, his City and his Province.
3 CONT
3 CONT Resting at Brenan's Funeral Home, 111 Paradise Row, Saint John (634-7424),
3 CONT with visiting on Sunday, January 2, 2011 from 1 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM and
3 CONT Monday, January 3, 2011 from 2 to 5 PM. The funeral service will be held
3 CONT from Trinity Anglican Church on Tuesday, January 4, 2011 at 12:00 Noon.
3 CONT Interment will take place in All Saint's Cemetery, Clifton Royal, at a later date.
3 CONT For those who wish, remembrances to any charity of the donor's choice would be
3 CONT appreciated by the family. Online condolences may be placed at www.brenansfh.com.
3 CONT
3 CONT Members of the Mesonic Lodge will gather for a tribute service on Sunday at 7pm at the funeral home.

1 EVEN Email received
2 DATE 9 June 1996
2 FROM Thomas E. Wetmore
2 SUBJ Another Thomas Wetmore
2 ADDR wetmore@mi.net
2 TO Thomas Wetmore, ttw@shore.net
2 TEXT My father's family came from Bloomfield, Kings County, NB.
3 CONT He lived on the family farm until 1967.
3 CONT Judge David Brown Wetmore (1764-1846) divided his land amongst
3 CONT his five sons.
3 CONT My great-great-grandfather, Thomas Wetmore (1807) was one of
3 CONT those sons.
3 CONT There are two grave stones in Bloomfield that say Thomas Wetmore
3 CONT from the 1800's.
3 CONT My mom has lots of information.
3 CONT
3 CONT Rev. James (1695)
3 CONT James (1727)
3 CONT David Brown Wetmore (1764)
3 CONT Thomas (1807)
3 CONT Oscar (1847)
3 CONT Frank (1898)
3 CONT Stanley (1952)
3 CONT Thomas (1980)
3 CONT Where do you fit into the family tree?

1 NAME Hezekiah /Wetmore/

1 TITL Captain
1 BIRT
2 DATE 22 April 1726
2 PLAC Middletown, Connecticut Colony
1 DEAT
2 PLAC West Indies
1 LETR from George Washington to Hezikiah Wetmore
2 CONT Head Quarters, January 8, 1783.
2 CONT Sir: In the regulation for paying Subsistence to the Officers of the Army it
2 CONT was not considered that the Officers of Cavalry are allowed more servants without
2 CONT Arms than those of the Infantry.
2 CONT Untill the Secy at War shall give further directions on this head you will please
2 CONT to pay to the Officers of Cavalry subsistence for the number of Servants without
2 CONT Arms allowed them by the regulation made by a Board of Genl. officers in Philada.
2 CONT last Winter and published in the Genl Orders of the 18th Jany last. 29
2 SOUR on the web from Washinton's papers
1 SOUR JCW

0 @I3668@ INDI
1 NAME Charles Escott /Hancock/ Jr
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE 27 August 1932
2 PLAC Jamestown, New York, United States
2 SOUR Obituary
1 RESI
2 PLAC Raleigh, North Carolina
2 ADDR 4708 Metcalf Drive  27609
1 NOTE He has married children, Deborah/Walter, Scott/Mandy, don't know which is his.
2 SOUR Letter to Thomas T Wetmore III
1 SOUR Richard J. Hancock
1 DEAT
2 DATE 13 February 2011
2 PLAC Raleigh, North Carolina, United States
2 SOUR Obituary
1 OBIT
2 TEXT Charles "Chuck" E. Hancock August 27, 1932 - February 13, 2011, Raleigh
3 CONT Charles E. Hancock died on February 13, 2011 after complications from heart surgery.
3 CONT Chuck was born in Jamestown, NY on August 27, 1932 but grew up in Michigan.
3 CONT He graduated from Kettering University in 1954 and entered the Army for 2 years during the Korean
3 CONT Conflict and was always proud of his military service as a "Korean Veteran".
3 CONT He returned to the University of Michigan to receive his BSIE undergraduate degree in 1957 and
3 CONT continued on at Michigan for his MBA graduate degree in 1958.
3 CONT He was president of the U of M ski club in 1957-58.
3 CONT He began his career as a consultant with Touche Ross and then The Sessions Company.
3 CONT While there, he wrote and published a text book on the Critical Path Method for project scheduling.
3 CONT He then joined General Mills for a 34 year career with it and succeeding companies,
3 CONT retiring in 1996 as Senior Vice President of Operations at GoodMark Foods, Inc. in Raleigh, NC.
3 CONT Chuck was an avid skier and skied all over the US and Europe.
3 CONT He became a member of the National Ski Patrol where he received an honorary National
3 CONT Appointment and rose to become Assistant Division Director of the Central Division and
3 CONT Treasurer of the Southern Division of NSPS.
3 CONT Because of his interest in first aid and rescue procedures, he became a loyal member
3 CONT of the American Red Cross where he taught first aid and CPR for 45 years.
3 CONT He also served on the Board of the local ARC chapter in Wake County for many years
3 CONT and was member of the Garner Rescue Squad for a number of years.
3 CONT Chuck was a member of St. Andrews Presbyterian Church where he served in many roles
3 CONT but was particularly proud of his duties during his three year stint as a Deacon.
3 CONT Chuck was predeceased by his daughter Wendi Ayn Hancock in 1985
3 CONT and his beloved wife of 46 years, Delphine Hancock, in 2004.
3 CONT He is survived by a daughter, Deborah, of Santa Fe, NM
3 CONT and a daughter, Catherine Coleman and her husband Buddy Coleman and his two grandchildren,
3 CONT Matthew and Adam Coleman of Wilmington, NC.
3 CONT He is also survived by his son, Scott Hancock, and his wife Amanda Hancock of Wilmington, NC.
3 CONT He was survived by his brother John "Penny" Hancock and his wife Marissa of Florida.
3 CONT He met Dr. Anne Fishel of Chapel Hill after his wife's death and they became soul mates and
3 CONT companions for many years of traveling, playing bridge, and attending UNC sporting events.
3 CONT A funeral service will be held 11:00 a.m. Friday, February 18, 2011 at Saint Andrews Presbyterian Church,
3 CONT 7506 Falls of Neuse Rd., Raleigh, NC 27615.
3 CONT The family will receive friends 7:00-9:00 p.m. Thursday, February 17th at Brown-Wynne Funeral Home,
3 CONT 1701 E. Millbrook Road, Raleigh, NC 27609.
3 CONT The family asked that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Wendi Ayn Hancock Memorial Fund
3 CONT at UNC Chapel Hill.
3 CONT This fund is in honor of Wendi and allows other women recognition and financial support for making
3 CONT life better at UNC Chapel Hill.
3 CONT Please send donations to P.O. Box 309 Chapel Hill, NC 27514.
3 CONT Condolences may be sent to www.BrownWynne.com
1 FAMC @F1035@
1 FAMS @F2415@

1 NAME Hillary Morrison /Cannell/

1 BIRT
2 DATE 14 July 1926
2 PLAC New Malden, Surrey, England
2 SOUR The New London "Day," January 2, 2011.
1 DEAT
2 DATE 28 December 2010
2 PLAC Clinton, Middlesex, Connecticut, United States
2 SOUR The New London "Day," January 2, 2011.
1 OBIT
2 TEXT Clinton - Hilary M. Smith, 84, of 91 East Main St., Clinton, formerly of Goshen Road,
3 CONT Waterford, passed away Tuesday night, Dec. 28, 2010, at her home.
3 CONT Mrs. Smith was born on July 14, 1926, in New Malven, Surrey, England,
3 CONT the daughter of Arthur and Eugenia (Greene) Cannell.
3 CONT She was married to Duncan R. Smith on Aug. 12, 1950, in New London. He passed away on Oct. 4, 2007.
3 CONT Her survivors include four daughters, Noelle Cormier of Canterbury, Valerie Smith of Hamden,
3 CONT Jillian Smith of East Lyme, and Diana Smith of Wisconsin;
3 CONT two grandchildren, Amanda Cormier and Tess Berry; and a great-grandson, Blake Berry.
3 CONT Byles Memorial Home, 99 Huntington St., New London, is assisting the family with services
3 CONT which will be held privately in Jordan Cemetery, Waterford.
2 SOUR The New London "Day," January 2, 2011.
1 BURI
2 DATE 3 January 2011
2 PLAC Waterford, New London County, Connecticut, United States
2 CEME Jordan Cemetery
2 SOUR Thomas T Wetmore III

1 DEAT
2 DATE 8 March 1993
2 PLAC Chesterfield, Connecticut
2 INST Chesterfield Convalescent Home
1 OBIT
2 DATE Wednesday, 10 March 1993
2 SOUR The New London "Day"
2 TEXT Groton -- Mabel Cox MacWhinney, 95, of Essex, a native of
3 CONT Noank, died Monday at the Chesterfield Convalescent Home in
3 CONT Chesterfield.
3 CONT She was born Nov. 14, 1897, in Noank, the daughter of
3 CONT Andrew and Jennie Escott Cox, and had been a resident of
3 CONT Essex since 1924.
3 CONT She was the widow of Thomas H. MacWhinney.
3 CONT Mrs. MacWhinney was the secretary of T. H. MacWhinney &
3 CONT Sons Construction Co. for many years.
3 CONT She was a member of the American Legion Auxilliary.
3 CONT She is survived by three sons, T. Martin MacWhinney of
3 CONT Oroville, Calif., and Escott H. MacWhinney and Andrew L.
3 CONT MacWhinney, both of Essex; one sister, Evelyn Rowley of
3 CONT Amston; four grandchildren; and three great-grandchildren.
3 CONT The funeral service will be at 2 p.m. Thursday at the
3 CONT Robinson, Wright & Weymer Funeral Home, 34 Main St.,
3 CONT Centerbrook.
3 CONT Burial will be in Centerbrook Cemetery.
3 CONT A calling hour will be from 1-2 p.m. Thursday at the
3 CONT funeral home.
3 CONT Donations in her memory may be made to the Essex Baptist
3 CONT Church, Prospect Street, Essex 06426; or to the Essex Fire
3 CONT Department No. 1, Prospect Street, Essex 06426.

1 REMV
2 DATE 1782
2 PLAC Danby, Vermont
2 INFO He settled on the farm later owned by Samuel Thompson.
3 CONT He made the first settlement in that part of the town.
3 CONT His log house stood on the west side of the highway,
3 CONT opposite the present dwelling-house.
3 CONT He subsequently settled on the homestead of his son Barton.
3 CONT In 1793 he built the present dwelling-house, which is one
3 CONT of the oldest framed houses in town.

2 TEXT Richard Westcoat, for misleading Jno Whitmore, was fined 10s to
3 CONT the countrey.

1 RESI
2 DATE 1642
2 PLAC Rippowam [soon Stamford], Connecticut
3 INFO now Rippowam?
1 EVEN Made member of General Court
2 DATE 6th of the 2d moneth, 1642
1 FREE made freeman
2 DATE 6th of the 2d moneth, 1642
2 INFO at General Court
1 COUR General Court
2 DATE 6th of the 2d moneth, 1642
2 INFO John Whitmore was admitted member of court and accepted charge of
3 CONT freeman.
2 SOUR @S1@
1 COUR
2 DATE 27th of Oct. 1643
2 PLAC New Haven, Connecticut
2 NOTE John Whitmore was a deputy from Stamford.
1 EVEN Land recorded
2 DATE 5th day of 2nd month of 1641
2 PLAC Whethersfield, Connecticut
2 TEXT The 2d month and 5 daie 1641, The lands of John Whitmore lying in
3 CONT Wethersfield on Connecticut river.  One piece whereon his house
3 CONT and barne standeth containing twelve acres and half more or
3 CONT less.  The ends abut against the Common or landing place, and
3 CONT part against the house lot of Robert Batte, west, and ye meadow
3 CONT Francis Norton east.  The side against ye lands of Ro. and Tho.
3 CONT Curtice north, and ye lands of Tho. Whitmore, Francis Norton, Mr.
3 CONT Denton, John Gossope and Tho. Coleman south.
2 SOUR Wethersfield town deeds, vol 1, p 121
3 SOUR @S1@

0 @I4177@ INDI
1 NAME Mindwell /Wetmore/
1 SEX F
1 BIRT
2 DATE 9 October 1760
2 SOUR JCW
1 INFO The following quote refers to this person:
2 CONT Frequently a girl's indenture would apprentice her
2 CONT specifically to both the husband and wife in a household, or
2 CONT to the wife alone, who would be her instructor in all the
2 CONT duties she would need to run her own household if she
2 CONT married, or to support herself as a servant.
2 CONT
2 CONT Mindwell Wetmore, the daughter of Thomas Wetmore, "one of the
2 CONT poor" of Middletown, was one of many such girls to be so
2 CONT apprenticed.
2 CONT She was sent for a year, in 1769, to Benjamin Wetmore of
2 CONT Waterbury to be "taught to read English well, and to do
2 CONT household work knitting spinning sewing and the like.
2 SOUR NAWCC Bulletin (National Association of Watch and Clock
3 CONT Collectors), August 1991, Volume 33/4, Number 273, page
3 CONT 411, "The Connecticut Apprentice," by Diana Ross McCain,
3 CONT an article that orignially appeared in the December 1989
3 CONT issue of "Early American Life."

2 SOUR Social Security Death Index
1 OBIT
2 DATE 8 November 2001
2 PLAC Allentown, Lehigh, Pennsylvania, United States
2 TEXT Robert E. Wetmore
3 CONT
3 CONT Robert E. Wetmore, 64, of Scranton, formerly of Effort, died Wednesday, Nov. 7, in the Veterans Center, Scranton.
3 CONT
3 CONT He was a truck driver for Consolidated Freightways and a member of the Teamsters Union.
3 CONT
3 CONT Born in Connecticut, he was a son of the late Elwood and Eleanor (Crane) Wetmore.
3 CONT
3 CONT He was a veteran of the Korean War
3 CONT
3 CONT Survivors: Son, Robert E. Jr of Stroudsburg, Michael of Tobyhanna, Monroe County, Steven in Florida;
3 CONT daughter Kathy Clare of East Stroudsburg; brothers Elwood of Huntsville, Ala., Arthur of Oaklawn, N.J.,
3 CONT Alfred in North Carolina; sister Shirley Faunce in Massachusetts; nine grandchildren; nieces, nephews.
3 CONT
3 CONT Memorial services: 2 p.m. Saturday, William H. Clark Funeral Home, 1003 Main St., Stroudsburg. No calling hours.

0 @I4703@ INDI
1 NAME Richard James/Wetmore/
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE 3 December 1966
3 NAME Richard James Wetmore
2 DATE 1966
3 SOUR Daphne Baird Wetmore research.
1 EVEN Email Received
2 FROM Richard James Wetmore
2 DATE 18 May 1996
2 EMAL SYWETMO@ibm.net
2 SUBJ Wetmore's In Canada
2 TEXT We were surfing the net and discovered your home page!
2 TEXT
2 TEXT My name is Richard James Wetmore, born 1966, (wife Shelley, nee
2 TEXT Chorney, born 1961).
2 TEXT My father's name is James Coster Raymond Wetmore and he was born
2 TEXT in New Brunswick.
2 TEXT His home there was a 150 year old family home, originally built by
2 TEXT a judge named A. K. Smeads Wetmore, who was appointed by the King
2 TEXT of England.
2 TEXT My family was originally Empire Loyalists who moved to Canada when
2 TEXT the thirteen colonies decided to separate from England.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Think we're related in some way?
1 EVEN Email Received
2 FROM Richard James Wetmore
2 DATE 19 May 1996
2 EMAL SYWETMO@ibm.net
2 SUBJ Wetmore's In Canada
2 TEXT Me (Richard James Wetmore) from my father (James Coster Raymond
2 TEXT Wetmore) from my grandfather (James Smeads Coster Wetmore) from
2 TEXT James Peters Wetmore from Abraham Kierstead Smeads Wetmore from
2 TEXT Reverend Robert Griffith Wetmore from ???
2 TEXT
2 TEXT If you'd like more information, contact my sister, Winona (Nona)
2 TEXT Dunn (nee Wetmore) who's done a lot of family history research.
2 TEXT She can be contacted at (506) 466-2335 in Saint Lawrence Station
2 TEXT in New Brunswick.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT My mother who lives in Galahad, Alberta also has a series of
2 TEXT documents - letters from A.K. Smeads' father to a friend detailing
2 TEXT events surrounding the birth of A.K. Smeads and to ask permission
2 TEXT to use his friend's name for his son.
2 TEXT He later wrote that his wife was dying and had to leave somewhere
2 TEXT and asked this friend to look after his son (A.K. Smeads).
2 TEXT Have other miscellaneous documents that have been passed down
2 TEXT through the generations. But, talk to Nona, she knows a lot.
1 SOUR Richard James Wetmore
1 SOUR Larry Wetmore, Needham, Mass.
1 SOUR 16pp

0 @I4747@ INDI
1 NAME James /Peters/
1 SEX M
1 TITL Judge
1 BIRT
2 DATE about 1745
2 PLAC prob New York
2 SOUR JCW
1 NOTE He was a New York loyalist to New Brunswick in 1783.
2 CONT He settled in New Brunswick in 1783, and was one of the
2 CONT agents to locate lands granted to the loyalists, who removed
2 CONT to that colony.
2 CONT Of the city of Saint John he was a grantee.
2 CONT In 1792 he was a magistrate of Queens county; also a member
2 CONT of the House of Assembly for a long period.
2 CONT He died at his seat at Gagetown, 1820 a.e. 75.
2 CONT His son, the Hon. Charles J. Peters, is the present (1847)
2 CONT Attorney General of N.B.
2 SOUR JCW
1 DEAT
2 DATE 1820
2 AGE a.e. 75 years
2 PLAC Gagetown, New Brunswick, Canada
2 SOUR JCW

0 @I5160@ INDI
1 NAME Appolos Russell /Wetmore/
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE 11 November 1796
2 PLAC Danbury, Connecticut, United States
2 SOUR JCW
1 RESI
2 PLAC New York, New York
2 SOUR JCW
1 DEAT
2 DATE 21 January 1881
2 PLAC New York, New York, United States
2 ADDR 33 West Ninth Street
2 SOUR New York Times Obituary
1 OBIT
2 TEXT DEATH OF MR. A. R. WETMORE
2 TEXT
2 TEXT HIS CONNECTION WITH MANY CHARITABLE WORKS
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Apollos Russell Wetmore, whose name has been prominently associated with the best philanthropic
2 TEXT efforts in the City for the last 25 or 30 years, died quietly in his bed at an early hour yesterday
2 TEXT morning, at the residence of his son-in-law, Mr. Charles E. Carryl, No. 33 West Ninth-street.
2 TEXT Mr. Wetmore retired to his room in his usual health on Thursday night, having passed the afternoon
2 TEXT in examining the affairs of the New York Juvenile Asylum, in which, as one of the founders, he was
2 TEXT particulary interested.
2 TEXT He left the office of the asylum about 5 o'clock, and went home.
2 TEXT Yesterday morning he did not make his appearance at the breakfast table as usual, and, after
2 TEXT waiting a few minutes, one of the members of the household went to his room.
2 TEXT He was found lying upon his bed in apparent repose, and had evidently expired in sleep without a struggle.
2 TEXT The extremities were still warm, showing that life had been extict only a few minutes--or an hour at furthest.
2 TEXT The event was not altogether unexpected, for, in addition to his advance age, Mr. Wetmore lived in
2 TEXT constant danger of apoplexy, and had been warned by his medical advisor that his demise would be sudden.
2 TEXT He had often observed that he had no dearer wish than "to die with the harness on."
2 TEXT For the last few years, since he retired from business in 1876, Mr. Wetmore had taken a particular interest
2 TEXT in various philanthropic movements, particularly in the Juvenile Asylum, the City Mission, the Association
2 TEXT for the Relief of the Poor, the Home for the Ruptured and Crippled, the Presbyterian Hospital, the Home
2 TEXT for Girls, ad the Woman's Hospital, one of the valuable featurs of which is the new Wetmore Pavilion.
2 TEXT In all of these institutions, as well as in the Tract Society, his assistance and advice were invaluable
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Mr. Wetmore was born in Danbury, Conn., Nov. 11, 1795, and inherited from his father, the Rev. Noah Wetmore,
2 TEXT a prominent minister, his bias for philanthropic enterprises.
2 TEXT When he was 13 years of age (in 1808) his father removed to this City, and became Superintendent of the New
2 TEXT York Hospital, which was then situated on Broadway.
2 TEXT In 1812 the son entered Columbia College, then at the foot of Marray-steet, but he did not graduate.
2 TEXT His health broke down under protracted study at the expiration of two years of college life, and in 1815
2 TEXT he entered the hardware store of Kip & Ingraham, where he remained for three years.
2 TEXT In 1818 he embarked in business for himself, in partnership with his brother, D. N. Wetmore, with whom he
2 TEXT remained until 1824, when he formed a copartnership with J. C. Green, who had served with him as a clerk.
2 TEXT The firm style was given as Green & Wetmore, and their establishment, at the corner of Washington and Vesey
2 TEXT streets, was for many years a landmark of the hardware trade in the City
2 TEXT The firm lasted for 11 years, at the expiration of which Mr. Green retired, and the business was continued
2 TEXT as Wetmore & Co.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT In 1830 Mr. Wetmore joined the Presbyterian church in Laight-street, under the pastorate of the
2 TEXT celebrated Dr. Cox.
2 TEXT From this date he had been active in all noble projects for the elevation of the dependent classes and the
2 TEXT rescue of the suffering.
2 TEXT in 1831, in conjunction with other prominent gentlemen, he founded the New York Tract Society, which was
2 TEXT incorporated at a later date with the City Mission, another of his philantrhopic creations.
2 TEXT The Presidency of this society was an office which he held for many years, and with which he was invested
2 TEXT at the time of his death.
2 TEXT He next gave his attention to the rescue of children from criminal and destructive influences, and thus laid
2 TEXT a firm basis for the work of the New York Juvenile Asylum, another of his philanthropic creations, of whose
2 TEXT Board of Managers he served as President for many years.
2 TEXT He was one of the active spirits in the foundation of the Society ofr Improving the Condition of the Poor,
2 TEXT and helped to bring into existence the Washing and Bathing Society, which however, perished after a few
2 TEXT years of precarious struggle.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT In 1822, at the age of 27, Mr. Wetmore was married to Mary Carmer, of this City, and eight years ago
2 TEXT celebrated his golden wedding with great ceremony.
2 TEXT Four years later, in 1876, Mrs. Wetmore died, and her bereaved husband took up his residence with one of
2 TEXT his married daughters, Mrs. Carryl.
2 TEXT Of the six children born of this marriage, the eldest, Henry C. Wetmore, is dead; the remaining five --
2 TEXT George C. Wetmore, Theodore R. Wetmore, William Wetmore, and the two daughters, Mrs. Henry Mesier and
2 TEXT Mrs. Charles E. Carryl--are well known in the highest social circles.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT As a philanthropist, Mr. Wetmore was regarded as a practical man in the management of institutions rather
2 TEXT than a theorist.
2 TEXT He believed in doing, not in talking, and devoted his time to results rather than theoretical explanations.
2 TEXT His name ranks with that of Howard and Peabody in this department of modern activity, and his association
2 TEXT with a project was considered a guarantee of both of the good faith of its promoters and of ultimate success.
2 TEXT Thousands of children during the last 20 years have owed their rescue from infamy and vice to his efforts,
2 TEXT and thousands of the City's poor have blessed his name as that of a benefactor.
2 TEXT His uprightness was a proverb, his kindness to the suffering a sunny spot in human experience.
2 TEXT The arrangements for the funeral have not been fully perfected.
2 TEXT The services will take place at 11  o'clock A.M. on Monday, at the Madison-Square Presbyterian Church,
2 TEXT the Rev. Mr. Parkhurst officiating and the Rev. Dr. Hall assisting.
2 TEXT Seats will be reserved for the delegates of the various boards with which he was associated, but other
2 TEXT details, such as the names of the pall-bearers, &c., remain to be announced hereafter.
2 SOUR New York Times
2 DATE Saturday, 22 January 1881

1 GRAD
2 DATE 1924
2 PLAC Cambridge, Massachusetts
2 DEGR Ph.D.
2 INST Harvard
2 SOUR obit in "Harvard Magazine," Sep-Oct 1989
1 RESI
2 DATE early 1940s
2 PLAC Cambridge, Middlesex, Massachusetts
3 ADDR 12 Frances Avenue
2 EMPL Harvard University
2 SOUR World War II Draft Registration
1 NOTE He was professor of botany emeritus at Harvard, where he taught
2 CONT from 1926 to 1962, chairing his department and serving as
2 CONT director of the biological laboratories.
2 CONT His research focused on the differentiation of plant
2 CONT structures during growth.
2 CONT A member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and the
2 CONT National Academy of Science, he was a past president of the
2 CONT Society for the Study of Growth and Development.
2 CONT His wife, Olive (Smith), A.M. '27, died in 1982.
2 CONT He leaves two daughters, Jean Buell '51 and Katerine Worssam
2 CONT '47.

0 @I5595@ INDI
1 NAME Raymond Eugene /Wetmore/
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE 4 August 1904
2 PLAC New Haven, Connecticut, United States
2 SOUR Obit below
1 DEAT
2 DATE 4 December 2005
2 PLAC Riverview, New Brunswick, Canada
1 BURI
2 DATE 7 December 2005
2 PLAC Yarmouth, Nova Scotia, Canada
2 CEME Mountain Cemetery
1 OBIT
2 TEXT Raymond Eugene Wetmore 1904 - 2005.
2 TEXT The death of Raymond Eugene Wetmore, 101 years, husbnd of the late Katherine
2 TEXT Wetmore, occurred at Royal Court, Riverview, on Sunday, December 4th, 2005.
2 TEXT Born in New Haven, Connecticut, on August 4, 1904, he was the son of the late Jesse E.
2 TEXT and Antoinette (Moses) Wetmore. Raymond attended the Yarmouth Academy and graduated
2 TEXT from Acadia University in 1926; re received his B.Sc. in Mechanical Engineering from
2 TEXT Nova Scotia Technical College in 1928; he was retired as a Lubrication Engineer from
2 TEXT Texaco Canada, Inc. He was a life member of the Association of Professional
2 TEXT Engineers of NB, a 60 year member of Hiram Lodge #12 AF&AM of Yarmouth, a past member
2 TEXT of the Moncton Golf and Country Club; a Pasrt Member of the Moncton Curlers Association;
2 TEXT he was a member of the Wesley Memorial United Church, Moncton. The last surviving
2 TEXT member of his immediate family, Raymond is survived by several nieces and nephews.
2 TEXT He was predeceased by his wife, Katherine (Dayson) Wetmore in 1980 and his parents.
2 TEXT In keeping with Mr. Wetmore's requestsw there will not be any visiting or funeral
2 TEXT service in Moncton. a Masonic Service conducted by officers and members of Hiram
2 TEXT Lodge #12 AF&AM, followed by  funeral service will be conducted at Sweeney's Funeral
2 TEXT Home in Yarmouth, NS, on Wednesday, December 7, 2005, at 2 pm. Interment will be in
2 TEXT Mountain Cemetery in Yarmouth, NS. Arrangements in Moncton are under the direction
2 TEXT of Cadman Bowness Funeral Home, (857-1110) 114 Alma Street, Moncton, www.cadmnbownessfh.com

1 FAMS @F1586@
0 @I5602@ INDI
1 NAME Sabra Moses /Wetmore/
1 SEX F
1 BIRT
2 DATE 1902
1 DEAT
2 DATE 28 November 1998
2 PLAC Halifax, Nova Scotia, Canada
1 OBIT
2 TEXT ELLIS (Wetmore), Sabra Moses - 96, Hebron, Yarmouth Co., died peacefully, at the home of her
3 CONT daughter in Halifax, on November 28, 1998. Born in Springdale, Digby Co., she was a daughter of the
3 CONT late Albert Stephen and Annie (Porter) Wetmore. She was a member of the Cedar Lake Baptist Church
3 CONT and taught school in Nova Scotia for five years. Then, in 1926, she went to the United States where she
3 CONT took a business course and worked in the real estate and insurance office of Rugg and Yerxa,
3 CONT Watertown, Mass. She returned to Nova Scotia in 1929, having accepted an offer from Mr. Yerxa to be
3 CONT secretary/accountant in his Nova Scotia business, Yerxa's Grocery Chain, with the head office in
3 CONT Wolfville. Later, after this business was dispersed, she worked in the office of H. T. Warne Company,
3 CONT Digby, and during the Second World War was in the civil service at the Yarmouth airport, West Camp,
3 CONT Works and Building section under Flight Lieutenant Vye. She married in 1943, her husband being in
3 CONT the Canadian Army Engineers. He was sent overseas that summer and she continued work at the
3 CONT airport until June 1945 when her husband, who was seriously wounded in April of that year, was
3 CONT invalided home in June. At that time she terminated her employment and the Ellis' retired to their
3 CONT home in Springdale and later moved to Hebron. She is survived by a daughter, Karen (Mrs. Douglas
3 CONT Russell), Halifax; grandchildren, Gillian and Bruce; nephew, Calvin Holman, Belmont, Mass.; niece,
3 CONT Mrs. Lois Holman, Georgia; several grandnieces and grandnephews. She was predeceased by her
3 CONT husband, William Ernest; sisters, Jessie (Mrs. Raymond Holman), formerly of Watertown, Mass.;
3 CONT Alberta in infancy. Visitation 2-4, 7-9 p.m. Tuesday with funeral 2 p.m. Wednesday, all in Sweeny's
3 CONT Funeral chapel, Yarmouth, Rev. Ulric Dawson officiating. Burial in Cedar Lake Cemetery. Donations
3 CONT may be made to Canadian Cancer Society or a charity of a choice.
2 SOUR Halifax Herald, Nov. 30, 1998

2 SOUR JCW
1 FAMC @F1769@
0 @I6118@ INDI
1 NAME Charles Hinckley/Wetmore/
1 SEX M
1 TITL Doctor
1 BIRT
2 DATE 8 February 1820
2 PLAC Lebanon, Connecticut
1 GRAD
2 PLAC Pittsfield, Massachusetts
2 INST Massachusetts Medical College
1 RESI
2 PLAC Lebanon, Connecticut
1 REMV
2 DATE 14 October 1848
2 PLAC Hilo, Sandwich Islands
2 NOTE They were missionaries.
1 DEAT
2 DATE 13 May 1898
2 PLAC Hilo, Hawaii
1 BIO
2 TEXT Charles Hinckley Wetmore was born at Lebanon, Connecticut, on
3 NOTE February 8, 1820.
3 NOTE By teaching school in the winter and studying in the summer, he
3 NOTE attained his medical degree, graduating from the Berkshire Medical
3 NOTE Institute in Massachusetts in 1846.
3 NOTE After graduation Dr. Wetmore practiced in Lowell, Massachusetts,
3 NOTE while continuing to teach to supplement his income.
3 NOTE Taking service as a missionary doctor under the American Mission
3 NOTE Board, Dr. Wetmore married Lucy Sheldon Taylor on September 25,
3 NOTE 1848, at Pittsfield, Massachusetts, just three weeks prior to
3 NOTE sailing for Hawaii.
3 NOTE The doctor was not attached to any Missionary Company; and he and
3 NOTE his bride took passage on the "Leland", arriving in Honolulu
3 NOTE March 11, 1849, after a voyage of 146 days.
3 NOTE
3 NOTE The Wetmores were assigned to Hilo, Hawaii, and were at their new
3 NOTE post by May 18.
3 NOTE Dr. Wetmore considered that his first professional duty was to care
3 NOTE for the missionary families, then the natives, and after that the
3 NOTE foreigners.
3 NOTE His patients were scattered over the entire island, and he
3 NOTE traveled by canoe, when this was possible, but mostly by foot.
3 NOTE On many occasions Mrs. Wetmore accompanied him.
3 NOTE
3 NOTE In 1850 the Wetmore's first child, a son, was stillborn.
3 NOTE It was out of their grief for the loss of this child that they
3 NOTE were led to establish a school for half-caste children that same
3 NOTE year.
3 NOTE The children, who numbered 13 that first year, were, with one
3 NOTE exception, Chinese-Hawaiian.
3 NOTE Three years later a second son, Charles Hinckley, Jr., was born
3 NOTE (who died in his 14th. year), in 1855 Frances Matilda was born,
3 NOTE then Catherine (Mrs. Henry Deacon) in 1859, and in 1860 Lucy
3 NOTE Taylor (Mrs. Charles Lewis).
3 NOTE
3 NOTE The smallpox epidemic of 1853 resulted in 75 deaths in the Hilo
3 NOTE and Puna districts.
3 NOTE That the death toll was no higher was due to Dr. Wetmore's
3 NOTE vaccination program and his countermeasures.
3 NOTE In 1855 he severed his connections with the American Board of
3 NOTE Missions.
3 NOTE During that same year the doctor was appointed physician and
3 NOTE purveyor to the United States Seamen's Hospital in Hilo.
3 NOTE In 1856 Dr. Wetmore began building Hilo's first drug store.
3 NOTE Placed in charge of the government dispensary for sick and indigent
3 NOTE Hawaiians in September, 1862, he received a salary of $300 per year.
3 NOTE
3 NOTE In 1871 Dr. and Mrs. Wetmore and their two daughters took a trip
3 NOTE to the United States--their first in 23 years.
3 NOTE In 1877 Dr. Wetmore made a second visit.
3 NOTE After the death of Mrs. Wetmore in 1883, the doctor, serving as a
3 NOTE delegate from the Hawaiian Board, and his daughter, Lucy, spent
3 NOTE the entire year of 1885 in the Marshall and Caroline Islands.
3 NOTE
3 NOTE In partnership with Mr. David H. and Edward G. Hitchcock Dr.
3 NOTE Wetmore helped to establish and manage Papaikou Sugar Plantation
3 NOTE but withdrew in 1883.
3 NOTE He also had interests in Kohala and other sugar plantations, as
3 NOTE well as in the Hilo Soda Works.
3 NOTE In 1889 he was a candidate of the Reform Party for the House of
3 NOTE Nobles but was not elected.
3 NOTE
3 NOTE Dr. Wetmore died May 13, 1898, at Hilo at the age of 78.
3 NOTE
3 NOTE The doctor was a long time trustee of the Hilo Boarding School,
3 NOTE served as deacon of the First Foreign Church in 1867, and was a
3 NOTE member of the Hawaiian Society of the Sons of the American
3 NOTE Revolution.
3 NOTE A stamp collector, he sold his entire collection in 1897 to help
3 NOTE raise funds for the new Hilo Foreign Church.
3 NOTE He was a lover of nature and was interested in botany, astronomy,
3 NOTE and mineralogy.
