0 @I6137@ INDI
1 NAME Victorine Upsher /Wetmore/
1 SEX F
1 DEAT
2 DATE 4 April 1915
2 PLAC New London, New London, Connecticut, United States
2 ADDR 505 Pequot Avenue
1 OBIT
2 TEXT DEATH OF MRS. B. P. LEARNED
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Well Known Woman Passed Away at Her Home Sunday Evening
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Mrs Victorine Upshur Learned, wife of Billings P. Learned, died at her home,
2 TEXT 605 Pequot avenue, Sunday night about 10 o'clock. Mr. [sic] Learned had been
2 TEXT a sufferer for the six days from bronchial pneumonia and complication developed
2 TEXT which caused her death.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Mrs. Learned was a daughter of the late Robert C. Wetmore of New York.
2 TEXT She and Mr. Learned were married in New York in 1893.
2 TEXT Besides her husband Mrs. Learned is survived by a sister, Miss Florence A. Wetmore
2 TEXT and two daughters, Mrs. Draper Clark of Paris and Mrs. Henry May of Babylon, L. I.
2 TEXT
2 TEXT Mrs. Learned had for years been actively engaged in charitable work.
2 TEXT She was intensely interested in the work of the Conecticut Humane society.
2 TEXT Since the outbreak of the war Mrs. Learned had given extenisvely of means and time to
2 TEXT the efforts to alleviate the sufferings of Belgians and the soldiers.
2 TEXT Mrs. Learned was a communicant and an active worker in St. James' church.
2 TEXT The funeral services are to be held there on Wednesday
1 SOUR JCW

1 FAMC @F1798@
0 @I6204@ INDI
1 NAME Frances Matilda/Wetmore/
1 NAME Fannie/Wetmore/
1 SEX F
1 TITL Doctor
1 BIRT
2 DATE 24 July 1855
2 DATE 29 June 1855
2 PLAC Hilo, Hawaii, Hawaii
3 NOTE Then the Sandwich Islands.
2 SOUR Sanford Wetmore's Ancestry.com tree.
1 DEAT
2 DATE 12 March 1919
2 PLAC Hilo, Hawaii, Hawaii
2 SOUR Sanford Wetmore's Ancestry.com tree.
1 BIO
2 TEXT Frances Matilda Wetmore was born June 29, 1855, at Hilo, Hawaii.
3 NOTE She was the daughter of the missionary doctor, Charles Hinckley
3 NOTE Wetmore, and his wife, Lucy Sheldon Taylor Wetmore.
3 NOTE
3 NOTE On July 26, 1867, Frances' beloved brother, Charlie, died suddenly
3 NOTE at the age of fourteen.
3 NOTE This tragedy served to strengthen her desire to become a doctor.
3 NOTE At fifteen she had exhausted all that local sources could offer in
3 NOTE the way of education, and in April, 1870, she was sent to
3 NOTE relatives in New England to continue her studies.
3 NOTE There she attended Mount Holyoke College at South Hadley,
3 NOTE Massachusetts.
3 NOTE
3 NOTE After graduation, Frances returned to Hilo where the greater part
3 NOTE of her time was spent in her father's drug store.
3 NOTE In Dr. Wetmore's absence, she waited on customers and helped
3 NOTE patients.
3 NOTE So successful was she in caring for their needs that Dr. Wetmore
3 NOTE wrote to his sister that people were sending for her to doctor
3 NOTE them and added, "she will use her needle better in surgery, I
3 NOTE think, than for anything else."
3 NOTE
3 NOTE In 1879 Frances left Hilo to enter Woman's Medical college in
3 NOTE Philadelphia.
3 NOTE Apparently, she received her M.D. by the end of 1882, since by
3 NOTE January, 1883, she had returned to Hilo and was her father's
3 NOTE partner.
3 NOTE Affectionately known as Dr. Fanny, she was beloved by the
3 NOTE Hawaiians and had a circle of friends including nearly everyone on
3 NOTE Hawaii.
3 NOTE In 1888 she was appointed government physician for Hilo by the
3 NOTE Board of Health, in all probability, the first woman to ever hold
3 NOTE such a position in the Islands. Her salary was $600 a year.
3 NOTE In 1989 she was made consulting physician at Hilo Hospital.
3 NOTE
3 NOTE In the course of a long and active life, Dr. Fanny was a member of
3 NOTE the Cousins' Society (from 1856), Woman's Board of Missions of the
3 NOTE First Foreign Church, trustee of the property of the Aloha Circle
3 NOTE of King's Daughters and Sons (charter member in 1889), secretary
3 NOTE of the Free Kindergarten Committee, trustee of the Hilo Boarding
3 NOTE School (from 1898), and trustee of the Hilo Public Library.
3 NOTE
3 NOTE On March 12, 1919, Dr. Wetmore died at Hilo with a few months of
3 NOTE her 64th. birthday.
1 SOUR @S1@
1 SOUR @S7@

1 FAMC @F1861@
0 @I6401@ INDI
1 NAME James Carnahan /Wetmore/
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE 1 May 1813
2 PLAC Whitestown, Oneida County, New York
2 SOUR JCW
1 CHR
2 DATE 9 July 1813
2 RECR Rev. John Frost
2 SOUR JCW
1 DEAT
2 DATE 12 August 1895
2 PLAC Elizabeth, New Jersey
2 AGE 82
2 SOUR Obituary in New York Times, August 14, 1895
1 OBIT
2 TEXT James C. Wetmore died Monday at his home in Elizabeth, N.J., aged eighty two.
3 CONT He was a member of the Stock Exchange in New York from 1850 to 1856.`
3 CONT He was a direct descendant of Elder Brewster of the Mayflowr,
3 CONT and a cousin of ex-Gov. and Senator Wetmore from Rhode Island.
3 CONT Mr. Wetmore's father was the Rev. Oliver Wetmore, a Presbyterian
3 CONT missionary among the Indians.
3 CONT The son was born at Wellsborough, N.Y., May 1, 1813.
3 CONT Mr. Wetmore spent many years in business in the South, and helped to build
3 CONT the Yazoo Canal, in Mississippi.
3 CONT He was the State Military Agent for Ohio during the war, and a prominent
3 CONT member of the Sanitary Comission.
3 CONT He was on intimate terms with Lincoln, Grant, Stanton, Chase, and the
3 CONT other noted men of that period.
3 CONT Gov. Tom Corwin of Ohio died at Mr. Wetmore's residence, in Washington,
3 CONT at a reception given to Ohioans.
3 CONT Mr. Wetmore was one of the Vestrymen of old Saint John's Church, in Washington.
3 CONT In 1851 he married Catherine Mary De Hart Chetwood of Elizabeth, a daughter
3 CONT of Major William Chetwood, and sister of the late Mayor Francis B. Chetwood.
3 CONT She and one son survive him.
2 SOUR New York Times, August 14, 1895

1 NAME George Melancthon /Wetmore/
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE 31 August 1858
2 PLAC Gate Township, Monroe County, New York
1 EDU Public Schools
1 EDU Dr. Dinan's Military School, Rochester, New York
1 EDU Rochester Business Institute, Rochester, New York
1 NOTE He was vice president of the American Chemical Manufacturing
2 CONT and Mining Co., Rochester, New York, for almost 20 years.
2 CONT He founded the Shinola Co., Rochester, New York, and was its
2 CONT president.
2 CONT He was also vice president of the Monroe Novelty Co., and
2 CONT director of the F. F. Dalley Co.
2 CONT He was a trustee of the Rochester Theological Seminary and a
2 CONT member of the Rochester Chamber of Commerce.

2 DATE 6 November 1633
1 EVEN Representative in General Court
2 DATE 1634
1 NOTE He was among the first settlers of Hartford, Connecticut.
1 REMV
2 DATE 1635 or May 1636
2 PLAC Hartford, Connecticut, United States
1 REMV
2 DATE 1659
2 PLAC Hadley, Massachusetts
1 NOTE He was also among the first settlers of Hadley, Massachusetts.
1 DEAT
2 DATE 11 March 1673
2 PLAC Hadley, Massachusetts
1 TEXT William, Cambridge, came to Boston in the Lion, arrived 16
2 CONT September 1632, freeman November 6, following year,
2 CONT representative in the first Gen. Court of dep. in Mass, 1634,
2 CONT removed next year or more probably in May, 1636, to Hartford,
2 CONT where was in highest esteem, ardent friend of famous Hooker,
2 CONT and after his dec. dissatisfaction with Stone, upon
2 CONT controversy of many years before and after 1654, removed to
2 CONT Hadley with large part of congregation about 1659, thence
2 CONT about 1670 to Farmington; he was ruling elder at both
2 CONT Hartford and Hadley.
1 SOUR Ancestry of Lawrence Williams, C.B. Williams, 1915
1 SOUR Descendants of John Dwight of Dedham
1 FAMC @F4328@
1 FAMS @F3919@
1 FAMS @F3921@

2 DATE 17 May 1676
1 SOUR "Ancestry of Lawrence Williams," C.B. Williams, 1915
1 SOUR Genserve vanw1
1 FAMC @F3920@
1 FAMS @F3919@
0 @I11037@ INDI
1 NAME Robert/White/
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE November 1560
2 PLAC England
1 RESI
2 PLAC Shalford, Essex County, England
2 DATE by 1585 until near death
1 BURI
2 DATE 17 June 1617
2 PLAC Messing, Essex County, England
1 NOTE Robert White was born in England.
2 CONT He was buried in Messing, Essex Co, England, 17 June 1617.
2 CONT He married twice; his first wife is not known.
2 CONT They had one child, Daniel.
2 CONT Robert White's second wife was Bridget Allgar, baptized 11 March
2 CONT 1562.
2 CONT They were married 24 June 1585 in Shalford, Essex Co, England.
2 CONT Robert and Bridget resided in Shalford from the time of their
2 CONT marriage until just before Robert's death.
2 CONT The baptisms of nearly all his children are recorded there, as
2 CONT are the marriages of his daughters Mary and Elizabeth.
1 NOTE Robert was a man of influence and wealth.
2 CONT His four daughters all married men who made their marks in the New
2 CONT World; it is believed that Mary Loomis, Elizabeth Goodwin and
2 CONT Anna Porter came with their husbands to New England.
1 SOUR "Ancestry of Lawrence Williams," C.B. Williams, 1915
1 SOUR Genserve vanw1
1 SOUR Genserve janis1

1 SOUR CAT
1 TEXT William Lewis, Sr, came from England in the ship "Lion"
2 CONT landing in Boston 16 Sept 1632; was admitted freeman in
2 CONT November, and joined the Braintree company, which, in Aug
2 CONT 1633, removed to Newtown (Cambridge).
2 CONT In 1636 he came with a company to Hartford and in 1659 again
2 CONT removed and became one of the founders of Hadley, Mass, which
2 CONT town he represented in General Court in 1662.
2 CONT He resided in Northampton in 1664, and some time before
2 CONT Nov 29, 1677, he removed to Farmington, Connecticut.
2 SOUR "Sketches of Southington, Connecticut," by Tinlow.

1 SOUR Savage; CAT
1 NOTE Thomas and his brother John were very early settlers of
2 CONT Wethersfield, Connecticut; had cattle ear-mark recorded
2 CONT in 1653; was relieved by an order of the General Court 21 May
2 CONT 1657 from training, watching and warding; a man of good
2 CONT reputation and large estate - inventory taken 9 December 1681
2 CONT by Nathaniel Boreman, Samuel Butler and William Warner to
2 CONT pounds 717-13-09; admin gr to his sons, John, Joseph and James
2 CONT and Mr. Kimberly; his son Samuel having rec'd his portion he
2 CONT died, before his father's death.
2 CONT His children agreed to a division of the estate which was made
2 CONT by Lieut James Treat, Stephen Chester and Samuel Wolcott under
2 CONT a decree of the Probate Court, dated 2 March 1681/2.
1 NOTE There is a family tradition, unsupported by any records, that he
2 CONT was a physician.
1 SOUR some material from "Genealogies and Biographies of Ancient
2 CONT Wethersfield", by Stiles, as communicated by G.L. Jensen

1 SOUR CAT; Savage
1 NOTE Matthew Woodruff came from Hartford to Farmington ca 1640/1,
2 CONT and died very old, ca 1682.
2 CONT He was one of the eighty four proprietors of Farmington in
2 CONT 1672, having been admitted a freeman in 1657.
2 CONT His wife, Hannah, was admitted to the church in Farmington,
2 CONT 2 April 1654.
2 SOUR "Southington, Connecticut," by Timlow.
1 TEXT Matthew, Farmington, an orig. propr. by w. Hannah wh. join.
2 CONT the ch. 2 Apr. 1645, had John, b. 1643; Matthew, 1646; Hannah,
2 CONT 1648; Eliz. 1651, all bapt. at once, 2 Apr.; and Mary, 5 Nov.
2 CONT 1654, wh. d. young; but of any more we kn. not, exc. Samuel,
2 CONT b. 26 Aug. 1661; was freem. prob. 1657, and d. 1682, his will
2 CONT being dat. 6 Sept. and pro. Dec. foll.
2 CONT In it he ment. w. three s., and d. Hannah Seymour, w. of the
2 CONT sec. Richard, only; but the Ct. supplied the deficience of his
2 CONT mem. in favor of Eliz. wh. had m. 1678, John Broughton of
2 CONT Northampton.
2 SOUR Savage

1 NOTE The marriage of Thomas and Experience is not shown in CAT,
2 CONT although there is much mention of a Thomas of Weymouth.
2 CONT According to CAT the wife of Thomas was probably Jane
2 CONT Powyes/Powys.
2 CONT There is an Experience Leland mentioned in CAT, who married
2 CONT somebody (Tom, find this).
1 NOTE Thomas Holbrook came to Weymouth, Mass in 1643, settled in
2 CONT Rehobeth, R. I. in 1645; married Experience Leland (dau. of
2 CONT Hopestill Leland of Dorchester (1643), Medfield 1668, Weymouth
2 CONT at death, will probated 24 Apr. 1677.
2 SOUR C. Dodge

1 SOUR "Bliss Book", C.A. Hoppin, 1913, said to be wrong about
2 CONT English ancestry
1 INFO Early but not original settler of Hartford of whose coming from
2 CONT England nothing is known, but his first residence was in that
2 CONT part of Boston called the mount, afterwards Braintree, now Quincy.
1 INFO In 1639 or 40 he is first mentioned in Connecticut at the same time
2 CONT with Thomas, Jr, who may be the freeman of May 18, 1642, in Mass,
2 CONT there left by his father whose death is heard of, though exact date
2 CONT is not gained.
1 INFO His widow Margaret was very resolute and capable, and after 2 or 3
2 CONT years removed with all her children except Thomas and Ann to
2 CONT Springfield.  She had 9 children and it has been absurdly said
2 CONT that all were brought from England; of most this is true.
1 SOUR Savage; Nexus, vol 6 (1989), pg 110; "Bliss Book," C.A. Hoppin, 1913

2 DATE after 1644
2 PLAC prob Branford, Connecticut
1 SOUR CAT
1 TEXT William came in the "Elizabeth and Ann," from London, 1635, aged
2 CONT 50; was admitted freeman at the Gen. Ct. 3 Mar. foll. when he
2 CONT was appoint. with Ludlow, and others, commissnrs. to rule the
2 CONT new settlem. at Conn. Serv. as rep. 1636, May in Mass. and in
2 CONT Sep. held Court in the young Col. next yr. he contin. to act as
2 CONT Assist. perhaps under the Mass. delegat. but not in 1638, when
2 CONT the inhab. of Conn. took the whole admin. of their own affairs,
2 CONT tho. their formal constitut. was not adopt. bef. Jan. 1639.
2 CONT He sat down at Wethersfield, of wh. he was rep. 1641-3; soon
2 CONT aft. being chos. again Assist. 1644, he rem. with s. Samuel and
2 CONT Daniel to the W. and lighted on or near Branford, 1644, there
2 CONT prob. d.
2 SOUR Savage
1 TEXT Branford was purchased by the New Haven colonists in Dec.,
2 CONT 1638.
2 CONT In 1644 a tract of land was sold by New Haven to Mr William
2 CONT Swain (Swayne) and others, for the accommodation of those
2 CONT persons in Wethersfield who wished to remove from thence ...
2 CONT 1643 Totokut, a place fit for a small plantation betwixt New
2 CONT Haven and Guilford, and purchased from the Indians, was
2 CONT granted to Mr. Swayne and some others in Wethersfield, they
2 CONT repaying the charges, which are betwixt 12 pounds and 13
2 CONT pounds, and joining in one jusisdiction with New Haven and the
2 CONT forenamed plantations, upon the same fundamental agreement
2 CONT settled in Oct 1643, which they duly considering accepted.
2 SOUR New Haven records Barber's "Hist. Cols. Ct."

0 @I11888@ INDI
1 NAME John /Stanley/
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE 1603
1 DEAT
2 DATE prob April or May 1634
2 PLAC aboard ship en route to America
1 SOUR Savage; CAT
1 NOTE John Stanley, brother of Thomas and Timothy "died on the way
2 CONT to New England" prob in April or May 1634, leaving three
2 CONT children, the youngest of whom died before March 3, 1634/5,
2 CONT when Thomas Stanley agreed to bring up the son John and
2 CONT provide for him, and Timothy took the dau Ruth.
2 SOUR "Hartford, Connecticut," by Barbour
1 TEXT John, br. of Thomas, d. on his passage to N.E. in 1634, leav. three
2 CONT ch. of wh. the youngest was d. bef. the order of Gen. Ct.
2 CONT in 3 Mar. 1635 as to dispos. of his goods and chattels, the whole
2 CONT being of the val.  pounds 116, pounds 58 to ea.  See Coll. Rec.
2 CONT I. 134.  The others, John, and Ruth, were several. commit. to
2 CONT uncles Thomas and Timothy.  Ruth m. 5 Dec. 1645, Isaac Moore of
2 CONT Farmington.
2 SOUR Savage
1 FAMC @F4442@
1 FAMS @F4339@
0 @I11889@ INDI

0 @I11991@ INDI
1 NAME Ephraim /Huet/
1 NAME Ephraim /Huit/
1 SEX M
1 TITL Reverend
1 ARRV
2 DATE 1639
2 PLAC Boston, Massachusetts
2 FROM Wraxall, near Kenilworth, Warwickshire, England
1 REMV
2 DATE 17 August 1639
2 PLAC Windsor, Connecticut
1 DEAT
2 DATE 4 September 1644
1 SOUR Savage; CAT
1 INFO Rev. Huit, first teacher to church of Windsor, Connecticut, and
2 CONT colleague with Rev John Warham, 1639.
2 SOUR Windsor, Connecticut, by Stiles.
1 TEXT Ephraim, Windsor, had been a min. of Wraxall, near Kenilworth, in
2 CONT Warwicksh. was proceed. against by Archbp. Laud 1638, for neglect
2 CONT of ceremonies, came next yr. with w. and ch. Susanna, Nathaniel,
2 CONT Sarah, Mercy, and Lydia; went from Boston, and reached W. 17 Aug.
2 CONT where he bec. collea. with Warham; had Mary, bapt. 2 Aug. 1640;
2 CONT and he d. 4 Sept. 1644.
2 CONT Sarah, and Nathaniel had d. 1642.
2 CONT The other four are nam. in his will, wh. is print. by Trumbull in
2 CONT Col.  Rec. I. 458.
2 CONT His wid. Isabel long outliv. him. and as admor. of his est. sold,
2 CONT 1647, to Richard Saltonstall his sh. in Swampscot and Dover
2 CONT patents, N.H. and d. 8 Mar. 1661.
2 CONT Of the ch. Susanna d. the yr. after her f. Lydia m. 10 or 20 Apr.
2 CONT 1656, Joseph Smith of Hartford; Mary m. 5 Dec. 1660, Thomas Strong
2 CONT of Northampton, and d. 1671.
2 CONT The fam. name in this branch failing, both Smith and Strong used
2 CONT it as name of bapt.
2 SOUR Savage

0 @I12356@ INDI
1 NAME Charles D /Wetmore/
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE 1867
2 PLAC possibly Elvira, New York
1 DEAT
2 DATE 9 May 1941
2 PLAC possibly New York, New York
1 RESI
2 PLAC New York, New York
1 TEXT Formerly a partner of the late Whitney Warren, and under the
2 CONT firm name of Wetmore & Warren established a reputation in
2 CONT designing modern hotel buildings in New York and other
2 CONT cities.
2 CONT
2 CONT Mr. Wetmore was a native of Elvira, N. Y., and after
2 CONT attending the city schools completed a formal education at
2 CONT Harvard, where he was graduated in 1889.
2 CONT During the five succeeding years he studied architecture in
2 CONT New York, subsequently joined Whitney Warren in partnership.
2 CONT Two of the firm's major works were the New York Central R.R.
2 CONT Terminal and the adjoining Biltmore Hotel, while other
2 CONT important buildings erected from the firm's plans include the
2 CONT Aeolian Hall, and the following Hotels: the Ritz Carlton, the
2 CONT Commodore; Ambassador; the Vanderbilt (1912), and additions
2 CONT to the Plaza Hotel, and in New York.  Warren & Wetmore also
2 CONT designed the Ritz Carlton in Atlantic City, N.J., the Belmont
2 CONT in Providence, R.I., the Westchester, Rye, N.Y., the
2 CONT Broadmoore, Colorado Springs, Colo., and the Royal Hawaiian
2 CONT in Honolulu, completed in 1937.
2 REFN Obit., New York Times, 5/10/1941;
2 REFN Architectural Record, June, 1941
1 SOUR clipping of unknown origin from Helel Pratt

1 NAME James A /Wetmore/
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE 1863
2 PLAC Bath, New York
1 RESI
2 PLAC Washington, D.C.
1 RESI
2 PLAC Coral Gables, Florida
1 DEAT
2 DATE 14 March 1940
2 PLAC possibly Coral Gables, Florida
1 TEXT Formerly (and over a period of forty-five years) Mr. Wetmore
2 CONT held the post of Architectural Supervisor of the U.S.
2 CONT Treasury Department in Washington.
2 CONT Born in Bath, N.Y., and educated in New York, he began work
2 CONT in the capital city as Court Stenographer, was first employed
2 CONT in the Treasury Department in the same capacity, later became
2 CONT a member of the Architectural Department.
2 CONT During his long connection with the Federal Government,
2 CONT numerous buildings (at least two thousand) were designed in
2 CONT his office.
2 CONT Retiring during the 1930's Mr. Wetmore spent his latter years
2 CONT in Coral Gables, Florida.

0 @I12369@ INDI
1 NAME Hiram V/Wetmore/
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE about 1842
2 PLAC Yarmouth, Yarmouth, Nova Scotia, Canada
1 NOTE He was a grandson of Captain John Wetmore.
1 EVEN newspaper article
2 TEXT HIRAM V. WETMORE, HERO
3 CONT Grandson of Capt. John Wetmore, Hiram V. Wetmore was born in
3 CONT Yarmouth about 1842.
3 CONT
3 CONT Serving in the Navy, at Sebastopal, he was commended for
3 CONT special gallantry during the bombardment.
3 CONT
3 CONT After the War, Queen Victoria gave a dinner for special heroes,
3 CONT at Windsor Castle.  She was astonished when this 14-year-old lad
3 CONT was presented and spent some time questioning him all about
3 CONT himself.  Remarking that she regretted that there was no award
3 CONT for such special gallantry, she dismissed him.  Very soon after,
3 CONT she instituted the Victoria Cross.
3 CONT
3 CONT Wetmore did not get the Cross, but he did get a special
3 CONT pension - the same as Cross-holders get - for life, in addition
3 CONT to another Pension.
3 CONT
3 CONT He died at him home in West Bay, N.B., in 1907, and is buried
3 CONT there.
3 CONT
3 CONT It is generally accepted that it was Wetmore's brave deed,
3 CONT coupled with his extreme youth, that prompted the Queen to
3 CONT institute the Cross, Britain's highest avward "For Valour."
1 DEAT
2 DATE 1907
2 PLAC West Bay, New Brunswick, Canada
1 BURI
2 PLAC West Bay, New Brunswick, Canada
1 SOUR "Down Memory Lane" column, by Blauveldt, from a Yarmouth paper, with
2 CONT no date

1 NAME Keith Robert Norton/Wetmore/
1 SEX M
1 RESI
2 DATE 1996
2 PLAC South Africa
1 NOTE He has been married for 22 years and has three sons, all Nortons.
1 LETR
2 DATE 3 May 1996
2 TEXT ... John Norton Wetmore was born 30 May 1876, presumably in
3 CONT England, probably near Bristol.
3 CONT He was my Grandfather, and married my Grandmother Edith Frances
3 CONT Ellen Williams on 10 November 1910, but I don't know where.
3 CONT I had heard that he came out to Rhodesia before this century, and
3 CONT was somehow involved with the British Forces in Southern Africa
3 CONT at the time of the Boer Wars, 1899 to 1902.
3 CONT As you know, the history of England in South Africa somewhat
3 CONT mirrored that of the North American continent 200 years previously.
3 CONT It would be ironical if the Norton Wetmores had come from loyalist
3 CONT Canada to Rhodesia, even if via England.
3 CONT
3 CONT These two produced four male children, Robert Norton W (my
3 CONT father - deceased Oct 22 1989), Grenvill George Norton W (deceased
3 CONT 14 Dec 1967), Cecil Norton living in retirement in Harare
3 CONT Zimbabwe, and incidentally very interested in the family ancestry,
3 CONT and David George Norton W (deceased21 December 1987).
3 CONT There are many next generation including myself, and our children.
3 CONT All of us left Rhodesia in the last ten to fifteen years, going
3 CONT all over the commonwealth.
3 CONT I am married to a German lady, for 22 years now, and we have three
3 CONT boys, all Nortons!
3 CONT
3 CONT My father was a diplomat, and represented Rhodesia in the USA from
3 CONT 1957 to 1962.
3 CONT My brother Michael and I were also there of course, in Washington
3 CONT DC, and the period happened to coincide with my senior school years.
3 CONT Due to the fact that in 1957 when my father was making plans to go
3 CONT to the States he happened to sit next to a Canadian insurance
3 CONT executive on a plane, I ended up at school in Canada.
3 CONT This was Ridley College in St Catharines near Niagara Falls.
3 CONT You can understand why he chose Canada, because at that time the
3 CONT Russians had just put up the first Sputnik and the Americans were
3 CONT suffering agonies of remorse and doubt over their schooling system,
3 CONT and my father was taking no chances.
3 CONT My stay in Canada was therefore punctuated with 8 times a year
3 CONT trips from St Catharines to DC.
3 CONT These commenced with steam drawn trains and ended in 1962 in
3 CONT Greyhound buses when even the electric trains were being withdrawn.
3 CONT I have not returned to those places in the intervening 34 years,
3 CONT and think that should I one day be lucky enough to revisit I
3 CONT should feel like Rip van Winkle did after his long sleep.
3 CONT My memories are vivid.
3 CONT
3 CONT My brother being 3 years older than me and knowing well the likely
3 CONT outcome of world history stayed on in 1962 and married an American
3 CONT girl on his 21st birthday.
3 CONT He is still there, living in Philadelphia I think and married for
3 CONT a second time.
3 CONT We have lost touch.
3 CONT
3 CONT In 62 on returning to Africa via England my father took me to
3 CONT visit Norton farm near Penzance in south east England.
3 CONT Near here we also spent some time with cousins who had been
3 CONT farming in the same place (in Cornwall) for some record number of
3 CONT generations.
3 CONT They were featured in National Geographic magazine a year or two
3 CONT after 1962 for that reason.
3 CONT That would probably be a fruitful source of family genealogy.
3 CONT I also have memory of a house called Henbury, I think near
3 CONT Bristol, which featured largely in the family history.
3 CONT This may have been where the Williams came from...
1 SOUR Keith Robert Norton Wetmore

1 FAMS @F4618@

2 TEXT From: kwetmore@mofo.com (Wetmore, Keith C.)
2 TEXT Organization: Morrison & Foerster LLP, 345 California St., San
2 TEXT Francisco, CA 94104
2 TEXT Date: Tue, 07 May 1996 16:29:26 -0700
2 TEXT Subject: Imagine my surprise
2 TEXT Hello Tom. My first day on the Internet, almost my first search,
2 TEXT I narcissisticly insert my own last name in a search request, and
2 TEXT I find your home page. At the risk of overstating matters, the
2 TEXT confluence of technology and history, both newly acquired, was
2 TEXT pretty overwhelming. Needless to say, I found your ancestry
2 TEXT fascinating (as it may, at least in part, be mine as well). I am
2 TEXT an attorney in San Francisco, where I have lived the last 15
2 TEXT years after growing up in Indiana. My father (Leonard Leander W.)
2 TEXT was from Northeast Illinois. His father was Alfred E. W. , who may
2 TEXT have been named after his grandfather. (I was born late in my
2 TEXT parents' lives -- at least for 1956 -- so my direct memory of
2 TEXT ancestory is fuzzy, though more information could be retrieved, I
2 TEXT think.) My mother, Doris Ann Chidester W., has done quite a bit of
2 TEXT work on the Wolfe/Gehrich side of her familty, less on the
2 TEXT Chidester side, and almost nothing with the Wetmores. In any
2 TEXT event, reply if the mood strikes. Thanks for sharing your hard work
2 TEXT with the rest of us.
1 NOTE He is an attorney in San Francisco, where he has lived for 15 years
2 CONT after growing up in Indiana.

1 BIO
2 SOUR monutainviewpeople.blogspot.com
2 TEXT Clarence Wetmore (1851-1936) First to register at Univerity of California, Berkeley
2 TEXT Clarence Wetmore???s father, Jesse Lamereaux Wetmore, was one of those adventurous 49ers who
3 CONT came to California on the trail of gold. He returned home to Maine to father the second of
3 CONT his sons, Clarence, born in 1852, and then Jesse brought his wife and his two sons, Charles
3 CONT and Clarence back to the Golden State. The family settled first in San Francisco, but by 1861
3 CONT had settled in Oakland at their new home at Clay and Tenth.
2 TEXT But Jesse had wandering feet. He left again, this time for South America, engaged in railroad
3 CONT building in Chile and later, Bolivia. The family survived, and Charles became the
3 CONT valedictorian of the Class of 1868 at the College of California in Oakland. In 1869,
3 CONT Clarence became the first student to register at the newly established University of California
3 CONT (chartered in 1868 to be the successor to the College of California). Clarence???s class attended
3 CONT classes for all four years at the old Oakland campus of the College of California, but on their
3 CONT graduation day in 1873, this group of pioneering students received their diplomas at the first
3 CONT event ever held on the Berkeley campus.
2 TEXT Clarence married Mary Camden, a California native, and with his brother Charles, founded
3 CONT Cresta Blanca Winery in the Livermore Valley in 1882. The Cresta Blanca Winery property is today
3 CONT the home of Wente Brothers Sparkling Winery and the Wente Brothers Restaurant.
2 TEXT [Wetmore bio courtesy of Barbara Smith and the Mountain View Cemetery docent program]
1 DEAT
2 DATE 1936
2 TEXT [Wetmore bio courtesy of Barbara Smith and the Mountain View Cemetery docent program]

1 NOTE He is considered the 'father' of the California wine industry.
1 NOTE He was married to Anna D. Smith.

1 SOUR Suzanne Clark
1 INFO
2 TEXT Cresta Blanca Wine Company, Livermore
2 TEXT A great name in the California wine industry, Cresta Blanca is owned by Schenley Industries.
3 CONT Since 1941 this company has operated the winery and tended the vineyards, which nestle in
3 CONT the gently sloping hills in the southeast corner of the Livermore Valley. Lucas Hat, whose
3 CONT family has been interested in growing grapes and making wine for generations, is in over-all
3 CONT charge of the vineyards and winery. The wine maker is Myron Nightingale, who has been closely
3 CONT associated with some of the industry's important experiments and achievements. A bonded winery
3 CONT is also maintained in Tulare County, right across the county line from Delano, Kern County.
3 CONT All Cresta Blanca wines are marketed through the CVA Corporation of San Francisco.
2 TEXT Founder of Cresta Blanca was the celebrated California wine pioneer Charles A. Wetmore,
3 CONT who purchased part of the old Rancho El Valle de San Jose in Livermore in 1882, planted his
3 CONT vineyards with selected imported cuttings, and built the Cresta Blanca winery in 1883.
3 CONT He named his winery and his wines after the limestone ridge which still dominates the
3 CONT vineyards and where a landslide at one time exposed a great white crest, sliced off the
3 CONT mountainside as by a giant's carving knife.
2 TEXT Charles Wetmore was born in Portland, Maine, in 1847 and came to California with his parents when
3 CONT he was nine years old. After attending public schools in Oakland he entered the newly
3 CONT established University of California, graduating with its very first class, of which he
3 CONT was valedictorian. He worked as a reporter on various newspapers, including the Alta California
3 CONT and the San Francisco Chronicle. Deeply interested in viticulture, he was appointed in 1878 as
3 CONT a delegate of the California State Vinicultural Society to visit the Paris Exposition.
3 CONT During this trip he made a thorough study of French winegrowing methods. On his return
3 CONT he organized the Board of State Viticultural Commissioners and served on it with prominence
3 CONT for a number of years. As an official of the California wine industry, as a winegrower, and as
3 CONT the author of treatises and articles on viticulture and wine production, Charles Wetmore was
3 CONT an outstanding authority on California wines for over half a century.
2 TEXT Wetmore considered that the gravelly soil at the mouth of the Canyon of the Arroyo del Valle
3 CONT in Livermore Valley offered every condition essential for producing the finest wines of the
3 CONT Bordeaux types. In Cresta Blanca he planted vines brought over from France, among them cuttings
3 CONT from Chateau d'Yquem in Sauternes and from Chateau Margaux in Medoc. He was a perfectionist in
3 CONT his methods, and the reputation of his Cresta Blanca wines became solidly established within a
3 CONT short time and their fame spread far and wide. The "Grand Prix" awarded to Cresta Blanca at the
3 CONT Paris Exposition of 1889 is said to mark the first time that California was officially recognized
3 CONT by France as a competitor in the production of fine table wines.
2 TEXT Clarence J. Wetmore, also a University of California graduate, became associated with his brother
3 CONT Charles in Cresta Blanca at an early date. In 1893 Clarence purchased the property from his brother
3 CONT and retained his connection with Cresta Blanca for over forty years, operating it until 1920,
3 CONT when he sold Cresta Blanca to L. B. Johnson. During Prohibition business was carried on, as allowed
3 CONT by the dry laws, for sacramental and medicinal purposes. With Repeal the corporation was reorganized
3 CONT with Clarence Wetmore once more as president and Johnson as general manager. With the death of
3 CONT Clarence Wetmore in 1936 Johnson became the sole owner. In 1941 the latter disposed of
3 CONT Cresta Blanca to Schenley.
2 TEXT Cresta Blanca produces table, aperitif, dessert, and sparkling wines of high quality, some of
3 CONT which are outstanding. The winery has continued to feature its white table wines grown in the Livermore
3 CONT Valley and also emphasizes its red table wines from grapes grown in the Napa and Sonoma valleys.
3 CONT Cresta Blanca has been a leader in the field of high-quality California sherries and also developed
3 CONT a flor sherry which will be marketed in the near future. High-quality ports and vermouths have
3 CONT been produced; some special port wines have not as yet been put on the market.
2 TEXT All wines are marketed under the Cresta Blanca brand, some with the added Souvenir labeling.
2 TEXT Table wines: WHITE: Dry Semillon, Sweet Semillon, Sauvignon Blanc, Chateau Sauterne, Haut Sauterne
3 CONT and Sauterne, Grey Riesling and Riesling, Chablis;
2 TEXT RED: Cabernet, Pinot Noir and Red Pinot, Burgundy and Claret;
2 TEXT ROSE: Vin Rose.
2 TEXT Sparkling wines (bottle-fermented) : Champagne (medium dry, available also in magnums), Brut
3 CONT Champagne (quite dry), Pink Champagne (medium dry), and Sparkling Burgundy;
2 TEXT Aperitif and Dessert wines: Dry Watch Cocktail Sherry (pale, dry) and Triple Cream Sherry
3 CONT (golden, sweet), aged in small cooperage and outstanding sherries both, Palomino Sherry
3 CONT (pale, dry) and Souvenir Sherry (medium dry); Tawny Port and Ruby Port; Golden Muscatel;
3 CONT White Vermouth (Triple Dry) and Sweet Vermouth.

3 CONT

3 CONT Percy Woodford Wetmore
3 CONT John Van Cott Wetmore
3 CONT David Wetmore (Daniel Van Cott Wetmore's younger brother)
3 CONT John Wetmore

3 CONT little success.

2 TEXT "Cousin John (Hancock) married Mary Deveraux, for his first
3 CONT wife, to whom five children were born: George and Henry (twins),
3 CONT Annie, Cora and Ella.  George, Henry and Cora are dead.  All
3 CONT unmarried, as far as I know.  All lived in Phila.  Annie married

3 CONT boy, Winfield Scott, died when about three years old.  Two
3 CONT girls, Bertie, next oldest, died when sixteen and Bessie died
3 CONT this year.  Bessie married Henry Horner and lived in

2 TEXT Cousin Mary (Hancock) married Joshua J. Duffy.  They had six
3 CONT children: John; Annie, Ella, Lillie, Will & Heston.  John died
3 CONT at 20; Lillie & Heston at about the same age.  Annie (who
3 CONT married Walter Turner, at Snow Hill), was about 39 when she

3 CONT in his early thirties.  Ella married David Hudson, engaged in
3 CONT the mercantile business at Snow Hill, and is still living.-- no
3 CONT children.  All, except Will, died of tuberculosis.

2 DATE 1801

1 SOUR David Wetmore email
2 EMAL dew@lightnin.brevard.edu
2 ADDR Brevard College, Brevard, NC 28712
2 TEXT I am seeking to learn of the relationship between Thankful Grace
3 CONT Wetmore, dau. of Andrew and Lucy Wetmore and Gilbert Allen
3 CONT Wetmore, son of John Wetmore, Jr. and Jane Osborn Wetmore.
3 CONT TGW was born in Vermont in 1801 and GAW was born in New York
3 CONT in 1837. Gilbert is in Stadel's book, Andrew, Lucy, and Thankful
3 CONT Grace are not.
3 CONT GAW was my great-grandfather, and he moved to Nebraska Territory
3 CONT sometime prior to 1863.
3 CONT Living near him was Sylvenus Duryea, whose mother was TGW.
3 CONT I'm more of an amateur historian than a geneaologist, and I'm
3 CONT trying to learn what took Gilbert to Nebraska.
3 CONT If you would like some information on the Nebraska Wetmores,
3 CONT I will be happy to share what I have.

1 NOTE On the same census sheet are Thomas T and Anna C Wetmore, Thomas her half brother,
2 CONT and also George S and Isadora Williams, George her nephew.
1 DEAT
2 AGE 32 years
2 DATE 7 February 1878
3 SOUR Connecticut Deaths and Burials, 1772-1934
2 PLAC Norwich, New London County, Connecticut, United States
2 CAUS Murder by arsenic poisoning by her husband Wesley Bishop
2 SOUR Vital Statistics from New Brunswick Newspapers, vol 44, item 222.
1 TEXT
2 CONT She was born in Carleton (Saint John). At the time of her death she was 32 years
2 CONT old and was a daughter of Daniel Wetmore, ship carpenter or ship builder of
2 CONT Saint John.
1 NOTE Info from Daily Telegraph, 12 July 1878 (abridged). See also D.T. July 15 page 3 and D.T. July 20 page 2.
1 NOTE Here is more text from the Saint John Daily Telegraph
2 TEXT
3 CONT Double Murder - Norwich, Conn., July 11- On June 6th, Charles H. COBB, tax collector of City and
3 CONT Township of Norwich, Conn.  while at the supper table, was taken suddenly ill and upon being
3 CONT assisted from the table to a lounge, went into convulsions and immediately expired. A post
3 CONT mortem was held, the contents of the stomach sent to Prof. Doremus of New York and the fact
3 CONT ascertained he died from arsenic. Suspicion rested upon Wesley W. BISHOP, he being an intimate
3 CONT friend of the family. Bishop's wife died in a similar manner last February. Prof Doremus came to
3 CONT the city and Mr. Cobb's remains were taken from the grave to ascertain how long the accused had
3 CONT been taking arsenic. Mrs. Bishop's body was exhumed at the same time. The coroner's jury found
3 CONT a verdict of guilty against Mrs. COBB on the charge of poisoning Mrs. BISHOP.  Mrs. Bishop's
3 CONT maiden name was Hattie E. WETMORE. She was born in Carleton (Saint John) and at the time of
3 CONT her death was 32 years old and was a daughter of Daniel WETMORE, ship carpenter or ship
3 CONT builder of Saint John. (abridged) (see also D.T., July 15 page 3 `The Norwich Double Murder') (see
3 CONT also D.T. July 20 page 2 col 2-3)
3 CONT 12 July 1878 D.T.

1 NAME Moses/Hicks/

2 DATE 29 November 1734
2 PLAC Rehoboth, Bristol County, Massachusetts
1 NOTE
2 CONT From Gayle Hix Notes:
2 CONT Moses bought 12 acres in Dighton, MA Jan 18, 1771 and sold the same 12 acres August 5, 1773.
2 CONT -- evidently moved to Richmond, NH. Warned out of town in Richmond on Mar 12, 1777.
2 CONT (This warning out also lists 7 of his 10 children -- all except Simeon, James, & Olive).
2 CONT Mr. Hix feels he removed to Royalston, MA to a 40-acre homestead purchased for him by son Simeon.
2 CONT His wife, Mary Goff, evidently died and he remarried about 1784 to Mary Bradford.
2 CONT Mr. Hix feels there is a 2nd group of 12 children by this 2nd marriage, not all identified yet.
2 CONT n an obituary for Simeon he is referred to as "the eldest son of a father who was twice married
2 CONT and had 22 children."
2 CONT Moses is listed in the 1790 census in Hoosick, Albany, NY (1,2,4); the 1800 census in
2 CONT Hebron, Washington, NY (12001-12010); 1810 census Stratford, Fulton, NY (00001-10001);
2 CONT 1820 census Sunderland, Bennington, VT - with Simeon?)
2 CONT He purchased 1 acre in Arlington, Vt 11/24/1795 and sold it 4/14/1797.
2 CONT Bought 5 acres in Sunderland, VT 4/20/1797 and sold it 8/11/1797.
1 SOUR Hicks/Hix Database - Northeast Connections

1 NAME Frank Joseph/Powell/
1 SEX M
1 TITL Reverend
1 BIRT
2 DATE 25 February 1858
2 PLAC Chester, England
1 SOUR "Lancashire: Biographies, Rolls of Honour," W. Ralph Hall Caine, London, 1917.
1 NOTE
2 CONT Powell, Rev. Frank Joseph, M.A., Vicar of Knotty Ash, and Chaplain of Alder Hey Hospital.
2 CONT
2 CONT Vicarage, Knotty Ash, Liverpool (Phone: Old Swan 258; Telegrams: Broad Green, Liverpool).
2 CONT Born: February 25th, 1858, at Chester; son of John and Martha Powell (English).
2 CONT Educated: The King's School, Chester; Oxford University; B.A., First Class Theological Honours;
2 CONT M.A., Denyer and Johnson Theological Scholarship.
2 CONT Married: June 5th, 1885, to Phoebe Elizabeth, daughter of the late Daniel Wetmore,
2 CONT of Liverpool and Lima, and has issue two sons and three daughters:
2 CONT Phoebe Mildred, M.D.
2 CONT Lois Etheldreda (serving as V.A.D. Nurse in France),
2 CONT Rev. Frank Osmund Standish, M.A.,
2 CONT Cuthbert Albar Wetmore, B.Eng., serving in France (Lieut, in South Midland Royal Engineers), and
2 CONT Joyce Frideswide.
2 CONT Profession: Vicar of Knotty Ash, Liverpool.
2 CONT Appointment: Chaplain of Alder Hey Hospital.
2 CONT Publication: "Lenten Self Discipline."
2 CONT Masonic Lodge: Lodge of Prudence 2114 (P.M., P.P.G.C.); Saint John of Jerusalem Chapter (P.Z., P.P.G.J.).

2 FROM Dana Callis, Dana.J.Callis@uscg.mil
2 DATE 22 July 2010
2 TEXT Tom,
2 CONT It would not have been unusually for her to have a baby at 15 if she was poor and
2 CONT screwing around (that how my father got here to a 16 year old mother).  In 2010 you can still
2 CONT get married in North Carolina at 14 pregnant or 16 without parents permission.
2 CONT So far as I know they are Mary's children according to the family.  They would be Doug's step sons.
2 CONT
2 CONT Douglas had no middle name or initial and neither did his father Daniel.
2 CONT Douglas's son was not a Junior as his name is Douglas Daniel Wetmore.
2 CONT The family is up to Douglas Daniel Wetmore the fourth but actually it should be the third
2 CONT because the original Douglas had no middle name.
2 CONT This will help you if you find something else on them.
2 CONT
2 CONT Dana

2 NAME Gerhard C Hubbard
2 SSN 521-34-7960
2 INFO State issued, Colorado
2 DATE 24 February 2009
2 BIRT
3 DATE 11 November 1916
2 RESI Last
3 PLAC Topeka, Shawnee, Kansas
2 SOUR Social Security Death Index
1 TEXT
2 CONT Gerhard C. Jerry Hubbard
2 CONT Gerhard C. Jerry Hubbard, 92, of Auburn, passed away Tuesday, February 24th, 2009 at
2 CONT Aldersgate Village. Jerry was born on November 11th , 1916 in Redlands, CA,
2 CONT the son of Philena and Herbert Hubbard. He graduated from the Southern Arizona School
2 CONT for Boys in Tucson, AZ, where he was active in rodeo and the polo team.
2 CONT It was here that he developed his lifelong love of horses and livestock.
2 CONT He attended college at the University of California at Davis, where he studied agriculture.
2 CONT Prior to World War II, Jerry helped manage the family cattle ranch in LaVeta, CO,
2 CONT where he met Dorothy Curry, who he would marry on November 20th , 1941, in Topeka, KS.
2 CONT He enlisted in the Army Air Corps in March, 1942, and served in the Pacific Theater until
2 CONT returning home after the war ended. Upon returning home in 1945, he and his wife bought a
2 CONT farm at Auburn, KS, on which they raised livestock and crops until retirement.
2 CONT Jerry is survived by his wife, Dorothy; children Rose Smith (Carl), Auburn, KS
2 CONT and Robin Hubbard (Jeannene), Topeka; grandchildren Gretchen Haugh (David), Olathe, KS,
2 CONT Lt.Col. David Smith (Kazumi), Hickam AFB, HI, Camden Hubbard, Topeka and Sean Hubbard (Jeri),
2 CONT Stillwater, OK, as well as 8 great-grandchildren. He was preceded in death by his brothers,
2 CONT Austin and Herbert. Jerry will lie in state after 3:00 p.m., Friday, February 27, 2009 at
2 CONT Kevin Brennan Family Funeral Home, 2801 SW. Urish Rd., Topeka, KS 66614, where the family
2 CONT will receive friends from 6-7:30 p.m. Funeral services will be held at 10:00 a.m.,
2 CONT Saturday, February 28, 2009 at Grace Episcopal Cathedral, 701 SW. 8th St, Topeka, KS, 66603.
2 CONT Interment will follow in the Reformed Presbyterian Cemetery in Winchester, KS.
2 CONT In lieu of flowers, the family suggests memorial contributions be made to the
2 CONT Alzhiemers Association or the Auburn Volunteer Fire Dept. Online condolences may be sent
2 CONT to www.kevinbrennanfamily.com. Gerhard C.

1 TEXT
2 CONT Plot 35, Lot 17
2 CONT Charles Camden (1817-1912) ??? Built First Paper Mill On West Coast
2 CONT
2 CONT Charles Camden was born in Aston Magna, England on January 29. 1817 and sailed to New York
2 CONT from Liverpool at the age of seventeen. He spent ten years in New York before sailing from Baltimore to
2 CONT Valpariso, Chile.
2 CONT
2 CONT Camden worked as an engineer in Chile and Peru, building the first paper mill on the Pacific Coast in Peru.
2 CONT While in Peru, he met and became friends and business partners with James Lick. In 1849,
2 CONT he heard about the discovery of gold up the coast in California and sailed for San Francisco.
2 CONT He worked at various occupations in Oakland and San Francisco before he and some friends decided
2 CONT that they would sail up the coast to find the Trinity River. Mistakingly believing that they had found it,
2 CONT they instead became the first boat to sail up the Eel River.
2 CONT
2 CONT He spent most of the next few years mining in Shasta County. In 1861, he built the Camden turnpike from
2 CONT Shasta to Tower House, a distance of twelve miles. Previous to that time the traffic of the
2 CONT country was carried on with pack mules, there being no wagon roads further than Shasta.
2 CONT He also fell in love during this time and married the former Philena Towner. One of his two daughters,
2 CONT Mary, married Clarence Wetmore.
2 CONT
2 CONT At the time of his death he owned property in Oakland, sawmills and mines in Shasta County
2 CONT and irrigation rights in Kern and San Diego counties.
2 SOUR Biography at mountainviewpeople.blogspot.com

2 SOUR Thomas Murray
1 DEAT
2 DATE
2 PLAC
1 NOTE 2421181. LEIGH (LEE) CARLETON WETMORE (son) b. Saint John West, Saint John Co., NB 22JUL1900.
2 CONT When Leigh Carleton Wetmore enlisted in the CEF 1AUG1916, he gave his residence
2 CONT as Lowell St, West Saint John, and his place-of-birth as Saint John and date as 22JUL1900.
2 CONT His next-of-kin he gave as his mother, Mrs. E. J. C. Wetmore.
2 CONT Apparently accepted, there is a notation that he is not allowed to proceed overseas
2 CONT until 22JUL1919. He described himself as a student, so probably was seeking adventure
2 CONT and release from the tedium of schoolwork (as well as being very patriotic.)
2 CONT He is described as 5 feet 4?? inches, with green eyes, fair complexion and light-brown hair;
2 CONT and as Church of England. He is indicated as a grenadier, suggesting he was mustered
2 CONT into a battery. He probably was accepted as his father was a major.
1 SOUR Thomas Murray?

0 @I13721@ INDI
1 NAME Rita B /Wetmore/
1 SEX F
1 BIRT
2 DATE 7 June 1918
2 PLAC Cambridge, Massachusetts
2 SOUR Daphne Baird Wetmore research.
1 DEAT
2 DATE 30 December 1989
2 PLAC Boston, Massachusetts
2 SOUR Daphne Baird Wetmore research.
1 OBIT Rita B. (Wetmore) Schmidt, 95, of Marblehead, originally of Cambridge, then Winchester, Boston, Rockport,
2 CONT and Cambridge again, passed away after a lengthy decline. Daughter and last child of the late Sherwood
2 CONT Jerry and Elizabeth Wetmore of Cambridge. Graduate of Cambridge Latin School, class of 1934, and Radcliffe
2 CONT College, class of 1938. Widow of the late Arthur P. Schmidt of Winchester, Boston, and Rockport.
2 CONT Survived by her son, Arthur and his wife Aurora Camacho of Media, Pennsylvania; her son, Mark and his
2 CONT wife Alicia Andrews of Marblehead; her grandchildren, Alicia, Genevieve, and Allison; step grandchildren,
2 CONT Jennifer, Janie, and Anna; her great grandchildren, Antonio, Thalia, Nayeli, and Elena Paz;
2 CONT and step great grandchildren, Abigail and Christopher.
2 CONT A funeral was celebrated at Our Lady Star of the Sea Church, 85 Atlantic Avenue, Marblehead on Tuesday,
2 CONT October 30 at 10AM.
2 CONT Cremation followed by interment will be at a later date.
2 CONT Relatives and friends respectfully invited.
2 CONT Visiting hours were held at the Eustis and Cornell Funeral Home, 142 Elm Street, Marblehead on Monday,
2 CONT October 29 from 4-8PM.
2 CONT In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Ritas memory to Oxfam America, 226 Causeway Street,
2 CONT 5th Floor, Boston, MA 02114. Please visit the online guestbook at www.austisand cornellfuneralhome.com

1 NAME Carole Elizabeth/Blair/

1 BIRT
2 DATE 31 October 1945
2 PLAC Saint John, New Brunswick, Canada
2 SOUR Daphne Baird Wetmore research.
1 NOTE She was adopted by Audrey Elizabeth Young and her first husband, Robert Blair.
2 CONT They were married in 1941 and lived in Iowa. Audrey divorced Robert and found employment
2 CONT as a housekeeper on a farm in Bloomfield. She married the hired hand, Frank Wetmore,
2 CONT in 1951. Carole lived with them until she was in eighth grade, then she moved
2 CONT to Iowa for high school. She then married and moved to Missouri.
2 CONT She found her birth family in 2002 and has become close with them.
2 CONT They are in New Brunswick.

1 FAMS @F5104@
0 @I13801@ INDI
1 NAME Frederick Douglas /Pettem/
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE 1 December 1919
1 DEAT
2 DATE 3 January 1976
2 CAUS Complications from diabetes.
1 NOTE Served as a pilot in the R.C.A.F. in World War II on active duty overseas.
1 NOTE Fred graduated from the University of British Columbia with a B.Sc.A. and M.Sc.A. and
2 CONT at the University of Rutgers in New Jersey as Ph.D., completing his post-doc training at
2 CONT Calpoly [California] and receiving a professorship at Caltech in the mid-1960's.
2 CONT He moved his family to E. Nigeria in 1967 as a Peace Corps consultant, just in time for the
2 CONT proclamation of the Republic of Biafra, and was instrumental in aiding the exodus of
2 CONT foreigners from that country.  He then spent several years in war-torn Viet Nam as an
2 CONT Agricultural Adviser with Development & Resources [D&R]; meanwhile the rest of the family
2 CONT took up residence in Madrid, Spain. 1969 saw the family on the Island of Ceylon, where Fred
2 CONT was on assignment as an agricultural expert to the Ceylonese government. In 1970, Political
2 CONT turmoil precipitated a move to India, where Fred joined the United Nation's F.A.O. Subsequent
2 CONT assignments took Fred to Italy, Lesotho and Laos [1974-75]. In December 1975, Fred was
2 CONT hospitalized in Bangkok, Thailand and died on January 3, 1976 from complications arising
2 CONT from a diabetic crisis. Gwen lived in Southern Spain until July 1998, at which time she
2 CONT decided to return to California, where she currently resides [2010] near her daughter, Susan.
2 SOUR Fred Douglas Pettem and Descendants, history updated by Susan and Mark Pettem in 1999.
1 SOUR Mark Pettem, his son.
1 FAMS @F5105@
0 @I13802@ INDI
1 NAME Mark Andrew /Pettem/
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE 30 October 1962
2 PLAC San Dimas, California
2 SOUR Mark Pettem, himself
1 NOTE Mark Pettem [third child of Fred Pettem], born October 30, 1962, traveled with the family
2 CONT around the world from the age of 4 and completed his secondary education at a boarding school
2 CONT in England, where he resided until 1979. Mark subsequently returned to Spain, where he studied
2 CONT Business Adminstration and began to work as the Marketing Communications Manager for the
2 CONT Spanish subsidiary of Siemens Metering, a division of Siemens Corp. He currently runs his
2 CONT own technological company and operates throughout Spain and Portugal. He was married [in 1987]
2 CONT to Mercedes Peñalver born April 5, 1961], an attorney from Sevilla, Southern Spain, who
2 CONT works in the legal services of the Andalusian Regional Government. They have two children:
2 CONT Frederick born February 29, 1990 and Beatriz born August 13, 1995.
1 SOUR Mark Pettem, himself
1 FAMC @F5105@
1 FAMS @F5107@
0 @I13803@ INDI
1 NAME John Frederick Douglas /Pettem/
1 SEX M
1 BIRT
2 DATE 27 July 1950
2 PLAC Vancouver, British Columnbia, Canada
1 SOUR Mark Pettem, his brother
1 NOTE John Pettem [first child of Fred Pettem] born July 27, 1950 at Vancouver, B.C. John married
2 CONT Silvia Veith, December 2, 1972. They have two daughters:
2 CONT Daisy, born September 13, 1973 at Boulder, Colorado and
2 CONT Clara born March 13, 1977 also at Boulder, Colorado.
2 CONT John and Silvia divorced in 1986. Although Silvia remarried after she and John divorced, she
2 CONT retained the Pettem name. As "Silvia Pettem" she has authored several books on Colorado History
2 CONT and writes a weekly newspaper column. John operates a printing business in Las Vegas, Nevada
2 CONT and lives at Pahrump, Nevada.
1 SOUR Mark Pettem, his brother

0 @I15791@ INDI
1 NAME Marie A /O'Brien/
1 SEX F
1 BIRT
2 DATE about 1925
2 PLAC Lawrence, Massachusetts, United States
1 DEAT
2 DATE 3 July 2013
2 PLAC Lawrence, Massachusetts, United States
1 SOUR Her obituary in Lawrence Eagle-Tribune
1 OBIT Lawrence, MA
2 CONT Marie A. (O'Brien) Wetmore, 88, of Lawrence, passed away peacefully July 3, at the
2 CONT Merrimack Valley Hospice House in Haverhill, surrounded by her loving family.
2 CONT She was born in Lawrence, and was the daughter of the late Frank and Edith (Thompson) O'Brien.
2 CONT Marie was raised in Lawrence and attended the Bruce School and Lawrence High School, Class of 1942,
2 CONT and continued her education at Lawrence General Nursing School, Class of 1945.
2 CONT While attending nursing school, she was a member of the U. S. Cadet Nurse Corps.
2 CONT Marie continued her nursing career at the Lawrence General Hospital for 26 years,
2 CONT and then for Dr. Mallen for 18 years, prior to retirement.
2 CONT She was also a member of the Lawrence General Nursing School Alumni Association,
2 CONT which she served as past president,
2 CONT and was a devoted parishioner for 60 years of St. Patrick's Parish in South Lawrence.
2 CONT
2 CONT Marie is predeceased by her husband of 55 years, Gordon W. Wetmore,
2 CONT and is survived by four children, Richard D. Wetmore and his wife, Kathleen of Methuen,
2 CONT Janet L. Nardi and her husband, Dominick of West Hartford Conn.,
2 CONT William Wetmore and his wife, Rosemarie of Andover, Mary W. Wetmore of Salem, Mass.;
2 CONT five grandchildren, Jennifer, Nathaniel, Kristin, Andrea, and Reed;
2 CONT a sister, Helen Kenyon of Minneapolis, Minn.;
2 CONT and many loving nieces and nephews.
2 CONT
2 CONT ARRANGEMENTS: Relatives and friends may call Monday, July 8, from 4 to 8 p.m.,
2 CONT at the Kenneth H. Pollard Funeral Home, 233 Lawrence St., in Methuen.
2 CONT A Mass of Christian Burial will take place on Tuesday July 9, at 11 a.m.,
2 CONT at St Patrick's Church in Lawrence, with burial to follow at St. Mary Immaculate Cemetery in Lawrence.
2 CONT In lieu of flowers, donations in Marie's honor may be made to Merrimack Valley Hospice,
2 CONT 360 Merrimack St., Bldg. 9, Lawrence, MA 01843, or http//www.merrimackvalleyhospice.org/.
2 CONT The Kenneth H. Pollard Funeral Home would like to extend a heartfelt thank you to the
2 CONT Wetmore family for allowing us to assist them with the arrangements. www.pollardfuneralhome.com.
